availability.p: This keyboarded and encoded edition of the work described above is co-owned by the institutions providing financial support to the Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership. This Phase I text is available for reuse, according to the terms of Creative Commons 0 1.0 Universal. The text can be copied, modified, distributed and performed, even for commercial purposes, all without asking permission.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

lg.l: The double sorow of Troylus to telle
Kyng Pryamus sone of Troye
In louyng / how hys auentures felle
From woo to wele / and after out of Ioye
My purpos is / or that I parte froye
Thesipho ne thow help me for to endyte
These woful verses / that wepyn as I wryte
To the clepe I goddesse of turment /
Thou cruel fury / sorowyng euer in payne
Help me that am the sorowful instrument
That help louers / as I can to playne
For wel sitte / the sooth for to sayne
A woful wyght / to haue a drery fere
And to a sorowful tale / a sory chere
For I that god of louys seruauntis serue
Ne dar not loue / for myn vnlyklynesse
Pray for spede / al shuld I therfore sterue
So fer am I / from hys help in derknesse
But natheles / yif thys may do gladnesse
To ony louer / and hys lady auayle
Haue he the thank / and myn be the trauayle
But ye loners that bathen in gladnesse
Yf ony drope of pyte in yow be
Remembre yow in passyd heuynesse
That ye han felt / and in the aduersite
Of other folk / and thynk how that ye
Haue felt how loue durst yow dysplease
Or ye haue wonne hem wyth to grete ease
And pray for hem that ben in the caas
Of Troylus as ye may after here
That loue hym bryng / in heuene to solace
And eke for me prayeth / to god so dere
That I haue myght / to shewe in som̄e manere
Such peyne & woo / as louys seruaūtis endure
As in Troylus vnsely aduenture
And byddyth eke for hem that ben dyspayred
In loue / that neuer wyl recouered be
And eke for theym that falsly ben apeyred
Thurgh wykked tunges / be yt he or she
Thus prayeth god / for hys benygnyte
So graūt hym soone / out of thys world to pace
That is dyspeyred out of louys grace
And byddyth eke for hem / that ben at ease
That god graunt hem ay / good • perseueraunce
And send hem myght / their ladyes for to please
That is to loue by worshyp and plesaunce
For so hope I my self best auaunce
To pray for hem that loues seruauntis be
And wryte theyr woo / and lyue in charyte
And for to haue on theym compassioun
As though they were theyr owne brethern dere
Now herkenyth wyth good entencioun
For now I wil go streyght to my matere
Iy whyche ye may the double sorow here
Of Troylus in louyng of Criseyde
And how she forsooke hym or he deyde
• T is wel wyst / how ye Grekis strong
In armes with a thousand shippes wēt
To troye ward / and the cit • e long
Assyegid wel t • n yere or they stent
And in dyuerse wyse / and oon entent
The rauysshyng to wreke / of Heleyne
By Paris don they wrought alle theyr peyne
Now fyl it soo that in the toun ther was
Dwellyng a lord of grete auctoryte
A grete deuynour / that clepyd was Calcas
That in science so expert was he
Knewe wel that Troye shuld destroyed be
By answere of hys god / that hyght thus
Dan Phebus or Appollo Delphycus
So whan calcas knewe by calculyng
And eke by answer of thys Apollo
That grekis shuld suche a peple bryng
Thurgh whyche that Troye must be fordo
He cast anon out of the toun to go
For wele he wys • e by sort that Troye sholde
Dystroyed be who so wold or nolde
For whyche he thought to departe softly
Toke purpos thus in ful vnknowen wyse
And to the grekis went ful pryuely
He stale anon and they in curteys wyse
Hym dyden both worshyp and seruyse
In trust that he had connyng hem to rede
In euery peryle / whyche that stood in drede
Noyse vp roos whan it was fyrst espyed
In alle the toun / and openly was spoken
That calcas traytour fled / was and alyed
To hem of grece / and cast was to be wroken
On hym that falsely hath hys fayth so broken
And sayd he and alle hys kynne attones
Were worthy to be brent bothe fel and bones
Now had Calcas left in thys myschaunce
Vnwyst of thys fals and wykked dede
A doughter whyche that was in grete penaūce
And of her lyf she was ful sore in drede
And wyst neuer what best was to rede
And as a wydewe was she al alone
And • yst to whom / she durst make her mone
Criseide was thys ladyes name a ryght
As to my dome in al Troyes citee
Most fayrest lady for passyng euery wyght
So Aungelyk shone hyr natyf beaute
That thyng none mortal femyd she
And ther wyth was she so perfyte a creature
As she had be made in scornyng of nature
Thys lady that alday / herd at ere
Hyr fader shame / falshed and treason
Ful nygh out of hyr wyt / for sorow & fere
In wydewes habyte large of samy te broun
Byfore Hector on knees she fyl adoun
Hys mercy lad / hyr self excusyng
Wyth pytous voys / and tenderly wepyng
Now was thys Hector pytous of nature
And sawe that she was sorowful bygon
And that she was so fayr a cr • ature
O • hys goodnes / he gladyd her anon
And sayd / late your faders treason gon
Furth wyth myschaunce & ye your self • n Ioye
〈◊〉 with vs while your good liste in troye
And al ye honour that men may do yow haue
As • erforth as though your fader dwe • id here
Ye shul haue / and your body shul men saue
As fer as I may ought enquyre and here
And she hym thanked with ful humble chere

And ofter wold / and it
•• d ben hys wyl
Toke her leue went home / and held hyr styl
And in her hous abode wyth suche meyne
As to hyr honour nede was to hold

And whyle that she was dwellyng in ye
〈◊〉
Kept hyr estate / and both of yong and old
Ful wel be • uyd and men of hyr told
But whether she child had or non
I rede it not / Therfor I lete it gon
The thynges fyl as they don of wer • e
Betwyx hem of Troye and Grekis ofte
For som̄e day bought they of Troye derre
And eft the Grekis founde nothyng soft
The folk of Troye / and thus fortune aloft
And vndyr eft gan hem to repente bothe
After theyr cours whan they wer • wroth
But how thys town com to distruction
Ne fallyth not to purpos me to telle
For it were here a long dygressioun
Fro my matyer / and yow ful long to dewlle
But the Troian gestis as they telle
In Omere in Dares / or in Dyte
Who so that can may rede hem as they wryte
And though ye greekis theym of Troie shet • en
Had and theyr atre besiegyd al aboute
Yet for alle theyr vsage wold they not letten
To worship & honour they goddis ful deuoute
Wyth most reuerence in honour out of doute
They worshypped a reliquyk callid Palladion
On whom was alle theyr trust aboue echon
And so byfel whan comen was the tyme
Of Apryll whan clothyd is the m • de
Wyth newe grene of lusty veer the pryme
And swete smellyng flowres whyte and rede
In sundry wyse shewyd as I rede
The folke of Troye theyr obseruaunces old
Palladion feste wente for to hold
Vnto the temple in alther beste wyse
Generally theyr wente many a wyght
To berkene of Palladion seruyce
And namely many a lusty knyght
And many a lady fressh and mayden bryght
Ful wel arayed both mest and lest
Both for the season and the hye fest
Among thise other folk was Criseyda
In wydewes habyte black / but natheles
Ryght as our first lettir is now an A
In beawte fyrst / so stode the makeles
Her goodly lookyng / gladdyd alle the pres
Nas neuer seen thyng to be preysed derre
Nor vnder clowd black so bryght a sterre
As was Criseyde / as folke sayd echone
That her beheld in her black weede
And yet she stood ful lowe and styl alone
Behynd other folk in lytel brede
And nye the dore vnder shames drede
Symple of atyre / and debonayre of chyere
Wyth ful assuryd lookyng and manyere
Thys Troylus as he was wont to guyde
Hys yong knyghtes lad hem vp and doun
In thyl • t large temple / on euery syde
Beholdyng ay the ladyes of the town
Now here now there / for no deuocioun
Had he to none to reuen hym hys reste
But gan to prayse and last whan hym leste
And in hye walk ful fast he gan to wayten
Yf knyght or sauyer / of hys •• mpanye
Gan for to sigh / or lete hys • yen •• yten
On ony womman that be coude espye
He wold smyle and hold it a folye
And said hē thus god wote she slepith ful s • ft
For loue of yow / whan ye torne fut oft
I haue herd trl pardieu • of yowre lyuyng
Ye louers and eke your lewde obseruaunces
And whyche a labour / folk haue in wynnyng
Of loue and in the kepyng whyche dout • lias
And whan your pray is lost wo & p • naunces
O veray foolis / blynde and nyce be 〈◊〉
Ther is not one can ware by other be
And with y• word he wold cast vp the browe
A staunce is thys not wele y spoken
At whiche the god of loue gan loken rowe
Ryght for despyte / and shoope to be wroken
He kyd anon / hys lowe was not broken
For sodaynly be hyt hym at the ful
And yet as prowd a pecok can he pul
O blynd world / O blynd entencioun
How oft fallyth alle theffes contrarye
Of sur quydrye and foul presumpcioun
For caught is prowd & caught is debonayre
Thys Troylus is clombyn on the stayre
And lytel wenyth that he shall descenden
But alday faylith thyng / that foolis wenden
As prowd bayard begynnyth for to skyp
Out of the way / so prykyth hym hys corn
Tyl he a lassh haue of the long-whyp
Than thynkyth he though I praunce al byforn
Fyrst in the trays / ful fat and newe y shorn
Yet am I but an hors / and horses lawe
I must endure / and wyth my feeris drawe
So fierd it by this fyers and prowd kynyght
Though he a worthy kynge sones were
And wend nothyng had had suche myght
Agenst hys wyl that shuld hys hert stere
Yet wyth a looke hys hert way a fuyre
That be that now was most in pryde aboue
Wax sodaynly most subgect vnto loue
For thy ensample take of thys man
Ye wyse prowde and worthy folkes alle
To scorne loue / whyche that so soone can
The fredom of yowre hertis to hym thralle
For euer it was and euer be shall
That loue is he / that all thyng may bynde
For noman may fordo the lawe of kynde
That this is sooth is prouyd and doth yit
For thys trow I ye knowen alle and som̄e
Men reden not that folk haue gretter wyt
Than they yt han ben most wyth loue y nome
And strengest folk be therwyth ouercome
The worthyest and grettest of degre
Thys was and is / and yet men shul it fee
And trewly it fallyth wel to be soo
For alther wysest han therwyth ben pleasid
And they that han ben althermost in woo
Wyth loue haue ben conforted most and easid
And oft it hath the cruel hert apeasid
And worthy folk made worthyer of name
And causith most to drede vyce and shame
Now sith it may not goodely be wythstonde
And is a thyng so vertuous in kynde
Refusith not in loue to bounde
Sith as hym self lyst he may yow bynde
The yerd is better that bowen wyl and wynde
Than that that brestith / and therfor I yow rede
To folowe loue / that yow so wel can lede
But forth to telle / in especyal
As of this kynge sone of whyche I told
And lete other thynges collateral
Of hym thynk I my tale forth to hold
Both of hys Ioye and of hys cares cold
And all hys werkis towchnyg thys matere
For ther as I gan I wyl therto refere
Within the temple he wēte hym forth pleyeng
Thys Troilus of euery wight aboute
On thys lady and now on that lokyng
Whether so she were of towne or of wythoute
And vpon caas byfel that thurgh a Yowte
Hys eye perad and so depe it went
Al on Criseide it smet and there it stent
And sodaynly he wax therwyth astonyed
And gan hyr bet behold in thryfty wyse
O mercy god thought he / wher hast yu woned
That art so fayre and goodly to deuyse
Therwyth hys herte began to sprede and ryse
And soft sighed / lest men myght hym here
And caught agayn hys fyrst pleyeng chere
She was nat wyth the leste / of hyr stature
But alle her lymmes / so wel answeryng
Weren to wommanhode / that creature
Nas neuer lasse mannyssh in semyng
And eke the pure wyse of her meuyng
Shewyd wele that men myght in her gesse
Honour estate / and wommanly noblesse
Tho Troilns ryght wonderly wel withal
Gan for to lyke her meuyng and hyr chyere
Whyche sumdel deynous was for she leete fal
Hyr looke a lyte asyde in suche manece
Askaunce what may I nat stond here
And after that her lookyng gan she lyght
Hym neuer thought haue seen so good a sight
And of hyr looke in hym ther gan quyken
So grete desire / and suche affectioun
That hys hert bottum it gan styken
Of hyr fygure wyth deepe oppressioun
And though he eerst had powred vp & doun
He was tho glad / hys hornes in to shrynke
Vnneth wist he how to looke or wynke
Lo he that leete hym self so connyng
And scorned theym that louys peynes dryen
Was ful vnware / that loue hath his dwellyng
Within the subtyl streames / of hyr eyen
That sodaynly hym thought he shuld dyen
Ryght wyth hyr looke the spyrit in hys hert
Blissed he loue / that can thus folk conuert
She thus in black / lykyng to Troylus
Ouer al thyng / he stode to beholde
Ne hys desyre / ne wherfor he stode thus
He neuer chyere made / ne word told
But from after / hys maner to behold
On other thyng somtyme hys looke he caste
And eft on hyr whyle the seruyse laste
And after thys not fully al awapyd
Out of the temple / al easily be went
Repentyng hym that he had euer Iapyd
Of louie folk / lest fully the descent
Of scorn fyl on hym self / but what he ment
Lest it were wyst in ony maner syde
Hys woo he gan dyssimulen / and to hyde
Whan he was fro the temple thus departed
He streyght anon / vnto hys palays turnyth
Right with hir look thurh shot & thurh dar tid
So feyneth he in lust / ther he soiournyth
And al his chere & speche / also he bournyth
And ay of louys seruauntis / euery whyle
Hym self to wicke at hem he gan to smple
And sayd lord so ye lyue alle in lese
Ye louers for the connyngest of yow
That seruyth most ententysly and lest
Hym t •• therof as often harme as prow
Your huyre is quyt agayn / ye god wote how
Nat wele for wele / but scorn for good see nyce
In feyth youre ordir is / r ••• d in goodely wyse
In no certayne ben al your obseruaun •• s
But it a sely feyre peyntes be
Ne nothyng askyth so grete attendaunces
As doeth your lay / and that knowen al ye
But that is not the worst so mo • e I the
But told I yow the worst poynt I leue
All sayd I soth / ye wold at me greue
But take thys that ye louers oft eschyewe
Or ellis don of good entrncioun
Ful oft your lady / wyl it mys conscriewe
And deme it harme / in her oppynyoun
And yit yf she for other encheason
Be wroth th • ne shalt yu haue a groyne 〈◊〉
Lord wele is hym / that may be of yow 〈◊〉
But for al thys / whan that he sawe hys tyme
He held his peas noke other boote hym gayned
For loue bygan hys fethyrs for to lyme
That wel vnneth vnto hys folk he feyned
That other besy nedis / hym dystrayned
For wo was hym that what to do he nyst
But bad hys folk go wher that hem lyst
And whan that he in chambre was alone
He doun vpon hys beddis feete hym sette
And fyrst he gan do sigh / and eft to grone
And thought ay so on hyr / wythouten lette
That as he sat and woke / hys spirit mette
That he her sawe temple and alle the guyse
Ryght of her looke / and gan it newe aduyse
Thus gan he make a myrrour of hys mynde
In whyche he sawe al hool hyr fygure
And that he wel coude / in hys hert fynde
It was to hym a ryght good auenture
To loue suche one / and yf he dyd hys cure
To seruen hyr yit myght he fal in grace
Or ellis for one of hyr seruauntis pace
Imagynyng that trauayle ne grame
Ne myght not for so goodely one be lorn
As she ne hym for no desyre ne shame
Al wers it wyst / but in pryce vp born
Of al louers wel more than byforn
Thus argued he in hys begynnyng
Ful vnauysed of hys woo comyng
Thus toke he purpos / louys craft to syewe
And thought he wold werke pryuely
Fyrst to hyde hys desire in mewe
From euery wyght y born vttirly
But he myght ought recouered be therby
Remembryng hym that loue to wyde y blowe
Yeldith vetter fruyt though swete seede be sowe
And ouer al thys moche more he thought
What for to speke / and what to hold ynne
And to art her to loue he fought
And a song / anon ryght to begynne
And gan lowd on hys sorow for to wynne
For wyth good hope / he gan fully assent
Cryseyde for to loue / and not to repente
And of hys songe not only the sentence

As wryteth myn auctour / callyd
• ollius
But pleynly saue oure tonges difference
I dare wel say in al that Twylus

Seyde in hys song
• o euery word ryght thus
As I shal seyn / and who so lyst it • err
Is next thys vers ye may it fynden nere
Yf no loue is / O god what ferle I so
And yf loue is what thyng and whych is he
Yf loue be good from whens comyth my we
Yf it be wycke / a wondyr thynkyth me
Whan euery •• ment and aduersice
That comyth of hym may to me sau • ry thynk
For ay thryse I the more that I it dryust
And yf that at myn owne lust I beenne
Frō whens comyth my wayllyng & my pleynt
Yf harm angre me / wherto pleyne I thenne
I note not why vnwery that I feynt
O quyst deth / O s • bete harme so queynt
How may of the in me be suche quantyte
But yf I consent / that it so be
And yf that I consent wrongfully
Conpleyne ywys / thus possid to and fro
Al styerles / wythin a bote am I
Amydde the see betwyn wyndes two
That in contrary stondyn euermo
Alas what is thys wondyr maladye
For hete of cold / for cold of hete I dye
And to the god of loue thus sayd he
Wyth pytous voys / O lord now yowre is
My spirit whyche that ought yowris be
Yow thank I lord / yt haue me brought to this
But whether goddesse or womman ywis
She be I note whyche that ye do me serue
But as hyr man I wyl ay lyue and sterue
Ye stonden in her eyen / myghtyly
As in a place / vnto your vertu dygne
Therfor lord yf my seruyce or I
May lyke yow / so be to me benygne
For myn estate Royal / I here resigne
In to her hande / and wyth ful humble chere
Bycome hyr man as to my lady dere
In hym ne deyned to spare blood Royal
The fyre of loue wherfrom god me blesse
Ne hym forbare in no degre for al
hys excellent or vertuous prowesse
But held hym as hys thral / in loue dystresse
And brent hym so in sondry wyse al newe
That sixty tyme a day / he lost hys hewe
So moche day from day / hys owne thought
For lust to hyr / gan quyken and encreace
That euery other charge he sette at nought
For thy sul oft / hys hote fyre to ceace
To see her goodly chere he gan to preace
For therby to be eased wel he wend
And ay the nere he was / the more he brend
But whan he had a space / from hys care
Thus to hym self / ful oft he gan to pleyne
He sayd a foole / now art thou in the snare
That whylom Iapydest / at loues peyne
Now art yu bent / now gnaw thyn owne cheyne
Thou were ay wont / eche louer to reprehende
Of thynge the which thou canst the not defende
What wyl now euery louer / say of the
If thys be wyst / but euer in thyn absence
Laugh in scorn / and sey lo wher goth he
That is the man / of so grete sapyence
That held vs louers / lest in reuerence
Now thanked be god / he may go in the daūce
Of hem that loue lyst / fyebly to auaunce
But o thou woful Troylus god wold
Syth thou must loue / thurgh thy destyne
That thou byset were / on suche one that shold
Knowe al thy woo / al lakked her pyte
But also cold / in loue towardis the
Thy lady is / as frost in wynter moone
And thou for done as frost in wynter soone
God wold I were aryued in the port
Of deth the whyche / my sorow wyl me lede
A lord to me it were a grete comfort
Than were I quyte of langusshyng in drede
For by myn hyd sorow y blowen in brede
I shal y iaped be / a thousand tyme
More than a foole of whos foly men ryme
But now help god / and ye swete for whom
I pleyne / y caught ye neuer wyght so fast
O mercy dere hert / and help me from
The deth / for I whyle my lyf may last
More than my self wyl loue yow to my last
And with som frendly looke / gladith me swete
Though neuer nothyng more ye me byheete
These wordis / and ful many another to
He spack and callid euer in his compleynt
Hyr name for to tellyn hyr / he is woo
Tyl nygh that he in salt teris dreynt
Al was for nought / she herd not hys pleynt
And whan that he bethought / on that folye
A thousand fold / hys woo gan multiplye
By waylyng in hys chambre / thus alone
A frend of hys / that callid was Pandare
Come oones in / and herd hym grone
And saw hys frend / in suche dystres and care
Alas quod he / who causith alle thys fare
O mercy god / what vnhap may thys mene
Hane now thus soone / greekis made yow lene
Or hast thou som̄e remors / of conscience
And art now fallen / in som̄e deuocioun
And waylest for thy synne & for thyn offence
And hast for fere / caught contricioun
God saue hem that bysieged haue thys toun
That so can leye / our Io • te on presse
And bryng oure lusty folk / to holynesse
These wordis sayd he / for the nones alle
That with such thing he might him āgry makē
And wyth hys angre / do hys sorow falle
As for the tyme / and hys corage awaken
And wel wyst he / as fer as tunges spaken
Ther nas a man of gretter hardynesse
Than he / ne nomore desired worthynesse
What caas quod Twilus tho / or what aduēture
Hath guyded the / to see me languysshyg
That am refuse / of euery creature
But for the loue of god / at my prayeng
Go hens away / for certis my deyeng
Wyl the dysease / and I mote nedis deye
Therfor go hens / ther is nomore to seye
But yf thou wene / I be thus sike for drede
It is not so / and therfor scorn me nought
Ther is another thyng I take of heede
Wel more thā ought the grekis han yit wrought
Whyche cause is of my deth / sorow & thought
But though I now tel it the ne lest
Be thou not wroth I hyde it for the best
Thys Pandare that ny malt / for woo & 〈◊〉
Ful oft sayd alas / what may thys be
Now frend quod he / yf euer loue or tro ••••

Hath ben or is / bytwene the and
〈◊〉
Ne do thou neuer / suche a cruelte
To hyde from me thy frende / suche a 〈◊〉
Wost thou not wel / that I am pandare
I wyl part wyth the al the peyne
Yf it be so / I do the no confort
As it is frendis ryght / sooth for to seyne
To entreparte woo / as glad dysport
I haue and shal for trew or fals report
In wrong and ryght / I loued the al my ly •••
Hyde not thy woo from me / but telle it blyue
Than gan thys sorowful Troylus to si ••
And sayd hym thus / god lieue it be my 〈◊〉
To tel it the / for sith it may the lyke
Yit wyl 〈◊〉 / though myn hert brest
And wel wote I / thou mayst do no rest
But lest thou deme / I trust not to the
Now herk frend / for thuo it standyeth wyth 〈◊〉
Loue ageynst whyche / who so defendyth
Hym self most / it al therlist au • ylith
Wyth dyspeyre / so sorowfully me offendyth
That ser • yght vnto the deth / myn bert say ••••
Therto desire / so brennyngly me assay •• th
That to be slayne / it were a gret • er Ioy •
To me than co be kyng / of Grece and Troye
Suffisith thys my ful frend Pandare
That I haue sayd / for now wost thou my 〈◊〉

And for the loue of god / my cold
〈◊〉
Hyde it wel / I told it neuer nomo
For harmes myght folowe me than two
Yf it were wyst / but be thou in gladnes
And lete me sterue / vnknow of my dysires
How hast thou thus / vnknydly and long
Hyd thys fro me / thou foole quod Pandarus
Perauenture thou mayst / after sucheon long
That myn aduyse / anon may helpen vs
Thys were a wounder thyng / quod Troylus
Thou cowdyst neuer in loue / thy self wysse
How deuyl mayst thou than / bryng me to blisse
Ye •• ylus herken now / quod Pandare
Though I be nyce / it happith often so
That oon that excesse doeth / ful euylfare
By good counsayl / can kepe hys frend therfro
I haue my self seen a blynd man go
There as he fyl / that cowde looke wyde
A foole may eke / a wyse man often guyde
A wheston / is no keruyng instrument
But yit it makyth / sharp keruyng coolis
And there thou woost / that I haue myswent
Eschiew thou that / for suche thyng to scoole is
Thus oft wyse men / ben ware by foolis
Yf thou do soo / thy wyt is wel bewarid
By hys contrary / is euery thyng declarid
For how myght euer / swetnesse be knowe
To hym that neuer / tastid bytternesse
Ne noman may / be inly glad I trowe
That neuer was in sorow / or som̄e dystresse
Eke white by black / by shame eke worthynesse
Eche set by other / more for othyr semyth
As men may see / and so the wyse it demyth
Syth thus of two contraryes / is oo lore
A that haue so oft / in loue assayed
Greuaunces ought conne / wel the more
Counsayle the / of that thou art dysmayed
And eeke the not ought / be euyl apayed
Though I desire / wyth the for to bere
Thyn heuy charge / it shal the lasse dere
A wote wel / it farith thus by me
As to thy brother Paris / and a pryncesse
Whyche that y clepyd was Oenont
Wrote in a compleynt / of hyr heuynesse
Thou sawe the lettir / that she wrote I gesse
Nay neuer yit ywys / quod Troylus
Now quod Pandare / herken it was thus
Phebus that fyrst founde / art of medicyne
Quod she that cowd / in euery wyghtis 〈◊〉
Remedy and rede / by herbis he knew fyne
Yet to hym self / hys connyng was ful lure
For loue had hym / bound in a snare
Al for the doughter of the kyng Am •••
That alle hys craft / no cowd • hys sorowes bete
Ryght so fare I / vnhappily for me
A loue one beste / and that me smertyth fore
And yit perauenture can I reden the
And not my self / repreue me nomore
A haue no cause I wote wel for to fore
As doeth an hawke / that lysteth for to • bey
But to thyn help / somwhat can I sey
And of o thyng / ryght siker mayst thou be
That certeyn for to dyen in the pryne
That shal I neuer more / dyscou • ren the
Ne by my trowth / I •• epe not restreyne
The from thy loue / though that it there Heleynt
That to thy brothyrs wyf / yf I it wyst
Be what she be / and loue hyr as the lyst
Therfore as frendfully / in me assure
And tel me plat now / what is thencheson
And fynal cause / of woo that ye endure
For douthyth nothyng / my en • encion
Nys nor to you / of reprehension
To speke as now / for no wyght may byreue
A man to loue / tyl that hym lyst to leue
And wyte wel / that both two ben vices
Mystrust al / o • ellis al to leue
But wel I wote / the meane of it no vyce is
For to trust som̄e wyght / it is a preue
Of trowth and for thy / wold I fayne remeue
Thy wrong conceyt / and do the somwhat tryst
Thy woo to tel / and tel me yf the lyst
The wyse seyth / woo hym that is alone
For yf he falle / he hath no help to ryse
And sith thou hast a felowe / telle thy mone
For thys is not certeyne the next wyse
To wynnen loue / as rechen vs the wyse
To walewe and wepe / as Nyobe the quene
Whos teens yit in marbyl stone be seene
Late be thy wepyng / and thy drerynesse
And lete vs l • ssen woo / wyth oure speche
So may thy woful tyme / seeme lesse
Delyte not in woo / thy woo to seche
As don thyse fooles / that theyr sorowes eche
Wyth sorow / whan they haue mysauenture
And lyst not to seche hem / othyr cure
Men seyn / to wretchis is consolacioun
To haue anothyr fel • w in hys peyne
That ought wel be / oure oppynyoun
For both thou and I / for loue we pleyne
So ful of sorow am I soth to seyne
That certaynly nomoore hard grace
May sitte on me / for why ther is no space
Yf god wyl thou art not agast of me
Lest I wold of thy lady the begyle
Thou wost thy self whom that I loue parde
As I best can / goon sith long whyle
And sith thou woost / I do it for no wyle
And seyst I am he / thou trustist most
Tel me somwhat / sith al my wyt thou woost
Yet Troylus for al thys / no worde seyd
But long he lay stylle / as he deed were
And after thys / wyth sighyng he abreyde
And to pandarus voyce / he leyd hys eve
And vp hys eyen cast he / that in fere
Was Pandarus / lest that in frenesye
He shuld falle / or ellis soone dye
And cryed awake ful wonderly and sharp
What slombryst thou / an in a lytargy
Or art thou lyke / an Asse vnto the harp
That herith sowne / whan men the strynges plye
But in hys mynde of that no melodye
May synken in / to gladden for that he
So dul is of hys bestialyte
And wyth that Pandare / of hys wordis stent
And Troylus yit hym / nothyng answerd
For thy to tellen / was not hys entent
Neuer to noman / for whom he so ferd
For it is sayd / men make oft a yerd
Wyth whyche the maker / is hym self y betyn
In sondry maner as these wyse tretyn
And namely / in hys counsayl tellyng
That touchyth loue / that ought to be secre
For of hym self / it wyl ynough out spryng
But yf that it / the bet gouerned be
Eke somtyme it is craft to seme fle
For thyng whyche in effect / men huntyn fast
Al thys gan Troylus / in hys herte cast
But neuertheles / whan he had herd hym crye
Awake he gan / and sighed wonder sore
And sayd frende / though that I stylle lye
I am not deef / now peas and crye nomore
I haue herd thy wordis / and thy lore
But suffre me / my myschyef to bewaylen
For thy prouerbis / may me not auaylen
None other cure canst thou for me
Eke I wyl not be curid / I wyl deye
What knowe I of the quene Nyobe
Eate be thyn old ensamples I the preye
No quod pandare therfore I seye
Suche is delyte of foolis to bywepe
Her wo but seeke boote they ne kepe
Now know I that reason in the faylyth
But tel me / yf I wyst what she were
For whom that the al this mysauenture aylyth
Durst thou that I told it in her eere
Thy woo sith thou darst not thy self for fere
And hyr besought / on the to haue som̄e rowth
Why nay quod he / by god and by my trowth
What not as busily quod pandarus
As though myn owne lyf lay in thys nede
No certis brother quod thys Troylus
And why / for that thou shuldest neuer spede
Woost thou not wel / ye that is out of drede
Quod troylus for al that euer ye conne
She nyl to no suche wretche as I be wonne
Quod pandarus alas what may thys be
That thou dyspayrid art thus causeles
What lyuyth not thy lady benedicite
How woost thou soo / that thou art graceles
Suche euyl is not alway booteles
Why put not impossible thus thy cure
Syth thyng to come is / oft hath aduenture
What shold he therfor fal in dyspeyre
Or be recreaunt / for hys owne teene
Or sle hym self / al be hys lady feyre
Nay nay but euer in oon be fressh and grene
To serue and loue / hys dere hertis quene
And thynk it is a gwerdon for to serue
A thousand fold more than he can deserue
And of that word toke heede Troylus
And thought anon / what folye he was in
And how that soth hym sayde Pandarus
That for to sle hym self / myght he not wynne
But both do vnmanhod / and a synne
And of hys d • th / hys lady not to wyde
For of his woo god woot she knew but lyte

And wyth that thought / he gan ful sor •
〈◊〉
And sayd alas / what is me best to do
To whom pandare / answerd yf the lyke
The best is / that thou telle me al thy woo
And haue my trouth / but thou fynd it so
A be shy boote / or that it be ful long
And ellis • o p • as / do me drawe and •• ng
Yeso s • yst thou / quod Troylus tho al ••
But god wote / it is not the rather so
Ful hard wote it / to helpen in thys ca •
For wele fynd I / that fortune is my foo
Ne alle the men that ryden conne or goo
May of hyr cruel w •• le the harm withstonde

For as she lyse, she pleyth wyth for and
〈◊〉
I graunt wel if at thou endurist woo
As sharp as doth Tiaue in beste
Whoo stomack fowlio tyr • n euermo
That hyght vulturre / as bookes 〈◊〉
But I may not endure / that thou dwelle
In so an vnskilful oppynyon
That of thy woo is no cumaon
But oones nyltow / for thy coward lert
And for thyn ite / and foolissh wylfulnesse
For wantrust tel of thy woundis smert
Ne to thyn owne help / do besynesse
As moche as speke a reason / more on lesse
But lyggese as he that lyst of nothyng ret •••
What womman coude loue suche a wretche
What may she deme / othyr of thy deth
Yf thou thus dye / and she note why it is
But that for drede is yolden vp thy breth
For Greekis han bysegyd vs ywys
Lord suche a thank shalt thou haue of thys
Thus wyl she say / and alle the towne atones
The wretche is ded / the deuyl haue hys bones

Thou mayst alone here wepe kne ••
and crye
But loue a womman that she wote it • nought
And she shal quyte it / thou shalt it not espye
Vnknow vnkyst / and lost that is vnsought
What many a man hath loue / ful dere y bought
Twenty wynter / that hys lady ne wyst
That neuer yit hys lady mouth he kyst
Quod pandarus thou blamest fortune
For thou art wroth / now at erst I see
Wost thou not wel that fortune is comune
To euery maner wyght / in som̄e degre
And yit thou hast thys comfort • o parde
So as hir Ioyes must ouergon
So must h • r sorowes passen euerychon
For yf her whele stynt any thyng to torne
Than scaceth she anon fortune to be
Now sith hyr whele by no way may so • ourne
What woost thou / of hyr mutabilite
Ryght as thy self lyse / she wyl do by the
Or yf she be not seen at thyn helpyng
Perauenture thou hast cause for to syng
And therfor woost thou what I the beseche
Late be thy woo / and turnyng to the ground
For who so lyst haue helpyng of hys leche
To hym byhouyth fyrst / vnkouer hys wound
To cerberus in helle / ay be I bounde
Were it for my sustre / al thy sorow
By my wyl she shuld be thyn to morow
Looke vp I say / and tel me what she is
Anon that I may goo aboute thy nede
Knowe I hyr not for my loue tel me thys
Than wold I hope rather for to spede
Tho gan the veynes of troylus to bleede
For he was hit and wax alle rede for shame
A ha quod Pandare / here begynnyth the game
And wyth that word he gan hym to shake
And sayd thyef thou shalt hyr name telle
But tho gan sely Troylus to quake
As thought ye men shuld haue led hym to helle
And sayd alas / of alle my woo the welle
That 〈◊〉 she my swete callid Cr • seyde
And wyth that word / for few nygh he deyde

And whan pandar •
herd hym her name 〈◊〉
Lord he was glad / and sayd frend so 〈◊〉
Now fare a ryght / for Io ••• name in 〈◊〉

Loue hath be set the wel be of good
〈◊〉

For of good name / wysedom and
〈◊〉
She hath ynough / and eke of gentylnesse
If she be fayre / thou woost thy self I gesse
Neuer saw I none more boun •• uous
Of her estate ne gladder of speche
A frendlyer / ne more gracious
For to do wel ne basse had nede to s • che
What to for to done / and al thys bet to eche
In honour to as f • r as she may stretche
A kynges hert semeth by hyre a wretche
And also thynk / and therwyth glad the
That syth thy lady vertuous is al
So folowyth it / that there is som pyte
Among alle thyse other in general
And for thy see that in especial
Requyre not that is ayenst her name
For vertu stretchyth not hym self to shame
Now bete thy brest / and seye to god of loue
Thy grace lord / for now I me repent
Yf I myspack afore now my self I loue
Thus seye wyth all thyn hert in good entent
Quod Troylus / a lord I me consent
And pray to the / my Iapis to foryeue
And I shal neuermore whyle I lyue
Thou sayst wel quod pandare / now I hope
That thou the goddis wrath hast apeased
And syth thou hast wept many a drope
And said such thing wherwith thy god is pleasid
Now wold neuer god / but thou were casid
And thynk wel she of whom rist al thy woo
Here a fore / thy confort may be also
For thilk ground / that berith the weedis wycke
Beryth este the holsom herbis ful ofte
Next the foule nettyl rowgh and thycke
The rose wexith swete / smoth and softe
And next the valey / is the hyl alofte
And next the derk nyght / is the glad morow
And also Ioye is next thend of sorow
Now booke that attempre be thy brydel
And for the best / ay suffre to the tyd
Or ellis all our labour / is al ydel
He hastyth wel / that wysely can abyde
Be dylygent and trewe / and alway hyde
Be lusty fre / perseuere in thy seruyse
And al is wel / yf thou werk in thy wyse
The tyme thou maist blis / that euer yu were born
And the goddis thank / that in so good a place
Haue the bistowed in loue / I durst haue sworn
That yu shuld neuer haue had / so fayce a grace
And why for thou were euer wont to chace
At loue in scorn / and for dyspyte hem calle
Delyuere the world / lord of thys foolis alle
Whan Toylus had herd / Pandare assentyd
To be hys help in louyng of Criseyde
Way of hys woo / as who sayth vnturmentid
But hott •• wax hys loue / and than he seyde
Wyth sobre chere / as though hys hert had pleyde
Now blysful venus / help or that I sterus
Of the Pandare / I may som̄e thank deserue
But dere frend how shal my woo be lesse
Tyl thys be don / and good eke trl me thys
How wylt thou sey / of me and my dyscresse
Leste she be wroth / thye drede I most ywis
Or wyl not here / or trowen how it is
All thys drede I / and eke for the manere
Of the hyr Eme / she wyl no suche thyng here
Quod Pandarus / thou hast ful grete care
Lest that the chorle / fal ouer of the moone
Why lord I hate of the / thy nyce fare
What entre • et • of that / thou hast to doone
For goddis loue / I byde the a boone
So lete me alone / and it shal be thy feste
What frend quod be nowe / do ryght as the leste
But herk / Pandare / o word for I nold
That thou in me / wendyst so grete folye
That to my lady / I desire shold
That touchyth harme / or any vylonye
For dredeles / me were leuer dye
Than she of me / ought ellis vndirstoode
But that / that myght sowne in to goode
Tho lowgh thys pandare / and anon answerd •
And I thy borow / fy no wyght doth but so
I tought not / though she stood and herd
How that thou seyst / but fare wel I wyl go
Adieu be glad / god spede vs with two
Yeue me thys labour / and thys besinesse
And of my speede / be thyn alle the swetnesse
Tho Troilus gan doun / on hys knees fall
And Pandare in hys armes / hent fast
And sayd now fy on the grekis all
Yit parde god shal help vs at the laste
And dredeles yf that my lyf may laste
And god to forn / yit som̄e of hem shal smert
And yit me athynketh thys auaunt me astert
Now pandarus / I can no more seye
But thou wise / yu wost / thou mayst / thou art al
My lyf my deth / hool in thyn hand I leye
Help now quod he / yis by my trowth I shal
God yeld the frend / and thys in special
Quod Troylus / that thou me recomanude
To her that may me / to deth comaunde
Thys Pandarus / tho desirous to serue
Hys ful frend / tho sayd in thys manere
Farwel and thynk I wyl / thy thank deserue
Haue here my trowth / & that thou shalt wel here
And went hys wey / thynkyng on thys matere
And how he myght best / byseche her of grace
And fynd a tyme herto / and a place
For euery wyght / that hath an hous to found
Ne rennyth not / the werke for to begynne
With rakil hand / but he wyl byde a stound
And send hys hertis lyne / out from wythynne
Altherfirst hys purpos for to wynne
Al thys Pandare / in hys hert thought
And cast hys werk ful wysely or he wrought
But Troylus tho / lay no lenger doun
But vp anon vpon hys steed bay
And in the feld he pleyeth the lyoun
Wo was the greke / that met with hym that day
And in the towne / hys manerr he holdyth ay
So goodely he was / and gate hym so in grace
That eche hym loued / that lokid in hys face
For he become / the frendlyest knyght
The gentyllest / and eke the most fre
The thryftyest and one the best wyght
That in hys tyme / was or myght be
Ded were hys Iapis / and hys cruelte
Hys hye port / and hys maner straunge
And eche of tho / gan for a vertu chaunge
Now lete vs stynt of Troylus a stounde
That farith lyke a man / that hurt is sore
And is somdele of akynge of hys wounde
Y lyssed wel / but helid no del more
And as an esy pacyent / the lore
Abydyth of hym that goth aboute hys cure
And thus be dryuyth forth hys aduenture

div.head: ¶And begynneth the prologe of the secunde booke

lg.l: OWte of thise black wawes / for to sayle
O wynde the wedir / begynneth to clere
For in this see / ye bote hath such trauayle
Of my connyng / that vnneth I it stere
Thys see clepe I / the tempestous matere
Of dyspeyre / that Troylus was ynne
For now of hope the kalendis begynne
O lady myn / that callid art Cleo
Thou be my spede fro this furth / and my muse
To Ryme wel thys booke / tyl I haue do
Me nedeth here / none other art to vse
For why to euery louer I me excuse
That of no sentement / I thys endyte
But out of latyn / in to my tunge I wryte
Wherfor I wyl haue / neyther thank ne blame
Of al thys werk / but prey yow mekely
Dysblameth me / yf ony word be lame
For as myn auctour sayth / so sey I
Eke though I speke / of loue vnfelyngly
No wonder is / for it of thyng now new is
A blynd man can not wel Iuge in hewis
I know eke that in forme of speche / is chaūge
Wythyn a thousand yere / of wordis tho
That hadden pry •• / ben now nyce and straunge
Vs thynketh hem / and yit they spack hem so
And sped as wel in loue / as men now do
Eke for to wynne loue / in sondry ages
An sondry • ondes / sondry ben vsages
And for thy yf it hap / in ony wyse
That ther be ony louer / in thys place
That herkenyth as the story can deuyse
How Troylus come / to hys lady grace

And thynkith s •
nold I / loue purchase
Or wondryth on hys speche / or doyng
I not but vnto me / it is no wondryng
For euery wyght / whyche that to rome went
Holt not oo path / ne alway oo manere
Eke in som̄e bond / were al the game y shent
Yf they ferd in loue / as men don here
As thus in open doyng / and in chere
In vysityng in forme / or sayd our sawes
For why men seyn / eche contre hath hys lawes
Eke scarsly be ther in thys place thre
That haue in loue seyd lyke / and don al
For to thy purpos thys may lyke the
And the ryght nought / yit al is sayd & shal
Eke som men graue / in the stone wal
As it betyd but sith I haue bygonne
Myn auctor shal I folowe yf that I conne

div.head: ¶And here begynneth the seconde booke

lg.l: IN may that modir is of monethis glade
That fressh flowris / blew whet & trede
Ben quykened ageyn / yt wīert deed made
And ful of baume / is fletyng euery mede
Whan phebus doth / hys bryght beames spaede
Ryght in the whyte boole / it is betyd
As I shal syng / on Mayes day the thryd
That pandarus / for al hys wyse speche
Felt eke hys part / of loues 〈◊〉 beene
That cowde he neuer / so wel of louynge preche
It made hys hewe / sul oft a day greene
Shoope hym that day / ther fyl hym a trene
In loue for whyche / to be ded / he wente
And made or it was day ful many a went
The swalow Proigne / wyth a sorowful lay
Whan morow come / made hyr waymentyng
Why she forshape was / and al the lay
Pandare a bed halt in a slomb • yng
Tyl she so nyh hym / made her chy •• ryng
How Ter • us gan forth / hyr sus •• r take
That wyth the noyse of hyr he gan awake
And gan to calle / and dresse hym to ryse

Remembryng hym / hys
••• nd was to done
From Troylus / and eke hys grede empryse
And case & knew / in good plice was the mone
To do viage / and toke hys wey ful soone
Vnto hys neas paleys / ther besyde
Now Ianus god of entre / thow hym guyde
Whan he was come / vnto hys neas place
Where is my lady to her folk quod he
And they hym told / and he forth in gan pace
And fond two othyr ladyes / sit and she
Wythin a paued parlour / and they thre
Herd hem a mayden / redyng the gest
Of the siege of thebes whyle hem lest
Quod Pandarus / madame god yow see
Wyth youre booke / and al the company
Ey vncle now / welcom ywis quod she
And vs she Ros / and by the hond in hy
She toke hym fast / and sayd thus nyght thry
To good mote it turne / of yow I mette
And with that word / she doun on bēche hym sette
Ye nece ye shul fare / wel the bet
Yf god wyl / al thys yere quod Pandarus
But I am sory / that I haue yow let
To herken on your booke / ye praysen thus
For goddys loue what sayth it / tel it vs
Is it of loue / or som̄e good thyng ye me lere
Vncle quod she your maystres is not here
Wyth that they gonne laugh / and tho she sayd
Thys romance is of Thebes / that we rede
And we han herd / hou that kyng layus deyde
Thurgh Edippus hys sone and al that dede
And here we stynt / at thyse lettres rede
How the bysshop as the booke can telle
Amphiorax fyl thurgh the ground to helle
Quod pandarus al thys knowe I my selue
And al the fleges of thebes / and the care
For herof ben therr / bookes made twelue
But lete be thys / and tel me how ye fare
Do way your wympyl / & shewe your face bare
Do way your booke / ryse vp & lete vs daunce
And lete vs do to may / som̄e obseruaunce
Ey god forbede quod she / be ye mad
Is that a wydewes lyf / so god yow saue
By god ye maken me / ryght sore adrad
Ye be so wyeld / it semeth as ye raue
It sit me wel bet / to be in a caue
To byd and rede / on holy sayntes lyues
Late maydens go daunce / and yong wyues
As euer thryue I / quod thy • pandarus
Yit couthe I 〈◊〉 a thyng / to do your •• rt 〈◊〉
Now vncle dere quod she / telle it ve
For goddis loue / is than the syege awey
I am of the Grrel • is / so ferd that I dey

Nay nay quod
〈◊〉 / as euer more I thryue
It is a thyng wel bet / than such fyue
Ye holy god quod she / what thyng • to that
What bet than suche • yue / nay ywys
For al thys world / ne can I rede what
It shal be som̄e • ape / I trowe it is
And but your self vs crl / what it is
My wyt to arrde it / is al to seene
Ao help me god I no •• what ye mene

And I your borow / ne neuer shal quod
• e
Thys thyng be told to yow / so most I thryue
And why so vncle myn / why so quod she
By god quod he / that wyl I trl as • lyue
For prowder wōman / is there none on lyue
And ye it wyst / in al the • owne of Troye
I lye not / so euer haue I Ioye
Tho gan she wonder / more than byforn
A thousand fold / & doun hyr eyen caste
For neuer sith the tyme / she was born
To knowe a thyng / desired she so faste
And wyth a sigh / she sayd hym at the laste
Now vncle myn / I wyl you not dysple ase
Ne axe thyng / that may do you dysease
So aftir thys / wyth many wordis glade
And frendly talis / and wyth mery chere
Of thys and that / they gonne pley and wade
In many vncowth glad and deepe matere
As frendis don / whan they ben met in feere
Tyl she gan aske hym / how that Hector ferde
That was the wal of Troye / and greekis yerde
Ful wel I thank it god / quod Pandarus
Saue in hys arme / he hath a lytel wounde
And eke hys fressh brothyr Troylus
The wyse worthy / Hector the secunde
In whom that euery vertu / lyst habounde
As al trowth / and al gentylnesse
Wysdom honour / fredom and worthynesse
In good feyth Eme quod she / that lykith me
They faren wel / god saue hem both two
For trewly / I hold it grete deynte
A kynges sone / in armes wel to do
And be of good condicions therto
For grete power / and moral vertu here
Is selden seen / in oo persone y feere
In good feyth / that is sooth quod Pandarus
But by my trouth / the kyng hath sones twey
That is to saye / Hector and Troylus
That certaynly though that I shuld deye
They ben vs voyde / of vyces dar I sey
As any men / that lyuen vndir the sonne
Theyr myght is wide knowē / & what they kōne
Of Hector nedyth nothyng for to telle
In al thys world / ther nys a bettir knyght
Than he that is of worthynesse welle
And he wel more vertu hath / than myght
Thys knowith many a wyse / & worthy knyght
The same pryce of Troylus I sey
God help me soo / I know not suche twey
By god quod she / of Hector that is sooth
Of Troylus the same thyng trowe I
For dredeles / men tellith that he doeth
In armes daye by daye / and that so worthyly
And berith hym here at hom so gentylly
To euery wyght that oueral pryce hath he
Of hem that were me leuest praysed be
Ye sey ryght soth ywis / quod Pandarus
For yesterdaye / who hath wyth hym ben
Myght haue woundred / vpon Troylus
For neuer yit so thyk a swarm of leen
As than the Grekis / from hym gan fleen
And thurgh the feld in euery wyghtis eue
Ther nas no cry / but Troylus is there
Now here now there / he hunted hem so faste
Ther nas but Grekis bloode / and Troylus
Now hym he hurt / and now hym doun he caste
Ay where he went it was arayeed thus
He was theyr deth / and sheld and lyf for vs
That as that day / ther durst none wythstonde
Whyle he held / hys blody swerd in hond
Therto he is the frendelyest man
Of grete estate / that euer I sawe in my fyne
And where hym lyst / best felawshyp can
To suche as hym thynkyth / able for to thryue
And wyth that word / tho Pandarus as blyue
Toke of theym leue / & said he wold gon henne
Nay blame haue I myn vncle quod she thenne
Whot eyleth yow to be thus wery soone
And namely of wymmen wil ye so
Nay sittyth doun by god I haue to doone
Wyth yow to speke / of wysdom or ye go
And euery wyght / that was aboute hem tho
That herd that / gan for awey to stonde
Whyle they two had / al that hem le • t on honde
Whan that hyr tale / brought was to an end
Of hyr estate and hyr gouernaunce
Quod Pandarus / now is tyme I wend
But now I sey aryse / and lete vs daunce
And caste your wydewes habyte / to myschaūce
What lyst yow thus / your self to dyffygure
Syth yow is betid / so glad an auenture
A wel bythought / for loue of god quod she
Shal I not wyte / what ye meane of thys
No thys thyng askyth / leyser quod he
And eke me wold / moche greue ywys
Yf I it told / and ye toke it amys
Yit were it bet / my tung for to stylle
Than sey a thyng / that were agayn your • ille
For nece by the goddesse Minerue
And Iubiter / that makyth the thunder to ryng
And by the blysful Venus / that I serue
Ye be the womman / in thys world lyuyng
Wythout peramours / to my wytyng
That I best loue / and bothest am to greue
And that ye wyten wel / your self I leeue
Ywis myn vncle / quod she grantmercy
Your frendshyp haue I founden euer yit
I am to noman / holden trewly
So moche as you / and haue so lytyl quyt
And wyth grace of god / wyth my ful wyt
As in my gylt / I shal you neuer offende
And yf I haue or thys / I wyl amende
B • th not agast / ne quakyth not wherto
Ne chaungyth not for fere / so youre hewe
For hardily the worst of thys is do
And though my tale be now / as to yow newe
Yit trust alway / ye shuld fynd me trewe
And were it thyng / me thought vnsittyng
To yow wold I / no suche talis bryng
Now my good Eame / for goddis loue I prey
Quod she come of / and telle me what it is
For both I am agast / what ye wyl sey
And eke me longyth / to wyte ywis
For whether it be wel / or be amys
Sey and late me not / in thys fere dwelle
So wyl I do now herkyn I shal telle
Now nece myn / the kynges de • e sone
The good wyse worthy / fressh and fre
Whyche alway for to do wel / is hys wone
The noble Troylus / so loueth the
That but ye help / it wyl hys baane be
Lo here is al / what shuld I more seye
Do what ye lyst / make hym lyue on deye
And yf ye lete hym deye / I wyl steruen
Haue here my trowth / nyl I not lyen
Al shuld I wyth thys ••• yf / my throte • eruen
Wyth that trene / brost out of hys eyen
And sayd / yf that ye do vs both dyen
What mene ye though we bothe apayre
Thus gylilis / than loue ye fysstred fayre
Alas be whyche 〈◊〉 / my lord so dere
That crew man / that noble knyght
That nought des •• eth / but yowre frendly chere
I see hym deye / ther he goeth vpright
And baseyth hym / wyth al hys ful myght
For to be slayne / yf hys fortune assent
Alas that god suche a beaute you sent
Yf it be so / ye so cruel be
That of hys deth / ye list not to retche
That is so trewe / and worthy as we see
Nomore than of a Iaper / or of a wretche
Yf ye be suche / yowre beawte may not s • retch
To make amendes / of so cruel a dede
Auysement is good / byfore the neede
Wo worth / the fayre Gemme vertules
Wo worth that herke / that doeth no bote
Wo worth that beaute / that is rowthles
Wo worth that wyght / that eche tret vndirfoote
And ye that be / of beaute crop and roote
Yf that wythal in yow be no rowth
Than is it harm / ye lyuen by me trouth
And also thynk wel that thys is no gawde
For me were leuer / yow and I and he
Were banged / than I shuld be hys bawde
As hye as any man / myght on vs see
I am thyn Eame / the shame were to me
As wel as thyn / yf that I shuld assent
Thurgh my counsayl / that he thyn honour shent
Now vnderstonde / for I not requere
To bynd yow to hym / by no byhest
But only that ye make hym better chere
Than ye haue don or this / & make hym more fest
So that hys lyf be saued / at the lest
Thys is al & som̄e / and playnly our entent
God help me so / I neuer other ment
Lo thys request / is not but skyl ywys
Ne doute of treason parde is ther none
I set the worst / that ye dredden thys
Men wold woundre / to see hym come and gone
There ageynst / answere I thus anone
That euery wyght / but he be foole of kynde
Wyl deme it loue / and frendshyp in hys mynde
What who wyl deeme / though he see a man
To temple go / that he the ymage etyth
Thynk eke how wel / and wysely that he can
Gouerne hym self / that he nothyng foryetith
That wher he comyth / the pryce & thank he getith
And eke therto / he shal come here so seld
What fors were it / yf al the towne beheld
Suche loue of frendis / regneth in all this towne
And wry you in that mantel / euerine
And god so wysly / be my saluacioune
As I haue sayd you / best is to do so
But good nece alway to stynt hys wo
So lete your daunger / sugrid be alyte
That of hys deth / ye be not to wyte
Criseyde whyche that herd hym / in this wyst
Thought I shal fole / what ye meane ywis
Now Eame quod she / what wyl ye deuyse
What is youre rede / I shuld do of thys
That is wel sayd quod he / certeyn best is
That ye hym loue agayn for hys louyng
As loue for loue / is skylful gwerdonny • g

Thynk eke how
• eld / wostith euery houre
In eche of yow / a party of beaute
And therfor or that age / yow deuoure
So loue / for old ther wyl no wyght of the
Late this prouer • / a lore vnto yow be
To late I ware / quod beaute whan it is past
And aage dauntyth / daunger at the last
The kynges foole / is wont to cry lowde
Whan that him thynkith / a wōman beri • h hir hye
So long more ye lyue / and al prowde
Tyl crowee feete / ben wax vndyr your eye
And send yow than / a myrrour in to p • ye
In whyche that ye may / see your face a morow
I byd than wysshe you / nomo • e sorow
Wyth thys he stynt / and cast doun the hede
And she began / to brest to wepe anon
And sayd alas / for wo why ner I dede
For of thys world / the feyth is al gon
Alas what shuld / a straunger to me don
Whan he that for my best / frend I wend
Wyl make me loue / and shuld me defend
Alas I wold haue trustid dou • eles
That yf I that / thurgh my dysauenture
Had louyd hym othyr Achylles
Hector or ony mannes creature
Ye nold haue had / no mercy ne mesure
On me but alwey / had me in repreue
Thys fals world alas / how may it leue
What is thys al / the Ioye and the feest
Is thys your rede / is thys your blysful caas
Is thys the vemy mede / of your byhest
Is al thys peynted proces / come to thys alas
Ryght for thys fyne / O lady myn Pallas
Thou in thys drdeful cas / for me purueys
For so astonyed am I / that I deye
Wyth that she gan sorowfully to syke
And may it be not bet / quod Pandaus
By god I shal nomore / come here this wyke
And god toforn / that am mystrusted thus
I see wel that ye sette lytel of vs
Or of our deth / Alas I woful wretche
Myght he yit lyue / of me is not to retche
O cruel god / o dyspytous mart
O furyes thre of helle on you I crye
So lete me neuer / out of thys hous depart
Yf that I ment harme or vylonye
But sith I see / my lord mote nedis dye
And I wyth hym / here I me shryue and seye
That wyckedly / ye do vs both deye
But sith it lykyth yow / that I be ded
By Neptunus / that god is on the see
Fro thys furth / shal I neuer ete brede
Tyl I myn owne / hert blood may see
For certeyn I wyl dye as soone as hee
And vp he stert / and on hys wey he raught
Tyl she ageyn hym / by the lap caught
Criseyde wyth that / ful ny starf for fere
So as she was / the ferdfullest wyght
That myght be / and herd eke with hyr ere
And saw the sorowful ernest / of the knyght
And in hys prayer / eke sawe none vnright
And for the harm / that myght eke fal more
She gan to rewe / and dred hyr wonder sore
And thought thus vnhappis fallen thyk
Alday for loue / in suche maner caas
As men ben cruel / in hem self and wyk
And yf thys man sle hym self alas
In my presence / if wyl be no solas
What men wyl it deme / I can not sey
It nedyth me / ful wysely to pley
And with a sorowful syke / she sayd thry
A lord what me is tyd / a sory chaunce
For myn estate lyeth in Iuparty
And eke myn Eames lyf / lyth in balaunce
But natheles / wyth goddis gouernaunce
I shal so do / myn honour shal I kepe
And eke hys lyf / and stynt for to wepe
Of harmes two / the lasse is for to chese
Yit had I leuer / make hym good chere
In honour than myn owne / eames lyf to leese
Ye sey ye nothyng / ellis requere
Nowis quod he / myn owne nece dere
Now wel quod she / and I wyl do my peyne
I shal myn hert / ageynst my lust constrayne
But that I nyl not / holdyn hym in honde
Ne loue a man / ne can I not ne may
Ageynst hys wyl / but ellis wyl I fonde
Myn honour saue / please hym from day to day
Therto nold I not oones / haue sayd nay
But that I drede / as in hys fantasy
But cease the cause / cesith the malady
But here I make a protestacion
That in thys proces / or ye further go
That certaynly / for no saluacion
Of yow though that ye sterue both two
And al the world on a day / be my fooo
Ne shal I neuer of hym / haue other rowth
I graunt wel quod Pandare / by my trowth
But may I trust wel to yow / quod he
That of thys thyng / that ye haue hyght me here
Ye wyl holden trewly / vnto me
Ye doute it not quod she my vncle dere
Ne that I shal haue cause in thys matrre
Quod he to pleyne / or ofter yow to preche
Why no parde what nedyth more speche
Tho fyllen they / in other talis glade
Tyl at the last / o goode Eame quod she tho
For hys loue / whyche vs both made
Tel me how fyrst / ye wysten of hys woo
Wote none of it but ye / he sayd no
Can he wel speke of loue / quod she I yow prey
Tel me for I the bet / shal me pouruey
Tho pandarus / a lytel gan to smyle
And sayd by my trouth / I shal yow telle
Thys othyr day / not go ful long whyle
Wythin the gardyn paleys / by a welle
Gan he and I / half a day to dwelle
Ryght for to speke / of an ordynaunce
How we the Grekis myght dysauaunce
Soone after that we gan to lepe
And cast wyth our •• rtis / to and fro
Tyl at the last he sayd he wold slepe
And on the gras / adoun he leyd hym tho
And I after / gan rome to and fro
Tyl that I herd / as I walkid alone
How he bygan / ful wofully to grone
Tho gan I stalk hym / softly behynd
And sikyrly / the footh for to sayne
As I can clepe agayn to my mynde
Ryght thus to loue / gan hym for to pleyne
He sayd lord haue rowth / vpon my payne
Al haue I be rebel / in myn entent
Now mea culpa / lord I me repent
O god / that thy dysposicion
Ledyst the fyne / by Iust puruyaunce
Of euery wyght / my lowe confess on
A corpt in gre / and send me such penaunce
As lykith the / but from desperaunce
Late not my ghoost / departe away from the
Thou be my sheld / for thy benygnyte

For c • rti •
lord so sore hath she me woundyd
That stood in black / with lookyng of hyr eyen
That to myn her • o bottum / it is foundyd
Thurgh whiche I wote / that I must nedis d • yen
Thys to the worst / I dar not bewrepe •
And wel the hotter / ben the gl • dis rede
That men hem wryen with ass •• n pale and deede

Wyth that he smote hys
• ed / doun anone
And gan to moe •• / I not what trewly
And I wyth that / gan styl away to gone
And lete the •• f / as nothyng wyst had I
And come ageyn anone / and stode hym by
And sayd awake / ye slepen alto longe
It semeth not that loue doeith yow 〈◊〉
That slepyn so that noman may yow wa ••
Who saw euer on thys so dul a man
Ye frend quod he / do ye y • ur • eedis ale
For loue and lete me / lyuen as I can
But though that • e for wo / wae pale & wan
Yit made he tho / as fresshe a contenaunce
As though he shuld haue l • d the daunce
Thys passid forth / tyl now thys other day
It fel that I come romyng al alone
In to hys chambre / and found how that he lay
Vpon hys bed but man so sore grone
Ne herd I neuer / ne what was hys mone
Ne wyst I not for as I was comyng
Al sodaynly he left hys compleynyng
Of whyche I tooke somwhat suspection
And nere I come / and fond he wept sore
And god so wys / be my saluacion
Neuer yit of thyng / had I rowth more
For nother wyth engyne / ne wyth lore
Vnne this myght I from the deth hym kepe
That yit feele I for hym / myn hert wepe
And god wote / neuer sith that I was born
Was I so besy / no man to preche
Ne neuer was to wyght / so deepe y sworn
Or he me told / who myght be hys leche
But now to rehersen al hys speche
Or al hys woful wordis / for to sowne
Ne byd me not but ye wyl see me swowne
But for to saue hys lyf and ellis nought
And to none harme of yow / thus am I dryuen
As for the loue of god / that vs hath wrought
Suche chere hym doth / as he and I may louen
Now haue I plat to yow / myn hert shryuen
And sith ye wote / that myn entent is cleene
Take hede therof / for I none euyl meene
And ryght good thryst I pray to god haue ye
That haue suche one caught wythouten net
And be ye wyse / as ye be fayre to see
Wel in the ryng / than is the Ruby set
Ther were neuer two / so wel y met
Whan ye be hys al hool / as he is yowre
Al myghty god graunt vs / to see that houre
Nay therof spack I not / a ha quod she
As h • lp me god / ye shenden euery de • e
A mercy dere rece / anon quod he
What so I spack / I ment but wele
By Mars the god / that helmed is wyth steel
Now be not wroth / my blood my nece dere
Now wel quod she / foryeuen be it here
Wyth thys he toke hys leue / and home he went
A lord so he was glad / and wel bygon
Criseyde aroos / no lenger she ne stent
But streyt into her closet / she wente anon
And set her doun as styl as ony ston
And euery word / gan vp and doun to wynd
As he had sayd / as it come to her mynd
And was som̄edel astonyed / in hyr thought
Ryght for the new cas / but whan that she
Was ful auysed / than fond she ryght nought
Of perile / whyche she ought aferd to be
For men may loue / of pessibylyte
A womman so hys hert may to brest
And she not loue ageyn / but yf she lest
But as she sat alone / and thought thus
Ascry aros at scarmyssh / al wythout
And men cried in the srete / see Troylus
Hath now put to flight / the greekis route
Wyth that gan her meyne / for to showte
A go we see / cast vp the gatis wyde
For thurgh thys strete / he must to paleys ryde
For other wey / is fro the yate none
Of dardanus / ther opyn is the cheyne
Wyth that come he / and al hys folk anone
An esy paas rydyng / in rowtis tweyne
Ryght as hys happy day / was sooth to seyne
For whyche men seyn / may not dystourbed be
That shal betyde must be of necessite
Thys Troylus sat / on hys bay steede
Al armed saue hys heed / ful rychely
And woundyd was hys hors / & gan to bleede
In whyche he rode / a paas ful softly
But suche a knyghtly sight truly
As was on hym / was not wythouten fayle
To looke on Mars / that is god of batayle
So lyke a man of armes / and a knyght
He was to see / fulfylled of hye prowesse
For both he hath a body / and a myght
To do a thyng / as wel as hardynesse
And to seee hym / in hys gere hym dresse
So fressh so yong / so worthy semyd he
It was an heuen / vpon hym to see
Hys helme to hewen / was in twenty places
That by a tassel / hyng hys back behynd
Hys sheld / to dasshed wyth swerdis & maces
In whyche men myght / many an arowe fynde
That thrylled had / horn nerf and rynde
And ay the people cryed / here comyth our Ioye
Next hys brother holder vp of Troye
For whyche he wax / alle reede for shame
Whan he the people / crye vpon hym herden
That to byhold / it was a noble game
How sobyrly he cast doun hys eyen
Criseyde gan alle hys chere espyen
And leete it so soft / in hyr hert synk
That to hyr self she sayd / who yaf me drynk
For of hyr owne thought / she wax alle rede
Remembryng her ryght thus / lo thys is he
Whyche that myn vncle swerith / he mote be dede
But I on hym haue mercy and pyte
And wyth that thought / ashamed wax she
Gan in hyr heed to pulle / and that as faste
Whyle he and all the people forth by paste
And gan to cast / and rolle vp and doun
Wythin hyr thought / hys excellent prowesse
And hys hye estate / and al hys renoun
Hys wyt hys shap / and eke hys gentylnesse
But most hyr fauour / was for hys dystresse
Was al for hyr / and thought it was a rowth
To sle suche one / yf that he ment trowth
Now myght som̄e enuyous Iangle thus
Thys was a sodeyn loue / how myght 〈◊〉 be
That she so hastyly / louyd Troylus
Ryght for the fyrst sight / ye parde
Now who so seyth / mote be neuer the
For euery thyng / agynnyng both 〈◊〉 nede
Or al be wrought wythouten any drede
For I sey not that she / so sodaynly
Yaf hym hyr loue / But that six dyde enclyne
To lyke hym fyrs • / & I haue told yow why
And after that / hys manhod and hye pyne
Made loue / in her herte for to myne
For whyche by proces / and by good seruy ••
He gate hyr loue / and not in sodaynt wy • e

And also blysful venue / wele
〈◊〉
Sat in her seuenth hous / of •• uene tho

Dysposed wele / and wyth aspect ••
〈◊〉
To helpen sely Troylus of hys woo
And sooth to sayne / she nas not al hys foo
To Troylus in hys natyuyte
God wote that wele the sonner / sped he
Now lete vs s • ynt / of Troylus a throwe
That rydyth forth / and lete vs turne faste
Vnto Criseyde / that hyng hyr lred ful lowe
Ther as she sat alone / and gan to caste
Wher that she wold apoynt hyr / at the laste
Yf it so were / hyr Eame nold ceace
For Troylus vpon hys / mo • e for to preace
And lord so she gan / in her thought argue
In thys matere / of whyche I haue you told
And what to do best were / and what to eschewe
That plyted she ful oft / in many a fold
Now was hyr hert warm / now was it cold
And what she thought / som̄what shal I wryte
As that myn auctor / lyftyth to endyte
She thought wele / that Troylus persone
She knewe by sight / and eke hys gentylnesse
And thus she sayd / al were it not to done
To graunt hym loue / yit for hys worthynesse
It were honour / wyth pley & wyth gladnesse
In honeste / wyth suche a lord to dele
For myn estate and hys hele
Eke wel wote I / a kynges sone is he
And sith he hath to see me / suche delyte
Yf I wold vtterly / hys sight flee
Perauenture he myght / haue me in dyspyte
Wher thurgh I myght stande / in wors plyte
Now were I wyse me haate to purchace
Wythouten nede / ther I may stonde in grace
In euery thyng / I wote ther lyeth mesure
For though a man forbede dronkennesse
He not forbedyth / that euery creature
Be drynkles / for alwey as I gesse
Eke sith I wote / for me is hys dystresse
I ne aught not / for that thyng hym dyspyse
Syth it so is / he meanyth in goodely wyse
And eke I knowe / of long tyme agon
Hys • hewys goode / and that he is not nyce
Ne a vantour certeyn / men seyn he is none
To wyse he is to do suche a vyce
And eke I nyl not / so hym cheryce
That he may make auaunt / by Iust cause
He shal me neuer bynde / in suche a clause
Now sette a caas / the hardest ys ywys
Men myght deme / that he louyth me
What dyshonour / were vnto me thys
May I let hym of that / why nay parde
I know also and alday here and see
Men louen wymmen / al beside hyr leue
And whan hym lyst nomore lete hym leue
I thynk how / he able is to haue
Of al thys noble towne / the thryftyest
To be hys loue / so she her honour saue
For in and out / he is the worthyest
Saue only Hector / whyche that is the best
And yit hys lyf now / lyeth al in my cure
Lo suche is loue / and eke myn auenture
Ne me to loue / a wonder is it nought
For wel wote I my self / so god me spede
Al wold I that noman wyst / of thys thought
I am one the fayrest / wythouten drede
And godelyest / who so takith heede
And so men seyn / in al the towne of Troye
What wonder is / though he of me haue Ioye
I am myn owne womman / wele at ease
I thank it god / as for myn estate
Ryght yong and stond vntyed / in lusty lease
Wythouth Ialowsy / or suche debate
Shal no husbond / sey to me chekmate
For outher they ben ful of Ialousye
Or maysterful / or louen nouelrye
What shal I do to what fyne lyue I thus
Shal I not loue in cas yf that me lest
What parde I am / now no religyous
And though that I myn herte / sette in rest
Vpon thys knyght / that is the worthyest
And kepe allbey / myn honour and my name
By al ryght / it may do me no shame
But ryght as whan / the sonne shyneth bryght
In marche that chaungyth / oft tyme hys face
And that a clowd put with wynd to flyght
Whyche ouersprad the sonne / as for a space
A clowdy thought / gan thurgh her hert pace
That ouersprad / hyr bryght thoughtis alle
So that for fere / almost she gan to falle
That thought was thys / alas sith I am fre
Shuld I now loue / and put in Ieopartye
My sikernesse / and thrallen lyberte
Alas how durst I thynk that folye
May I not wele / in other folk espye
Their dredeful Ioy / their constreynt & their peyne
Ther loouyth none / yt she ne hath wey to pleyne
For loue is yit / the most stormy lyf
Ryght of hym self / that euer was bygonne
For euer som̄e mystrust / or nyce strif
Ther is in loue / som̄e clowd ouer the sonne
Wherto we wretchyd wymmen / nothyng conne
Whan vs is wo / but fitte wepe and thynk
Oure wretche is thys / oure owne woo to drynk
Also these wycked tunges / ben so prest
To speke vs harme / eke men ben so vntrewe
That right anon / as ceasid is theyr lest
Deceasith theyr loue / & furth to loue a newe
But harm y do is do / who so it rewe
For though thyse men / for loue hem self rende
Ful sharp begynnyng / brekyth oft at ende
How often tymes / hath it knowen ben
The treason that to wymmen / hath be done
To what fyne is suche loue / I can not seen
Or wher becomyth it whan it is gone
Ther is no wyght I trowe / that wote sone
Where it bycomyth / no wyght ther at spornyth
That erst was nothyng / in to nought tornyth
How busy yf I loue / must I be
To please them / that Iangle of loue & dremyn
And coy hem / that they sey no harme of me
For though ther be no cause / yit hem semyn
Al be for harme / that folk her frendis wenyn
Or who may stoppe / euery wykked tunge
Or sowne of bellis / whyle they ben runge
And aftyr that thought gan to clere
She sayd that he / nothyng vndyrtakyth
Nothyng acheuyth / be hym looth or dere
And wyth another thought her hert quakyth
Than slepyth hoope / and after drede awakyth
Now hote now cold / but thus betwyx twey
She ryst hyr vp / and went her for to pley
Adoun the steyre / anone ryght doun she went
In to the gardyn / wyth hyr neecis thre
And vp & doun they made many a went
Flexible and she Tarbe and Antigone
To pleyen that Ioye it was to see
And othyr of hyr wymmen / a grete route
Hyr folowyd in the gardyn / al aboute
Thys yerde was large and rayled al the aleyes
And shadowed wele / with blosmy bowes grene
Y benched newe / and sanded al the weyes
An whyche she walkith / arme in arme bytwene
Tyl at the last / Antigone the shene
Gan on a Troyan song / syngen clere
That it an heuene was / for to here
She sayd O loue to whom I haue and shal
Ben humble subgect / trew in myn entent
As I best can / to yow lord yeue I al
For euermore myn hertis lust / the rent
For neuer yet / thy grace no wyght sent
So blisful cause / as me my lyf to lede
In al Ioy and seurte / out of drede
The blysful god hath me / so wel be set
In loue ywis / that all that berith lyf
Ymagyne ne cowde / how to be bet
For lord wythout / Ielowsy or stryf
I loue one whyche is most ententyf
To seruen wel / vnwery and vnfeyned
That euer was / and leest with harm dysteyned
As he that is / the welle of worthynesse
Of trowth ground / myrrour of goodelyhed
Of wyt Appollo / stone of secretnesse
Of vertu roote / of lust fynder and h • ed
Thurgh whyche is al my sorow from me deed
Ywis I loue hym best / so doth he me
Now goode thryft haue he / wherso euer he be
Whom shuld I thank / but yow god of loue
Of al thys blis / in whyche I bathe now in
Al thankid be the lord / for that I loue
Thys is the right lyf / that I am in
To eschewe al maner / vyce and syn
Thys doth me / so to vertu entende
That day by day / I in my wyl amende
And who that seyth / that for to loue is vyce
Or thraldom / though he feele in it dystresse
He outhyr is envious / or right nyce
Or is vnmyghty / for hys shrewdnesse
To loue for suche maner folk / as I gesse
Defamyn loue / as nothyng of it knowe
They speke / but bent they neuer hys bowe
What is the sonne the wors of kynd ryght
Though that a man / for feblenes of hys eyen
May not endure on it / to looke for bryght
Or loue the wors / though wretchys on it cryen
No wele is he worth / that may no sorow dryen
And for thy who that hath / an heed of verre
Fro cast of stones / beware hym in the werre
But I wyth al myn hert / and my myght
As I haue sayd / wyl loue vnto my lost
My dere hert and al myn owne knyght
In whyche myn hert / grauen is so fast
And hys in myn / that it shal euer last
Al dred I first / loue hym to begynne
Now wote I wel / ther is no pa • l ynne
And of hyr song / right at that word she s • ynt
And therwyth al / now nece quod C • seyde
Who made thys song / wyth so good entr • t
Antigone answerd anon and sayd
Madame ywis the goodehest mayde
Of grete esiatr / in al the towne of Troye
And led her lyf / in most honour and Ioye
Forsooth so it semyth / vp hyr song
Quod tho Enseyde / and gan therwyth to 〈◊〉

And sayd lord / to ther suche 〈◊〉
among
These louers / as they fayde endyte
Yewis quod fressh Antigone the whyse
For al the folk / that haue or ben aly ••
Ne coud not wel the blys of loue desery ••
But wene ye that euery wretche wote
The parsytr blisse of loue / nay ywys
They wene al loue / yf one behote
Do wey do wey they wote nothynge of thys
Men must aske at seyntis / yf it is
Ought f • yre in heuene / for they conne tells
And aske fyendis yf it be foule in helle
Cnseyde vnto that purpos / nought answerd
But sayd ywis / it wyl be nyght as fast
But enery word / whyche that she of herd
She gan to prynt it / in her hert fast
And ay gan loue / it lessyd more to agost
Than it dyd erst / and synkyn in her hert
That she wax som̄what / able to conuert
The dayes honour / and the heuenes eye
The nyghtis foo / al thys clepe I the sonne
Gan westren fast / and dounward for to wry
As he that had hys dayes cours y ronne
And whyte thynges / wexed dymme & donne
For lak of light / and sterris to appere
That she and al hyr folk / home went in feere
So whan it lyketh her / to go to reste
And voyded were tho / that voyden ought
She sayd that to sleepe / wel hyr leste
Hyr wymmen soone / in to her bed byr brought
Whan all was husht / tho lay she styl & thought
Of alle thyse thynges / the maner and the guyse
To reherce it nedyth not / for ye ben wyse
A nyghtyngale / vpon a Cedre grene
Vndyr the chamber wal / ther as she lay
Ful lowd song / ageyn the mone sheene
Parauenture in hyr bryddis / wyse alay
Of loue that made / hyr hert fressh and gay
That herkeneth she / so long in goode entent
That at the last / the ded sleep • hyr hent
And as she sleepe / anon ryght hyr mette
How that an Egle / fetherid whyte as bone
Vndyr her brest / hys long clees sette
And out her hert rent / and that anone
And dyd hys hert / in to hyr brest gone
Of whyche she nought agros / ne nothyng smert
And forth he fly / wyth hert left for hert
Now lete her sleepe / and we oure talis hold
Of Troylus that is to paleys riden
For the searmyssh / of whyche I told
And in hys chambre sitte / and hath abyden
Tyl two or thre / of hys messagers yeden
For Pandarus / and sought hym so faste
Tyl they hym fond / & brought hym at the last
Thys Pandarus / cam lepyng in attones
And sayd thus / who hath ben wel I bete
To day wyth swerdis / wyth slynges & stones
But Troylus that hath caught hym an hete
And gan to Iape / and sayd lord ye swete
But ryse and lete vs soupe / and go to reste
And he answerd / go we where the leste
Wyth al the hast goodely / that they myght
They sped hem from the souper and to bedde
And euery wyght / out at the dore hym dyght
And wher hym lest / vpon hys wey hym spedde
But Troylus / that thought hys hert bledde
For woo / tyl he herd som̄e tydyng
He sayd frend / shal I now wepe or syng
Quod Pandarus / be styl and lete me sleepe
And do on thyn hoode / thy nedis sped be
And cheese yf thou wylt / syng daunce or leepe
At short wordis / thou shalt trust in me
And my nece wyl do wel by the
And loue the best by god and by my trowth
But lack of poursute / make it in thy slowth
For thus ferforth haue I / thy werke bygonne
From day to day / to thys day by the morowe
Hyr loue and frendshyp / haue I to the wonne
And therto hath the leyde / hyr feyth to borowe
Algate one foote / is lissed of thy sorowe
What shal I lenger / sermon of it hold
As ye haue herd byfore / he al hym told
But right as floures / thurgh the cold of nyght
Yclosed stoupen on hyr stalkis lowe
Redressen ageyn / the sonne bryght
And spreden out theyr colours / kyndly by rowe
Ryght so gan he tho / hys eyen vp throwe
Thys Troylus and sayd / O Venus dere
Thy myght thy grace / I heryed be it here
And to Pandare / held vp both hys handis
And sayd lord al thyn be it that I haue
For I am hoole / al brostyn be my bondis
A thousand Troyes / who so that me yaue
Eche after other / god so me wysse and saue
Ne myght me so gladdyn / lo my hert
It spredyth so for Ioy / it wold out stert
But lord how shal I do / how shal I lyuen
Whan shal I next / my dere hert see
How shal thys long tyme / away be dryuen
Tyl thou be ageyn / at hyr from me
Thou mayst answere / abyde abyde but he
That hangyth by the neck / sooth to seyne
In grete dysease / abydyth for the peyne
Al Esily now / for loue and charyte
Quod Pandarus for all thyng hath tyme
So long abyde tyl that the nyght departed be
For siker as thou lyest here byme
And god to forn I wyl be there at pryme
And for thy werk som̄what shal I seye
Or on som̄e other wyght thys charge leye
For god woot that I haue euer yit
Be redy to serue / in to thys nyght
Haue I not feyned / but enforced my myght
Do now as I shal sey / and fare a right
For I haue do thy lust / wyth al my myght
And yf thou nylt / wyte thy self thy care
On me is not a long / thyn euyl fare
I wote wel that thou wyser art than I
