A thousand fold / but and I were as thou
God help me so I wold vtterly
Ryght of myn owne hand / wryte to her now
A letter in whyche / I wold telle her how
I ferd amys / and her beseche of rowth
Now help thy self / and let for no slouth
And I my self shal therwyth to hyr gon
And whan thow wost that I am there
Worth vpon a courser and that anon
Ye hardyly / ryght in thy best gere
And right forth by yt place as nought ne were
And thou shalt synd vs / yf I may fittyng
At som̄e wyndowe / in to the strete lokynge
And yf the lyst / thou mayst vs fal • we
And vpon me make thy contrnounce
But by thy lyf beware / and fast eschyewe
To taryen ought / god sh • ld vs from myschalice
Ryde forth thy wey / and hold thy gouernalice
And we shuln speke of the somwhat I trowe
Whan thou art gon / to make thyn eren glowe
Touchyng thy letter / thou art wyse ynow
I wote wel thou nylt / it clerkly endytr
As make it wyth these / argumentie • ow
Ne seriuanly / ne • aftyly it wryte
Blot •• it eke / wyth thy treris alyte
And though thou wryte / a goodely word & soft
Though it be good / reherse it not to oft
For though the lest harper / vpon lyue
Wold on the best sowned / Ioly harpe
That euer was / wyth as hys fyngres fyue
Touche ay one stryng / or ay one warbyl harpe
Wyth hys nayles / poynted neuer so sharpe
It shuld make euery wyght to dulle
To here hys glee / and of hys strokes fulle
Ne Iompre not / no dyscordaunt in feere
As vsen these termes of physik
In loues termes / hold on thy matere
The fourme alwey / and do that it be lyke
For yf a peyntour / wold peynt a pyke
Wyth asses feete / and heed as an ape
It cordyth not / so ner it but a Iape
Thys consayl lyked wel Twylus
But as a dredeful man he sayd thys
Alas my dere brother pandarus
I am ashamed / for to wryten ywys
Lest of myn Innocence / I sayd amys
Or that she nold / for despyte it receyue
Than were I ded / ther myght nothyng it weyue
To that Pandare answerd / yf the lest
Do as I sey / and lete me therwyth gon
For by that lord / that formed Est and West
I hope of it / to brynge answer anon
Ryght of hyr hond / and yf thou wylt none
Late be / and sory mote he be hys lyue
Ageynst thy lust / that helpyth the to thryue
Quod Troylus depardieux yche assent
Syth that the lyst I wyl aryse and wryte
And blysful god pray I / wyth good entent
The vyage and the letter / I shal endyte
So spede / and thow minerua the whyte
Gyue thow me wyt / my lettir to deuyse
And sat hym doun / and wrote in thys wyse
Fyrst he gan her / hys ryght lady calle
Hys hertis lyf / hys lust / hys sorowes leche
Hys blys and eke these other termes alle
That in suche •• as / ye louers alle seeche
And in ful humble wyse as in hys speche
He gan hym recomaund vnto hyr grace
To tel al how / it askyth moche space
And after thys / ful lowly he hyr preyde
To be not wroth / though he of hys foly
So hardy was her to wryte or seyde
But loue it made / or ellis must he dye
And pytously gan mercy for to crye
And after he sayd / and lyed lowde
Hym self was lytel worth / & lesse good cowde
And prayed her haue exeusid hys vnkonnyng
That lytel was / and eke hym self also
Was wele ny deed / in hys wrytyng
And after that / than gan he tel hys woo
But that was endlees / wythouten hoo
And sayd he wold / in trowth alwey hym hold
And rad it ouer / and gan the letter fold
And wyth hys salt treris / gan he bathe
The Ruby in hys signet / and it he set
Vpon the wexe / delyuerly and rathe
Therwyth a thousand tymes / or he let
He kyst the lettyr / and after that it shet
And sayd lettre / a blysful destyne
The shapyn is / my lady shal the see
Thys Pandare toke the letter ryght by tyme
On morow & to hys necis palays he hym stert
And fast he swore / that it was passed pryme
And gan to Iape / and sayd ywys myn hert
So fressh it is / al though it sore smert
I may not sleepe / neuer a mayes morow
I haue a Ioly woo / & a lusty sorowe
Cryseyde whan she / her vncle herde
Wyth dredeful herte / and desirous to here
The cause of hys comyng / thus answerd
Now by your feyth myn vncle quod she dere
What maner wynd / guydyth yow now here
Telle vs your Ioly woo / and youre penaunce
How ferforth ben ye / put in louys daunce
By god quod he / I hoppe alway behynde
And she to laugh / hyr thought her hert brest
Quod Pandarus / loke alwey that ye fynde
Game in my hood / but herkenyth yf ye lest
Ther is right now come to towne a gest
A greeke aspye / and tellyth new thynges
Wherfor I come / to tel yow tydynges
In to the gardyn gowe / and ye shul here
Al pryuyly of thys / a long sermon
Wyth that they went / arme in arme yfere
In to the gardyn / from the chamber doun
And whan he was so fer / that the sown
Of that he spak / noman here myght
He sayd her thus / and out the lettir plyght
Lo he that is / as holy youres free
Hym recomaundyth / lowly to yowre grace
And sent yow thys letter / here by me
Auyse you on it / whan ye haue space
And of som̄e goodely answere / yow purchace
Or so help me god / pleynly for to seyne
He may not long lyue / in thys peyne
Ful dredefully tho / gan the stonde stylle
And toke it not / but alle here humble chere
Gan for to chaunge / and sayd script ne bylle
For loue of god / that touchyth suche matere
Ne bryng me none / and also vncle dere
To myn estate haue more reward I prey
Than to hys lust / what shuld I more sey
And lokyth now yf thys be resonable
And lettyth not / for fauour ne for slowth
To sey a sooth / now were it couenable
To myn estate by god / and by yowre trowth
To take it / to haue of hym rowth
In harmyng of my self / or repreue
Bere it ageyn / for hym that ye on leeue
Thys Pandarus / gan on hyr for to stare
And seyd now / thys is the most wondyr
That euer I sawe / late be thys nyce fare
To deth mote I smyte be / wyth thondyr
Yf for the citee / whyche that stondyth yondyr
And I a lettyr to yow / bryng or take
To harm of yow / what lust ye thys to make
But thus ye fare wele ny / all and som̄e
He that moste desirith / yow to serue
Of hym ye retche leest / where he become
Or whether that he lyue / or ellis sterue
But for al that / I may deserue
Refuse it not quod he / and bent hyr fast
And in hyr bosum / doun the lettre thraft
And sayd hyr / cast it fast away anon
That folk may / see and gawre on vs • wey
Quod she I can abyde / tyl they be gon
And gan to smyle / and sayd Game I prey
Such āswer an yow lyse / such your self po • uey
For trewly / I nyl no lettir wryte
No than wyl I / so that ye endyte
I herwyth she laugh / and sayd go we dyne
And began at hym self / Iape faste
And sayd ne •• I / haue so grete a pyne
For loue that euery othyr day I faste
And gan hys Iaprs / best forth to caste
And make her so to laugh / of bye folye
That she for laughtir / wend for to dye
And whan she was comen / in to the halle
Now Eame quod she / we wyl go dyne an one
And gan som̄e of hyr wymmen / to calle
And streyght vnto hyr chambyr / gan she gone
But of hyr besynesse / thys was one
Among other thynges / out of drede
Ful pryuely / thys letter gan she rede
Auysed word by word in euery lyne
And fond no lack / she thought he cowde goode
And vp it put and went hyr in to dyne
But Pandarus / that in studye stoode
Or he was ware / she toke hym by the hoode
And sayd ye were caught / or that ye wyste
I vouchesauf quod he / do what ye lyste
Tho wysshen they / and set hem doun to ete
And aftyr anon / ful slyly Pandarus
Gan drawe hym to the wyndow / next the strete
And sayd neece / who hath arayed thus
That yondy • hous / that stont / aforyenst vs
Whyche hous quod she / and come for to behold
And knewe it wele / & whos it was hym told
And fyllen forth / in speche of thynges smale
And satyn in the wyndow / bothe twey
Whan Pandarus fawe tyme / vnto hys tale
And sawe wel / hyr folk were a wey
Now neece myn tel on / quod he I sey
How lykyth yow thys letter / that ye wote
Can he ther on / for by my trowth I note
Therwyth al rose hewed / tho wax she
And gan to homme / ye so I trowe
And write to hym wele for goddis sake quod he
My self to medes / wyl the lettre sowe
And held hys handis vp / and fel on knowe
Now goode nece be it neuer so lyte
Gyue me the labour / it to sowe and plyte
Ye for I can so wryte quod she tho
And eke I note / what I shul to hym sey
Nay neece quod Pandare / sey not so
Yit at the lest / thank hym I yow prey
Of hys good wyl / o do hym not to dey
Now for the loue of me / my neece dere
Refuse not at thys tyme / my prayere
God graunt quod she / al thyng be wele
God help me so thys is the fyrst lettyr
That euer I wrote / ye or ony dele
And in to a closet / for to auyse hyr bettyr
She went anon / and gan hyr hert vnfettyr
Out of dysdeygnous pryson lete a lyte
She sette hyr doun / and gan a lettyr wryte
Of whyche to tel / in short is myn entent
Theffect as fer / as I can vnderstonde
She thankid hym of al / that he wele ment
Towardis her / but holden hym in honde
She wold not / ne make hyr self bonde
In loue but as hys suster / hym to please
She wold ay fayne / do hys hert ease
She shyt it / and to Pandare gan gon
There as he sat / and lookid in to the strete
And doun she set hyr / by hym on a ston
Of Iasper vpon a qwysshon / of gold I bete
And sayd as wysly / help me god the grete
I neuer dyd a thyng / wyth more peyne
Than wryte thys / to whyche ye me constreyne
And toke it hym / he thanked here and seyde
God wote of thyng / ful oft both bygonne
Comyth end goode / and neece myn Criseyde
That ye to hym / of hard now be wonne
Ought he be glad / by god and by yond sonne
For why men seyn / impressions light
Ful lyghtly ben al / redy to the flyght
But ye haue pleyde / the tyraunt nye to longe
And hard was it / yowre hert for to graue
Now stynt that ye / not lenger on it honge
Al wolde the fourme / of daungyer it saue
But hastyth yow / to do hym Ioy to haue
For trustyth wele / to long y do hardnesse
Causith dyspyte ful oft / for dystresse
And right as they declarid thys 〈…〉 ere
Lo Troylus ryght / at the stretis end
Come rydyng / wyth hys people in feere
Al softly / and thyderward gan bend
There as they sat / as was hys wey to wend
To paleys ward / and Pandare hym aspyed
And sayd neece / lo who 〈◊〉 here now ryde
O flee not in / he seeth vs as I suppose
Lest he may thynk / that we hym eschew
Nay nay quod she / and wax as rede as rose
Wyth that he gan / hyr humbly salew
With dredeful chere / and oft his hew was new
And vp hys hede / debonayrly he cast
And bekened on Pandare / and forth he past
God wote yf he sat / on hys hors a ryght
Or goodely was beseyn / that ylk day
God wote whether he was like a māly knyght
What shuld I dretche / or telle of hys aray
Criseyde whyche that / all thyse thyng say
To tel in short / hyr lyked alle in fere
Hys persone hys aray • hys looke hys chere
Hys goodely maner / and hys gentylesse
So wel that neuer / sith she was born
Ne had she suche rowth / of hys dystresse
And though she had be hard / there toforn
To good hope / she hath now caught a thorn
She shal not pul it out / thys next wyke
God send her mo suche / thornes on to pyke
Pandare whyche that stood hyr fast by
Felt the yren hote / and bygan to smyte
And sayd nece / I pray yow hertyly
Tell me that I sh 〈…〉
A womman 〈…〉 to wyte
Wythout 〈…〉 rowth
Were it w 〈…〉 by my trowth
God help m 〈…〉 y me sooth
Yf ye feele yo 〈…〉 ot lye
Lo yond he r 〈…〉 o he doth
Wele quod P 〈…〉 / as I haue told yow thry
Late be yo 〈…〉 ame / and foly
And speke 〈…〉 ym hym / in easynge of hys hert
Late nycete not d 〈…〉 yow both to smert
But theron was / to heue and to done
Considered al thyng / it may not so be
And why for speche / and eke it were to soone
To graunt hym yit / so grete a lyberte
For playnly her entent / as sayd she
Was for to loue hym / vnwyst yf she myght
And gwerdon hym with nothyng / but with sight
But pandare thought / it shuld not be so
Yf that I may thys nyce oppynyon
Shal not be hold / fully yeris • wo
What shuld I make of thys / a long sermon
She must assent / on that conclusion
As for the tyme / and whan that it was eue
And al was wele / he roos and toke hys leue
And on hys way homward / ful fast hym sped
And ryght for Ioye / he felt hys hert daunce
And Troylus he fond / alone a bed
That lay as don / thyse louers in a traunce
Betwyx hope / and derst desperaunce
But Pandare ryght / al hys in comyng
He sang as who sayth / som̄what I bryng
And sayd who is in hye bedd so soone
Y buried thus / it am I frend quod he
Who Troylus nay / help me so the moone
Quod Pandarus / th 〈…〉
A charme that was 〈…〉
The whyche can hele 〈…〉
So that thow do forthw 〈…〉
Ye thurgh the myght of g 〈…〉

div.l: Haue here a lyght / & looke ouer a 〈…〉
But oft gan hys hert / glad and a 〈…〉
Of Troylus whyle he gan it rede
So as the wordis / yaue hym hoope and drede

lg.l: But fynally / he toke alle for the best
That she hym wrote / for som̄what he byheld
On whyche he thought / he myght hys hert rest
Al couered she the word / vndyr sheld
Thus to the more worthyer / part he held
That what for hope / and Pandarus byhest
Hys grete woo foryeede / at the lest
But as we may alday / our seluen see
The more woode and cool / the more fyre
Ryght soo encreas of hope / what so it be
Therwyth ful oft / encreasith hys desyre
Or as an Oke / cometh of a lytel spyre
So thurgh thys letter / whiche that she hym sent
Encreace gan desire / wyth whyche he brent
Wherfor I sey alwey / that day and nyght
Thys Troylus / gan to desire more
Than he dyde erst / thurgh hope & did his myght
To preacen on / as by Pandarus lore
And wrote vnto hyr / of hys sorowes sore
Fro day to day / he lete it not refreyde
That by pandare somwhat he wrote or seyde
And dyd also hys other obseruaunces
That to a louer / longyth in thys caas
And after that hys dyce / torned on chaunces
So he was outher glad / or sayd alas
And held after hys gyftes / ay hys pas
As after suche answere as he had

So were hys daye •
〈◊〉 other glad
But to pandare alwey / was hys recours
And pytously gan / vnto hym pleyne
And hym besought / of rede or som̄e socours
And Pandarus sawe hys woodely peyne
Wax wele ny deed / for rowth sooth to seyne
And besily wyth al hys hert he cast
Som̄e of hys woo to slee / and that as fast
And sayd lord / and frend / and brother dere
God wote that thy desease / doeth me woo
But wylt thou stynt / al thys woful chere
And by my trouth / or it be dayes two
And god to forn / yit shal I shape it so
That thou shalt come / in to a certeyn place
Ther as thou mayst thy self / prey hyr of grace
And certaynly I note / yf thou it wost
But tho that ben expert / in loue I sey
It is one of the thynges / that furtherith most
A man to haue a leyser / for to prey
And siker place hys woo for to bewrey
For in good hert / ther must rowth impresse
To hyr that seeth / the gyltles in dystresse
Perauenture thynkest thou / though it be soo
That kynd wold done / for to begynne
To haue a maner rowth / vpon my woo
Seyth daūgyer nay thou shalt me neuer wynne
In that maner for no maner gynne
Though that she bende yit / she stant on Roote
What in effect is thys / vnto my boote
Than ther ageynst / whan that the sturdy oke
On whyche men hacke / oft for the nones
Receyued hath / the happy fallynge stroke
The grete sweyght / doth it falle at ones
As don thyse rokkes / to the mylstones
For swyfter cours / comyth thyng of weyght
Whan it descendyth / than don thynges •• ght
But Reede that bowyth doun / wyth euery blast
Ful lyghtly wyth the wynd / it wyl aryse
But so nyl not an oke / whan it is cast
It nedyth me not / the long to deuyse
Men shuld reioyse / of grete empryse
Acheuyth wele / and stondyth oute of doute
Al haue men ben / the lenger ther aboute
But Troylus now tel me yf the lest
A thyng the whyche / I shal aske the
Whyche is the brother / that thou louest best
As in thy veray hertis pryuyte
Ywys my dere brother / Deyphebe
Now quod Pandare / or houris twyes twelue
He shal the ease / vnwyst of hym selue
Now lete me alone / and werke as I may
Quod he / and to deyphebus wente he tho
Whyche had hys lord / and grete frend ben ay
Saue Troylus noman he loued so
To tel in short / wythout wordis mo
Quod Pandarus / I pray yow that ye be
Frend to a cause / whyche that touchyeth me
Yis parde quod Deyphebus / wel thou wost
In alle that euer I may / and god to fore
Al neere it but for oo man / that I loue most
My brother Troylus / but sey me wherfore
It is for sith the day / that I was bore
I nas nor neuermore / to be I thynk
Ageynst a thyng / that myght the forthynk
Pandarus gan hym thank / and thus he seyde
Lo sire I haue a lady in thys towne
That is my neece / and callyd is Criseyde
Whyche som̄e men wolde do oppression
And wrongfully haue her possession
Wherfor yowre lordshyp / I yow beseche
To be oure frend wythout more speche
Deiphebus answerd / is it thys
That thou to me spack of / so straungely
Criseyde my frend / he sayd she is
Than nedyth quod Deiphebus / hardily
Nomore of thys for trusteth wel that I
Wyl be hyr champioun / wyth spere and swerd
I rought not / though all hyr foes it herd
But tel me / for thou wost thys matere
I myght hyr best auayle / now late see
Quod Pandarus / yf ye my lord so dere
Wold as now do / thys honour vnto me
To prayen hyr thys / to morow that she
Come vnto yow / hyr playntes to deuyse
Hyr aduersaryes / wold therof agryse
Lord yf that more / I durst yow prey as now
And charge yow to haue so grete trauayle
To haue som̄e of yowre brethern / here with yow
Than myght hyr cause / the better auayle
Than wote I wel / she myght neuer fayle
For to be holp / what at your instaunce
What wyth hyr othyr frendes / sustenaunce
Deiphebus whyche that was / come of kynde
To al honour / and bounte to consent
Answerd it shal be don / and I can fynde
Yit gretter help to thys / in myn entent
That wylt thou sey / yf for Heleyne I sent
To speke of thys / I trow it be best
For she may leede Paris / as hyr lest
For Hector whyche that is my lord my brother
It nedyth not to pray hym frend to be
For I haue herd hym / bothe one tyme and other
Speke of Criseyde suche honour that he
May sey no bet / suche hap to hym hath she
So nedyth not hys help / now for to craue
He shal be suche / ryght as we wyl hym haue
Speke thou thy self also to Troylus
On my behalue / and pray hym wyth vs dyne
Syr al thys shal be do / quod Pandarus
And toke hys leue / and neuer gan to fyne
But to hys neecis hous / as streyght as a lyne
He come and fond hyr / from the mete aryse
And set hym doun / & spack right in thys wyse
He sayd / O veray god so haue I ronne
Lo neece myn / see ye not how I swete
I note whether the more / ye me thank conne
Be ye not ware / how fals Poliphete
Is now aboute / eftsoones to plete
To bryng on yow / aduocatis newe
I no quod she / and chaungyd all her hewe
What is he more aboute / me to dretche
And do me wrong / what shal I do alas
Yit of hym self / nothyng wold I retche
Ner it for Anthenor and Eneas
That ben hys frendes / in suche maner cas
But for the loue of god / myn vncle dere
No fors of it / lete hym haue al yfere
Wythout that I haue ynowgh for vs
Nay quod Pandare / it shal nothyng be soo
For I haue be right now / wyth Deiphebus
At Hector / and myn other lordis moo
And shortly made eche of theym / hys foo
That by my thryft / he shal it neuer wynne
For aught he can / whan so that he begynne
And as they cast / what was best to done
Deiphebus / of hys owne curtesye
Came hyr to prey / in hys owne propyr persone
To hold hym / on the morow companye
At dyner whyche she wold / hym not denye
But goodely gan / to hys prayer obeye
He thankyth hyr / and went vpon hys weye
Whan thys was done thys pandare vp anone
To tel in short / forth he gan to wende
To Troylus as styl as ony stone
Of al thys thyng he told hym word and ende
And how he Deiphebus gan to blende
And sayd now is tyme / yf that thou conne
Bere the wele to morow / and al is wonne
Now speke now prey / now pytously compleyne
Leue not for nyce shame / or drede or slowth
Somtyme a man mote / tel hys owne peyne
Byleue it and she wyl haue / on the rowth
Thou shalt be sauyd / by thy feyth in trowth
But wele wote I thou art in a drede
And what it is / lo I can it rede
Thou thynkest now / how shal I do al thys
For by my chere / must folke espye
That for loue is / that I fare amys
Yit had I leuer ywys / for sorow dye
Now thynk not so / thou doest grete folye
For I ryght now / haue found a manere
Of sleyght / for to couere al thy chyere
Thou shalt goo ouer nyght / and that as blyue
Vnto Deiphebus hous / the to pley
Thy malady the bet / awey to dryue
For why thou semyst syke / the sooth to sey
Soone after that / doun in thy bed the ley
And sey thou mayst / no lenger vp endure
And be right there / and byde thy aueuture
Sey that the feuer / is wont the to take
The same tyme / and last tyl a morowe
And lete see now / how wel thou kanst it make
For parde sike is he that is in sorowe
Go now fare wele / and venus here to borowe
I hope and thou / thy pourpos hold ferme
In grace she shal / the fully conferme
Quod Troylus ywys / thou nedeles
Counseylest me / sikerly to feyne
For I am sike / in ernest douteles
So wel ny that / I sterue for the peyne
Quod Pandarus / thou shalt the bettyr pleyne
And hast the lasse nede / to countrefete
For hym men deme hote / that men see swete
Lo hold the at thy Trist clos / and I
Shal wele the dere / vnto thy lowe dryue
Therwyth he toke hys leue / al softly
And Troylus to paleys went blyue
So glad he nas / neuer in all hys lyue
And to Pandarus rede / gan al assent
And to Deiphebus hous / at nyght he went
What nedyth yow / to tellen of the chere
That Deiphebus gan hys brothyr make
Or hys accesse / or hys sikely manere
How men hym gan / wyth clothys lade
Whan he was leyde / & how men did hym glade
But alle for nought / he held forth hys guyse
As ye haue herd / Pandare hym deuyse
But certeyne is / or Troylus hym leyde
Deiphebus preyd hym / ouer nyght
To be a frend and helpyng to Criseyde
God wote that he / it graunted anon right
To be hyr ful frend / wyth al hys myght
But suche a nede it was / to praye hym thenne
As for to bydde / a woode man to renne
The morowe come / and nyghen gan the tyme
Of mele tyde / that the fayre quene heleyne
Shoope hyr to be / an hour after the pryme
Wyth deiphebus / to whom she wold not feyne
But as hys suster / homely soth to seyne
She come to dyner / in hyr playn entent
But god & Pādare / wyst none what this ment
Come eke Criseyde al innocent of thys
Antygone hyr suster and Targe also
But fle we now prolixite best is
For loue of god and lete vs fast goo
Ryght to theffect / wythout talis moo
Why al thys folk / assembled in that place
And lete vs of theyr salowynges pace
Grete honour dyd hem Deiphebus certeyne
And fed hem wel / with al yt myght hem lyke
But euermore alas / was hys refreyne
My good brother / Troylus the sike
Lyeth yet / and therwyth al he gan to sike
And after that / he peyned hym to glade
Hem as he myght / and good chere hem made
Compleyned eke Heleyne / of hys sikenesse
So feythfully / that pyte was to here
And euery wyght than / was for that accesse
A leche anon / and seyde in thys manere
Men curen folke / thys charme I wyl yow 〈◊〉
But ther sat one / al lyst her not to 〈◊〉
That thought / yit best cowd I be hys lec ••
After compleynt / than gan they hym to preyse
As folk don yet / when som̄e han bygonne
To preyse a man / and vp wyth hym to reyse
A thousand fold / yit hyer than the sonne
He is that can / that fewe lordis conne
And Pandarus of that / they wold afferme
He not forgate / hys praysyng to conferme
Herd al thys / Cryseyde wel ynowgh
And euery word / gan to notyfye
For whyche wyth sobre chere / her hert lowgh
For who is that / nold hym gloryfye
To mone suche a knyght / to lyue or dye
But al passe I / lese ye to long dwelle
For al is / for a fyne that I you telle
To tyme come / from dyner for to ryse
And as theym ought / they rysen eueryc • on
And gan a whyle / of thys and that deuyse
But Pandarus / brake al that speche anon
And saydto Deiphebus / wyl we gon
Yf yowre wyl be / as I yow preyde
To speke here of the needis / of Criseyde
Heleyne whyche that / by the hand hyr held
Toke fyrst the tale / and sayd gowe blyue
And goodly on Criseyde she beheld
And sayd Iouis late hym neuer thryue
That doeth yow harm / & bryng hym self of lyue
And yeue me sorowe / but he shal it rewe
Yf that I may / and alle folkes be trewe
Tel thou thy neecis caas / quod Deiphebus
To Pandarus / for thou canst best it telle
My lordis and my ladyes it stant thus
What shuld I lenger / do yow dwelle
He rong hym out a proces lyke a belle
Vpon hyr foo / that hyght poliphete
So haynous that men / myght on it spete
Answerd of this eche of theym / worse thā other
And poliphete / thus gan they waryen
An hanged lo such one / were he my brother
And so it shal / for it may not varien
What shuld I lenger / in thys processe taryen
Playnly al at ones / they hyr behyght
To be hyr frend / in all that euer they myght
Spack than heleyne / and herd Pandarus
Wote ought my lord my brother thys matere
I meane Hector / or wote it Troylus
He sayd ye / but wyl ye now me here
Me thynketh thys / sith Troylus is here
It were goode / yf that ye wolde assent
She told hym her self / al thys or she went
For he wyl haue the more / hyr grief at hert
By cause loo / that she a lady is
And by yowre leue / I wyl but in stert
And do yow wyte / and that anon ywys
Yf that he sleepe / or wyl ought here of thys
And in he leepe / and sayd hym in hys eere
God haue thy soule brought I haue thy bere
To smylen gan / of thys Troylus
And Pandarus / wythout restonyng
Out went anon / to Heleyne and Deiphebus
And seyd hem so / ther be no taryeng
Ne more I wyl wel / that ye bryng •
Criseyde anon / my lady that is here
As he may endure / he wyl yow here
But wel ye wote / the chambre is but lyte
And fewe folk may lyghtly / make it warme
Now lokith ye / for I wyl haue no wyte
To bryng in pr •• s / that myght do hym h • rme
• r hym dysease / for my bettyr arme
Where it be •• t / she abyde tyl eft sonne is
Now looke ye that knowe / what to dene is
I say for me best is / as I can knowe
That no wyght now wend in but ye • wey
But it were for I can in a throwe
Reherce hyr cause / vnlyke that she can sey
And after thys / she may hym oones prey
To be hyr good lord / in short and take hyr leue
Thys may not moche / of hys ease hym true
And for that she is straunge / he wyl forbere
Hys ease whyche he dare not for yow
Eke other thynges / whyche touchyth not to her
He wol yow telle / I wote it wel ynow
That secret is / and for the townes prow
And she that nothyng knew / of thys entent
Wythout more / to Troylus in went
Heleyne in al hyr goodely soft wyse
Gan hym sa •• w / and wommanly pley
And sayd ywys / ye mote algate aryse
Now fayr brother / be al hole I yow prey
And gan hyr arme / vpon hys shulder ley
And hym wyth al hyr hert / she gan dysport
As she best cowde / of sorow hym to comfort
Soone after quod she / we yow byseke
My dere brother Deiphebus / and I
For loue of god / and so doth Pandare eke
To be good lord / and frend right hertyly
Vnto Criseyde whyche that certeynly
Receyuyth wrong / as wote wel here Pandare
That can hyr cas / wel bet than I declare
Thys Pandarus / gan now hys tunge affyle
And al hyr caas rehersid / and that anon
Whan it was seyd / soone after in a whyle
Quod Troylus / as soone as I may gon
I wyl ryght fayn / wyth al my myght anon
Haue god my trowth / hyr cause to sustene
Goode thryft haue ye / quod Heleyne the quene
Quod Pandadas / and yit yowre wyl be
That she may take hyr leue / or that she go
Now ellis god forbede it tho quod she
Yf that she vouchesauf / for to do so
And wyth that word / quod Troylus ye two
Deiphebe / and ye my suster dere
To yow haue I to speke / of a matere
To be aduysed / by yowre aduyse the bettir
And had as hap was / at hys beddis hede
The copy of a tretice / and a lettyr
That Hector had hym sent / to askyn rede
Yf suche a man / were worthy to be dede
Note I not who / but in a grysely wyse
He prayed hem bothe anon / on hyt auyse
Deiphebus / gan thys lettyr vnfold
In ernest grete / so dyde heleyne the qwene
And romyng outward / fast gan it behold
Dounward a stayre / and in to an herber grene
Thys ylke thyng / they redden hem betwene
And largely / the montenaunce of an honre
They gonne on it / for to rede and powre
Now lete hem rede / and tourne we anon
To Pandarus / that gan ful fast pry
That as wel in and out / gan he gon
Vnto the chambre a loft / and that on hy
And sayd god saue al thys company
Come now my neede / my lady awene Heleyne
Abydyth yow / and eke my lordis • weyne
Ryse take wyth yow / your neere Antigone
Or whom ye lyst / or nofors hardyly
The lesse preace the bet / come forth wyth me
And loke that ye thank humbely
Hem al thre / and whan ye may goodely
Yowre tyme see / takyth of hem yowre leue
Lest we to long / hys rest hym byreue
Al innocent / of Pandarus entent
O uod tho C • seydes / go we vncle dere
And arme in arme / inward with hym she went
Auysyng wel hyr wordis / and hyr chere
And Pandarus / in erne fullest manere
Seyd al folk / for goddis loue I prey
Styntyth ryght here / and softely ye pley
Auyse ye what folke / ben here wythynne
And in what ply • r one is / god hym amende
And ynward thus / ful softly begynne
Neece I coniure / and hyely defende
On hys half / whyche that vs soule hath sende
And in the vertu / of the corownes tweyne
Sle not this man / that hath for yow this peyne
Fy on the deuyl / thynk whyche one be is
And in what plyte he lyeth / come of anone
Thynk al suche taryed tyde / lost is
That wyl ye both sey / whan ye ben one
And sikerly ther yit / dyuyneth none
Vpon yow two / come of now yf ye conne
Whyle folk is blent / lo al the tyme is wonne
In tyteryng in pursuyte / and delayes
Folk wyl dyuyne / at waggyng of a stre
That though ye wold / haue after merye dayes
Than dare ye not for why / for he and he
Spack suche a word / thus lookid she and she
Thus tyme y lost / I dare not wyth yow dele
Come of therfor / and bryng hym to hys hele
But now to yow / ye louers that ben here
Was not trroylus / in a cankerdort
That lay & myght / the whyspryng of her here
And thought o lord / now rennyth my sort
Fully to dye / or haue no comfort
And was the fyrst tyme he shuld hyr preye
Of loue / o myghty god what shal I seye

div.head: ¶And here begynneth the prologe of the thyrde booke

lg.l: O Blisful light of which the beames clere
Adourneth / al the hye heuenes fayre
O sonnys lyf / O Iouys doughter d • re
Pbe saunce o loue / o goodely debonayre
In gentyl hertis / redy to repayre
O veray cause of hele / and of gladnesse
Y heryed be thy myght / and thy goodnesse
In heuene and helle / erthe and see
Is fyrst thy myght / yf that I wel dyscerne
As man bryd best / fyssh herbe and grene tree
The feld in tymes / wyth vapour eterne
God louyth and to loue / he wyl not werne
And in thys world / no lyues creature
Wythout loue is worth / or may endure
In Iouis fyrst / to thylk effectis glade
Thurgh whyche that thynges / lyuen al and be
Commendyd / and amoureux hem made
O mortal thyng / and as thou lyst ay see
Yaue hem in loue / ease or aduersite
And in a thousand fourmes / doun hem sent
To loue in erthe / and whom ye lyst is blent
The fyers Mars / to apesyn of hys Ire
And as ye lyst me make hertis dygne
Algatis hem / that ye wyl sette a fyre
That dreden shame / and vyces yit resigne
Ye to hem curteys / fressh be and benygne
And hem promotith / aftyr a wyght entendyth
The Ioye that he hath / your myght hym fendyth
Ye holdyn regne and hous / in vnyte
The sothfast cause / and frendshyp be also
Ye know all thylk / couered qualyte
Of thynges whiche that folkes wondren on so
That they can not constrewe / how it may geo
She louyth hym / or why loueth he not here
Or why this fissh / & not that comyth to the were
The folke a lawe / han sette in vniuers
And thys know I / by theym that louers be
That who so striuyth with yow / hath the wers
Now lady bryght / for thy benygnyte
At reuerence of hem / that seruen the
Whos clerk I am / teche me deuyse
Som̄e Ioye of that / is felt in thy seruyse
Ye in my naked / hertis sentement
In elde / and do me shewe of thy wytnesse
Caliope / thy dayes ben now present
For now is nede / seest thon not my dystresse
How I must telle anon / right the gladnesse
Of Troylus to venus heryeng
To which gladnesse who nede hath god hym bryng

div.head: ¶And here begynneth the thyrde booke

lg.l: LAy al thys mene whyle Troylus
Recordyng hys lesson / in thys manere
Mafey thought he / thus wil I sey & thus
Thus wyl I pleyne / vnto my lady dere
That word is good / & that shal be my matere
Thys wyl I not for geten / in no wyse
God lyeue he werke / as he gan deuyse
And lord so hys hert / gan tho to whappe
Heryng hyr come / and sore for to syke
And Pandarus / that lad hyr by the lappe
Come nere and gan / in at the curteyn pyke
And sayd god do bote / on al sike
See who is here / yow comyn to vysite
Lo here is she / that is yowre deth to wyte
Therwyth it semed / that he wept almost
A ha god / quod Troylus so sorowfully
Wher me be woo / o myghte god thou wost
Who is al there / I see not trewly
Syr quod Criseyde / it is Pandare and I
Ye swete hert / Alas I may not ryse
To knele and do yow honour / in som̄e wyse
And dressid hym vpward / and she ryght tho
Bygan hyr handis soft / vpon hym leye
O for the loue of god / do ye not so
To me quod she / what is thys to seye
Syr come 〈◊〉 I to yow / for causes tweye
Fyrst yow to thank / of yowre good lorshyp eke
Contynuaunce therof / I yow byseke
Troylus that herd thus / hys lady praye
Of lordshyp hym was nother / quyck ne dede
Ne myght one word / for shame to hyr seye
And though men shuld haue smyte of his hed
But lord so he was / sodaynly rede
And hys lesson / that he wend had conne
To pray hyr / was thurgh hys hert y ronne
Criseyde al thys espyed wel ynowgh
For she was wyse / & louyd hym neuer the lasse
Al though he were not malaꝑt / & made it towgh
Or was to bold / to syng a foole a masse
But whan his shame / bygan somwhat to passe
Hys wordis as I may / my rymes hold
I wyl yow tellen / as techen bokes old
In chaungyd voyce / right for hys lady drede
Whyche voyce eke quoke / & therto hys manere
Goodely abasshyd and now hys hyewes rede
Now pale vnto Criseyde hys lady dere
Wyth looke doun cest / and humble lowly chere
Lo altherfyrst word / that hym astert
Was twyes mercy mercy swete hert
And stynt a while / & whan he myght out bryng
The next word was / god wote for I haue
As ferforth as I haue had connynge
Be yowres all / so god my soule saue
And shal tyl that / I woful wyght be graue
And though I ne dare / ne can to yow compleyne
Y wys I suffre not / the lasse peyne
Thus moche as now / o wommanly wyf
I may out bryng / and yf it yow dysplease
That shal I wreke / vpon myn owne lyf
Ryght soone I trowe / and do yowre hert and ease
If wyth my deth / yowre hert may apease
For sith ye haue me herd / somwhat seye
Now retche I neuer / how soone that I deye
Therwyth hys manly sorow / to byhold
It myght hath made an hert / of stone to rewe
And Pandare wept / as he to water wold
And seyd wo begon / ben hertis trewe
And prokid euer hys neece / newe and newe
For loue of god / make of thys thyng an ende
Or slee vs both at ones / or we hens wende
Ey what quod she / by god and by my trowth
I wote not what ye wold that I sey
I what quod he / that ye haue of hym rowth
For goddis loue / and do hym not to dey
Now than quod she thus I wold hym prey
To telle me the fyne of hys entent
Yit wyst I neuer / wel what he ment
What that I meane / o swete hert dere
Quod Troylus / o goodely fressh fre
Wyth the streames / of youre eyen clere
Ye wold frendly / somtyme on me see
And that ye suffre / that I neuer be he
Wythout braunche of vyce / in ony wyse
Yow for to serue / lyke as ye wyl deuyse
As to my lady ryght / and chyef resort
And al my wytte / and al my dylygence
And I to haue ryght as yow lyst comfort
Vndyr your yerd egal / to myn offence
As deth / ye yf I do ony offence
And that ye lyst me / somoche honoure
Me to coumaunde / ought in ony houre
And I to be yowre / veray humble trewe
Secret / and in my paynes pacyent
And euermore desire / fresshly newe
To serue and be / y lyke dylygent
And wyth good hert / al holy yowre talent
Receyue in gree / how sore tht me smert
Lo thus meane I / myn owne swete hert
Quod Pandarus lo here / an hard request
And resonably / a lady for to werne
Now neece myn / by natal Iouis fest
Were I a god / ye shuld sterue as yerne
That heren wel thys man / nothynge yerne
But yowre honour / and see hym almost sterue
And be so loth / to suffre hym yow to serue
Wyth that she gan hyr eyen / on hym cast
Ful esily / and ful debonayrly
Auysyng hyr / and hyed her not to fast
Wyth neuer a word / but sayd hym sobyrby
Myn honour sauf / I wyl wel trewly
And in suche fourme / as ye conne deuyse
Receyuen hym fully / to my seruyse
Besechyng hym / for goddis loue that he
Wold in honour trowth / and gentylnesse
As I wel • meane / eke meane he wel to me
And myn honour / wyth al besynesse
Ay kepe yf I may / & do hym gladnesse
From hensforth / ywys I wyl not feyne
Now beth al hole / no lenger that ye pleyne
But natheles / thys warne I yow quod she
A kynges sone / though ye be ywys
Ye shul nomore / haue souemynte
Of me in loue / right but as in that cas is
Ne I nyl forbere / yf ye don amys
To wrath yow / and whyle ye me serue
Cherissh yow right after yow deserue
And shortly dere hert and al my knyght
Beth glad and drawe yow / to lustynesse
And I shal trewly / wyth al my myght
Yowre bytter torne / al in to swetnesse
Yf I be she / that may do you gladnesse
For euery woo / ye shul recouere a blysse
And hym in armys toke / and gan hym kysse
Fyl Pandare on knees / and vp hys eyen
To heuene he threwe / and held hys handis hye
Immortal god quod he / that mayst not dyen
Cupido I meane / of thys mayst gloryfye
And Venus thou mayst / make melodye
Wythouten hand / me semyth that in towne
For thys myracle / I here eche belle sowne
But ho nomore as nowe / of thys matere
For why thys folk / wyl come vp anone
That haue the letter red / o I hem here
But I adiourne the / Criseyde anon
And the Troylus / that whan thou mayst gon
That at myn hous / ye be at my warnyng
For I ful wel / shal shape your comyng
And easith there your hertis / right ynowgh
And lete see whyche of yow / shal here the belle
To speke of loue / a lytel therwyth he lowgh
For there haue ye / a lyser for to telle
Quod Troylus / how long shal it dwelle
Or thys be do quod he / whan thou mayst ryse
Thys thyng shal be / right as I deuyse
Wyth that Heleyne / and eke Deiphebus
Than comen vpward / at the stayre ende
And lord so to grone / tho gan Troylus
Hys brothyr and hys sustir / for to blende
Quod Pandarus tyme is that we wende
Take neece myn / yowre leeue at al thre
And lete hem speke / and come forth wyth me
She toke hyr leue / at hem ful honestly
As she wele cowd / and hyr reuerence
Vnto the ful / they dyden hardyly
And wonder wel spack / in hyr absence
Of hyr in praysyng / of hyr excellence
Hyr gouernaunce hyr wyt / and hyr manere
Commendyng it / that Ioy it was to here
Now lete hyr wende / to hyr owne place
And torne we / to Troylus ageyn
That gan ful lyghtly / of the letter pace
That Deiphe • us / had in the gardyn seyn
And of Heleyne and hym he wold feyn
Delyuered be and sayd that hym lest
To slepe and after talis to haue rest
Heleyne hym kyst and toke / hyr leue blyue
Deiph • bus eke / and home went euery wyght
And pandarus / as faste as he may dryue
To Troylus come / tho as blyue right
And on a paylet / al that glad nyght
By Troylus he lay / wyth blysful chere
To talke and wel was hem / they were in fere
Whan euery wyght was voyded / but they two
And alle the doores / were fast y shet
To tel in short / wythouten wordis mo
Thys Pandarus / wythout ony let
Vp ros and vpon hys beddis syde / hym set
And gan to speke / in a sobre wyse
To Troylus / as I shal yow now deuyse
Myn alther best lord / and brother dere
God wold and thou / that it sat me so sore
Whan I the sawe / so languysshyng to yeere
For loue of whyche / the woo wax euermore
That I wyth alle my myght / and my lore
Haue euer sith / do my besynesse
To bryng the to Ioy / out of dystresse
And haue it brought / to such plyte as yu wost
So that thurgh me / thou stondyst now in wey
To fare wele / I sey it for no lost
And wost thou why / for shame it is to sey
For the haue I begonne / a game to pley
Whyche that I neuer do shal / eft for other
Al though he were / a thousand fold my brother
That is to seye / for the am I becomen
Betwyx game and ernest / suche a meane
As maken wymmen / vnto men comen
Thou wost thy self / what that I wold meane
For the haue I / my neece of vyces cleene
So fully made thy gentylesse to tryst
That al shal be / ryght as thy self lyst
But god that al wote / take I to wytnesse
That I neuer thys / for couetyse wrought
But only to abredge / thy dystresse
For which wel nygh / yu deydest as me thought
But goode brother / do now as the ought
For goodis loue / and kepe here out of blame
So as thou art wyse / kepe hyr out of shame
For wel thow woste the name is yit of hyr
Among the people / as who sey halowyd is
For neuer was yit wyght / I dare wel swere
That euer wyst / she dyd amys
But wo is me / that I that cause alle thys
May thynk / that she is my neece dere
And I hyr Eame / and traytour both I fere
And were it wyst / that I thurgh myn engyne
Had in my nece / put thys fantasye
To do thy lust / and holy to be thyne
Why alle the people / wold vpon it cry
And sey that I / the worst trechery
Dyde in thys cas / that euer was bygonne
And she fordone / & thou right nought y wonne
Wherfor er I wyl further go a paas
The I pray eft / though thou shuldest dey
That pryuyte / go wyth vs in thys caas
That is to sey / thou neuer vs bewrey
And be not wroth / though I the oft prey
To hold secre / suche an hygh matere
For skylful is / thou wost wel my prayere
Thynk what woo / there hath betyd or thys
For makyng of auauntis / as men rede
And what myschaunce / yit in thys world is
Fro day to day / ryght for that wykked dede
For whyche thyse wyse clerkis / that ben dede
Haue wryte or thys / as yit men teche vs yonge
The fyrst vertu is / to kepe the tong
And ner it that / I wold as now abredge
Dyffusion of speche / I cowde almost
A thousand old storyes the aledge
Of wymmen thurgh fals / and foolis bost
Prouerbis canst thy self / ynow and wost
Ageyn that vyce / for to be a lable
Though men soth sey / as often as they gabbe
For tong alas / so oft here byforn
Hath made ful many a lady / bryght of fewe
Sey welawey the day / that she was born
And many a mayden / sorowe for to newe
And for the more parte / al is vntrewe
That men of yelp / & it were brought to preue
By reason none auauntour / is to leue
A vauntour and a lyer / al is one
As thus I suppose / a womman louyth me
And sayth certeyn / that other wyl she none
And I am sworn / to hold it secre
And after I go / and tel it two or thre
Y wys I am a vauntour / at the lest
And a lyer / in brekyng of my behest
Suche maner folk / what shal I clepe hem what
And looke that I be right nought to blame
That hem auaūt of wymmen / & sey she is that
That neuer yit / in ernest nor in game
Knewe hyr nomore / than the deuyls dame
No wonder is / so god me send hele
Though wymmen drede / wyth vs men to • ele
I sey not thys / for no mystrust of yow
Ne for no wyse man / but for foolis nyce
And for the harm / that in the world is now
As wele for foly vsed / as for malyce
For wele I wote / that wyse folk that vyce
No womman dredyth / yf she be wele auysed
For wyse folk ben / by foolis harmes chastysed
But now to purpos / lyef brother dere
Haue al thys thyng / that I haue sayd in mynd
And kepe the clos / and be now of good chere
For at thy day / thou shalt me trewe fynd
I shal thy processe / sette in suche a kynd
And god tofore / that it shal the suffyse
For it shal be ryght / as thou wyl it deuyse
For wel I wote / thou meanest wel parde
Therfore I dare thys fully vndyrtake
Thou wost eke / what thy lady grauntid the
And day is sette / the charters vp to make
Haue now good nyght / I may no lenger wake
And byd for me / sith thou art nowe in blisse
That god the sende deth / or soone lisse
Who myght tel / half the Ioye or feest
Whyche that the sowle / of Troylus tho felt
Heryng theffect / of Pandarus behest
Hys old woo / that made hys hert swelt
Gan tho for Ioye / to wasten and to melt
And al the thoughtis / of hys sighes sore
Attones fled / he felt of theym nomore
But ryght as thyse holtis / and these hayes
That haue ben in wynter / deed and dryen
Reuesten hem in grene / whan that may is
Whan euery lusty / lysti • h for to pleyen
Ryght in that self wyse / soth for to seyen
Wax sodaynly hys hert / ful of Ioye
That gladder was ther neuer man in Troye
And gan hys looke / on Pandarus vp cast
Ful soberly / and frendly vnto see
And sayd frende in Apryl the last
Wel thou wost / yf it remembre the
Wel nygh the deth / for woo thou fond me
And how thow dydest / all thy besynesse
To knowe of me / the cause of my dystresse
Thou wost how long / I forbare to seye
To the that art the man / that I best tryst
And perille none was it / to the bewreye
That wyst I wel / but telle me yf the lyst
Syth I so both was / that thy felt it wyst
How durst I mo telle / of thys matere
That qwake now / and noman may vs here
But natheles by that god / I the swete
That as hym lyse / may al thys world gouerne
And yf I lye / A chylles wyth a spete
My hert cleue / al were my lyf a terne
As I am mortal / yf I late or yerne
Wold it bewrey / it shewe or conne
For al the good / that god made vndyr the sonne
But rather wold I dey / and determyne
As thynketh me now / stokked in pryson
In wretchydnesse in fylth / and vermyne
Captyf to cruel kyng A gamenon
And thys in al the templis / of the towne
Vpon the goddis al / wyl I the swere
To morow day / yf it likyth the to bere
And that thou hast / somoche y do for me
That I ne may / it neuermore deserue
Thys know I wel / al myght I now for the
A thousand tymes / in a morow sterue
I can nomore / but that I wyl the serue
Ryght as thy slaue / whyder so thow wende
For euermore vnto my lyues ende
But here wyth al myn hert / I the beseche
That neuer in me / thou deme suche foly
As I shal sey / me thought by thy speche
That thys that thou hast / me for company
Do / I shuld deme it a bawdry
I am not wood / al yf I lewd be
It is not bawdry / that wote I wel parde
But he that goth / for gold or for rynges
On suche message / calle hem what the lest
But thys that thou doest / for gentylnesse
Compassion felawshyp and trust
Departe it so / for wyde where is wyst
How that ther is / dyuersite requyred
Betwyx thynges / lyke as I haue lerid
And that thou knowe / I thynk not ne weene
That thys seruyse / a shame be or a Iape
I haue my fayr sustyr / Polixene
Cassandre Heleyne / or ony of the frape
Be she neuer so fayre / ne so wel y shape
Tel me whyche thou wylt / of euerichon
To haue for thyn / and lete me than alone
But sith thou hast do me thys seruyse
My lyf to saue / and for no hope of mede
So for the loue ofgod / thys grete empryse
Perfourme it ou • / for now is most neede
For hye or lowe / wythout ony drede
I wyl alwey / thy hestis al kepe
Haue now good nyght / and late vs both slepe
Thus held hem eche of other / wel apayed
That al the world ne myght it amende
And on the morow / whan they were arayed
Eche to hys owne neede / gan entende
But Troylus thought / as the fyre he brende
For sharp desire / of hope and of plesaunce
He not forgate / hys wyse gouernaunce
But in hym self wyth manhod gan restreyne
Eche recheles dede / and eche brydeld chere
That al tho that lyuen / soth to seyne
Ne shuld haue wyst / by word ne manere
What that he ment / as touchyng thys matere
From euery wyght / as fer as the clowde
He was so wyse / and dyssimylen he cowde
And al thys whyle / whyche I yow deuyse
Thys was hys lyf wyth hys ful myght
By day he was / in Martis hygh seruyse
That is to say / in armes as a knyght
And for the most part / the long nyght
He lay and thought / how that he mygt serue
Hys lady • est / hyr thank for to deserue
For why she fond hym / so dyseret in al
So secrete / and of suche obeysaunce
That wel she felt / he was to hyr a wal
Of styele a sheld / from euery dysplesaunce
That to be / in hys good gouernaunce
So wyse he was / she was nomore aferd
I meane as fer / as ought to be requyred
And Pandarus / to qwykene alwey the fyre
Was euer lyke / prest and dylygent
To ease hys frend / was set alle hys desire
He shof ay on / he to and fro was sent
He lettris bere / whan Troylus was absent
That neuer wyght wyst / as in hys frendis nede
Ne bare hym bet / to do hys frend to spede
But nowe perauenture / som̄e men wayte wold
That euery word or looke / sond or chere
Of Troylus / that I reherse shold
In al thys whyle / vnto hys lady dere
I trow it were / a long thyng to here
Or of ony wyght / that stant in suche dysioynt
Hys wordis all / or euery looke to poynt
Forsoth I haue not herd / it done or thys
In story none / ne noman here I wene
And though I wold / I cowd not ywys
For ther was som̄e epystyl / sent betwene
That wold as seyth my auctour / wele contene
An hundryd verse / of which hym lyst not wryte
How shuld I than / a lyne of it endyte
But to the grete effecte / that I sey thus
That stondyng in concord and quyete
Thyse ylke two / Criseyde and Troylus
As I haue sayd / in thys tyme swete
Saue only that / oft tyme they myght not mete
Ne leysir had / her spechis to fulfylle
It befel ryght / as I shal yow telle
That pandarus / which yt alway dide his myght
Ryght for the fyne that I speke of here
As for to bryng to hys hous som̄e nyght
Hys fayre neece / and Troylus y feere
Ther as at leyser / al thys hye matere
Touchyng theyr loue / were at the ful vp bound
Had as hym thought / a iyme therto y found
For he wyth grete delyberacion
Had euery thyng / that therto myght auayle
Forn cast / and put in execucion
And nothyr left for cost / ne for trauayle
That none of hem shuld in nothyng fayle
And for to be not espyed there
He thought wele / an impossible were
And dredles / it clere was in the wynd
Of euery pye / and euery let game
Thus al is wel / and al thys world is blynd
In thys matere bothe wyld and tame
Thys tymber is redy for to put in frame
Vs lackyth not / but that we wyten wold
A certeyn houre / in whyche she comyn shold
And Troylus that at hys puruyaunce
Knew at the ful / and wayted on it ay
Had here vpon eke made / hys ordynaunce
And fond hys cause / and eke all the aray
That yf that he were myssed / nyght or day
The whyle he was aboute thys seruyse
That he was go / to do hys sacryfyce
And must at suche a temple / all ne wake
And worshyp Appolo / ther wold he be
And first to see / the holy lau • er quake
Or that Appollo / spack out of the tre
To tel hym whan / the Grekis shuld fle
And for thy let hym noman / god forbede
But pray Appollo / that he wold hym spede
Now is there lytyl more / for to done
But Pondare vp / and shortly to seyne
Ryght vpon the chaungyng / of the mone
Whan lightles is the world / a nyght or tweyne
And that the welkyn / sho • pe hym for to reyne
He streyght a morow / vnto hys neece went
Ye ha • e wel herd / the fyne of hys entent
Whan he was there / he gan anon to pleye
As he was wont / and at hym self to Iape
And fynally he swore / and gan hyr seye
Both thys and that / she shuld hym not escape
Ne make hym lenger / aftyr hyr to gape
But certaynly / she must by hyr leue
Come soupe wyth hym / at hys house at eue
At whyche she lough / and gan hyr self excusen
And sayd it reyneth / lo how shuld I gon
Lat be qd he my frēd / ne seond not thus & musen
Thys mote be doon / ye shul be there anon
So at the last / krof they fyl at on
And ellis soft he swore hyr in hyr erre
He wold neuer come / there as she were
And she ageyn / gan hym for to rowne
And asked hym / yf Troylus were there
He swore hyr nay / for he was out of towne
And sayd neece / I pose that he were there
Ye durst neuer haue / the more fere
For rather than men / shuld hym espye
Me were leuer / a thousand fold to dye
Nat lyst myn Auctour / fully to declaryn
What that she thought / whan he sayd so
That Troylus was / out of towne y faryn
As yf he sayd / soth therof or no
But that she grauntyd / wyth hym for to go
Wythout nayeng / sith he her besought
And as hys neece / obeyed as hyr ought
But natheles than / gan she hym beseche
Al though wyth hym to go / was no fere
For to be ware / of gostly peoples speche
That dremen thynges / whyche that neuer were
And wele auyse hym / whom he brought there
And sayd Eame / sith I must yow tryst
Looke al be wel / for I do as yow lyst
He swore hyr tho / by stokkes and by stones
And by the goddis / that in heuene dwelle
Or ellis were hym leuer / fell and bones
Wyth Pluto kyng / as depe be in helle
As Cantalus / what shuld I lenger dwelle
Whan al was wel / he roos and toke hys leue
And she to sonper come / whan it was eue
Wyth a certeyn / of hyr owne men
And wyth hyr fayre neece Antigone
And other of hyr wymmen / nyne or ten
But who was glad / who as trowe ye
But Troylus that stood / and myght it see
Thurgh a lytel wyndow / in a stewe
Ther he shet was / sith mydnyght in a mewe
Vnwyst of euery wyght / but of Pandare
But now to purpos / whan that she was come
Wyth alle Ioye / and al frendis fare
Hyr Eame anone / in armes hath hyr nome
And after to the sowper / al and som̄e
Whan tyme was to sowper they be fette
God wote ther was no deynte / for to sette
And after sowper / gan they to ryse
At ease wel / wyth hertis fressh and glade
And wel was hym / that cowd best deuyse
To lyken hyr / or to lawghen her made
He song she pleyde / he told a tale of wade
But at the last / as euery thyng hath ende
She toke hyr leue / & nedis wold home wende
But o fortune / executiyce of wyerdis
O influence / of the se heuenes hye
Sooth is that vndyr god / ye ben oure hyerdis
Though to vs / ben the causes w • ye
Thys meane I now / for she gan homward hye
But execut • d was al / besyde hyr leue
The goddis wyl / for whyche she must bleue
The bent moone / wyth her hornes pale
Saturne and Iuno in Cancro Ioyned were
That suche a rayne / from heuene gan aua ••
That euery man and womman that was there
Had of the smoky rayne / a very fere
And Pandare lough tho / and seyd thenne
Now it were tyme / a lady go henne
But now good nece / yf I myght euer please
Yow ony thyng / than pray I yow quod he
To do myn hert / as now so grete an ease
As for to dwelle here / thys nyght wyth me
For neece thys is yowre owne hous parde
Now be myry I sey / it is now no game
To wende now home / it were to me a shame
Criseyde whyche that cowde / qs moche goode
As half a world tooke heede of hys prayer
And sawe it rayned / and al was on a floode
She thought as good chepe may I dwelle here
And graunt it gladly / wyth a frendly chere
And haue a thanke / than grutche & than abyde
For home to gone / it wyl not wel betyde
I wyl quod she myn vncle lyef and dere
Syth that yow lyst / it skyl is to be so
I am ryght glad / wyth yow to dwellen here
I sayd but a game / that I wold go
Ywys graunt mercy / neece quod he tho
Were it a game / or sooth for to telle
I am now glad / syth that ye lyst dwelle
Thus al is wel / but tho bygan a ryght
The newe Ioye / and al the fest ageyn
But Pandarus / yf goodely had he myght
He wold haue hyed hyr / to bed ful fayn
And sayd lord / thys is a huge rayn
Thys were a wedyr / for to slepen ynne
And that I rede vs / soue to bygynne
And neece woote ye / wher I shal you ley
For that we shul not / lygge fer a sonder
And for ye shul neyther / dare I seye
Here noyse of reyne / ne of thonder
By god right in my lytel closet yonder
And I wil in that lytel house alone
By wardeyn / of your wymmen euerychone
And in thys myddyl chambre that ye see
Shuln al your wymmen / sleepen fayre & soft
And al wythin / shal yowre self be
And yf ye lygge wel to nyght / come more oft
And carith not for the wedir / though it be aloft
The wyne was brought / & whan so that you lest
Than is it tyme / for to go to rest
Ther was nomore / but therafter soone
They voyde drank / and trauers drawe anon
Gan euery wyght / that had nought to done
More in the place / out of the chambre gone
And alway in thys meane whyle it rone
And blew therwyth / so wondyrly lowde
That wel nye / noman other here cowde
Tho Pandarus / ryght as hym ought
Wyth wymmen syche / as were hyr nyh aboute
Ful glad vnto hyr beddis side hyr brought
And toke theyr leue / and gan ful lowe loute
And sayde at thys closet doore / wythoute
Ryght ouerthwert / your wymmen lyggen alle
That whom ye lyst of hem / ye may soone calle
So whan she was in the closet leyde
And al hyr wymmen forth by ordynaunce
A bed were they / as I haue yow seyde
Thys was nomore / to skippe ne to traunce
But bodyn go to bed / wyth myschaunce
Yf ony man was stiryng / ony where
And lete theym sleepe / that a bed were
But Pandarus / that wele cowde eche a dele
The old daunce / and euery poynt therin
Whan that he saw / that al thynge was wele
He thought he wold / vpon hys werk begynne
And gan the styewe doore / alsoft vnpynne
And styl as stone / wythout lenger lette
By Troylus adoun / he by hym sette
And shortly to the poynt now for to gon
Of al thys thyng / he told hym word & end
And sayd make the redy / ryght anon
For thow shalt in to heuene blys wend
Now seynt venus / thou me grace send
Quod Troylus / for neuer yit no neede
Had I or now / ne halfuendel the dreede
Quod Pandarus / ne drede the neuer a dele
For it shal be ryght / as thou wylt desyre
So thryue I thys nyght / I shal make it wele
Or cast all the growel / in the fyre
That blysful venus / thys nyght me enspyre
Quod Troylus as wys / as I the serue
And euer bet and bet / shal tyl I sterue
And yf I had o Venus ful of myrth
Aspectis bad of Mars or of Saturne
Or thurgh combust / or let were in my byrth
Thy fadyr pray / al thylk harme dystorne
Of grace / and that I glad ageyn may torne
For loue of hym / thow louedyst in the shawe
I meane Adeon / that wyth the bore was slawe
O Ioue eke / for the loue of the fayre Europe
The whyche in fourme of a boole / awey the fet
Now help and Mars wyth thy bloody Cope
For loue of Cipac / thou me not ne let
O Phebus thynk / whan Diane hyr self shet
Vndyr the bark / and ran awey for drede
Yit for hyr loue / now help at thys neede
Mercurie for the loue / of hyr eeke
For which Pallas / was with Aglaurus wroth
Now help / Diane and eke I the beseke
That thys vyage / be not to the loth
O fatal sustren / whyche or ony cloth
Me shapen was / my destyne me sponne
So help to thys werk that is here bygonne
Quod Pandarus / thou wretchyd mouses hert
Art thou agast / so that the wyl the byte
Why do on thys furryd cloke / vpon thy shert
And folowe me for I wyl haue the wyte
But byde and late me go / a fore a lyte
And wyth that word / he gan vndo the trappe
And Troylus he brought in by the lappe
The sterne wynde / so lowde gand to rowte
That no wyght others noyse / myght here
And they that lay / at the dore wythoute
Ful sikyrly they slept / al in feere
And Pandarus wyth a ful sobre chere
Goth to the doore anon / wythout let
Ther as they lay / and softly it shet
And as he come ageynward / ful pryuely
Hys neece a wooke / and asked who is there
My dere neece quod he / it am I
Ne wondryth not / ne haue of it no fere
And nere he come / and sayd hyr in hyr 〈◊〉
No word for the loue of god I yow beseche
Late no wyght aryse / and here of oure speche
What whyche wey ben ye come bene diate
Quod she and how / •• us vnwys • of hem asse

Here at thys lytel trap doore / quod
• e
Quod tho Creseyde / late me som̄e wyght calle
O god forbede that it shold befalle
Quod Pandarus / that ye suche folye wrought
They myght deme / that they neuer er thought
It is not good a sleepyng hound to wake
Ne yeue a wyght / a cause to dyuyne
Yowre wymmen sleepe / all I vndyrtake
So that for theym / the heus men myght myne
And sleepe wol / that tyl the sonne shyne
And whan my tale brought is to an ende
Vnwyse right as I come / so wyl I wende
Now neece myn / ye shul wel vndyrstond
Quod he so as ye wymmen / do men alle
That for to hold a man / long in hond
And hym hyr lyef / and dere hert calle
And make hym an •• e / aboue a calle
I meane as loue another / in the meane whyle
Se doeth hyr self a shame / and hym a guyle
Now wherby that I telle yow / al thys
Ye wote your self as wel as ony wyght
How that yowre loue / al fully grauntyd is
To Troylus the worthyest knyght
One of thys world / and therto trowth ye plight
That but it were on hym a long / ye nold
Hym neuer falsen / whyle ye lyue shold
Now stant it thus / sith I fro yow went
Thys Troylus platly / for to seyn
Is thurgh a gutter by a preuy went
In to my chambre come / in al thys reyne
Vnwyst of ony maner wyght certeyn
Sauf of my self / as wysly haue I Ioye
And by the feyth / I owe Priam of Troye
And he is come / in suche peyne and dystresse
I trowe he be / al fully wood by thys
He sodaynly mote falle / in to woodenesse
But god help / and why the cause is thys
He seyth hym told is / of a frend of hys
How that ye shuld loue / one horast
For sorow of whiche / this nyght wil be his last
Criseyde / whyche that al thys wonder herd
Gan therwyth / aboute hyr hert cold
And wyth a sygh / she sodaynly answerd
Alas I wend / who so talis told
My dere hert / wold me not hold
So lightly fals / alas conceytis wrong
What harm they do / for now I lyue to long
Horast alas / and falsen Troylus
I know hym not / god me help so quod she
Alas what wycked spyryte / told hym thus
Now certis Eame / to morow and I hym see
I shal of that as fully excusen me
As euer dyd womman yf that hym lyke
And wyth that word / she gan for to syke
O god quod she / so worldly selynesse
Whyche clerkis calle / fals felycite
Y medlyd is / wyth many a bytternesse
Ful anguysshous / that is god wote quod she
Condicion / of veyne prosperite
For eyther Ioyes / come not ay in feere
Or ellis no wyght / hath hem alwey here
O brutyl wele / of worldly Ioye vnstable
Wyth what wyght / so that thou be or pleye
Eyther he wote that / thou art Ioye mutable
Or wote it not / it mote be one of tweye
Now yf he wote it not / how may he seye
That he hath veray Ioye / and selynesse
That is of ignoraunce / ay in derknesse
Now yf be wote / that Ioye is transiterye
As euery Ioye / of worldly thyng mote fle
Now eueryc • e / that hath in memorye
The drede of lesyng / makyth hym that he
May in no porfit / sikernesse be
And yf to leese hys Ioye / be sette amyte
Than semyth that Ioye / is wo • th but lyte
Wherfor I wyl dyffyne / in thys manere
That trewly for ought / I can espye
Ther is no veray wele / in thys world here
But o thou wycked / serpent Ialowsye
Thou mysbeleued / enuyous folye
Why hast thou made Troylus / me vntryst
That neuer yit agylted hym / that I wyst
Quod pandarus / thus fallen is thys cas
Why vncle myn quod she / ho told hym thys
Why doeth myn dere hert / thus alas
Ye wote ye neyce myn / quod he what is
I hope al shal be wele / that is amys
For ye may qwenche al thys / yf ye lest
And doth right so / I hold it for the best
So shal I do to morowe / ywys quod she
And god toforn / so that it shal suffise
To morow alas / that were fayre quod he
Nay nay it may not stande in thys wyse
For neece myn / thus wryten clerkis wyse
That peryl is / wyth dretchyng in y drawe
Nay suche abodis / ben not worth an hawe
Neece al thyng hath tyme / I dare a vowe
For whan a chamber a fyre is / or an halle
Wel more myster is / it sodaynly rescowe
Than to dyspute / and aske among hem alle
How thys candel / in the strawe dyde falle
A benedicite / for al that long fare
The harm is do / and fare wel feld fare
And neece myn / ne take it not a gryef
Yf that ye suffre hym / al nyght in thys woo
God help me soo / ye had hym neuer lyef
That dare I sey / now ther is but we two
But wel I wote / ye wyl not do so
Ye be to wyse / to do so grete folye
To put hys lyf / al nyght in Ieopardye
Had ye hym neuer lyef / by god I weene
I had neuer thyng so lyef / by god quod she
Now by my trowth quod he / that shal be seene
For sith ye make thys ensample / of me
Yf I al nyght / wold hym in sorow see
For al the tresour / in the towne of Troye
I byd god / neuer more haue I Ioye
Now lokyth than / yf that ye be hys loue
To put al nyght hys lyf in Ieopardye
For thyng of nought / now by that lord aboue
Not only thys delay / comyth of folye
But of malyce / yf I shal not lye •
What platly / and ye see hym in dystresse
Neyther ye wysely don / ne gentylnesse
Quod tho Criseyde / wyl ye do o thyng
And ye therwyth / shul s • ynt hys dyscase
Haue here and bare hym / thys blew ryng
For ther is nothyng / may hym bettyr please
Saue I my self / ne more hys hert ease
And sey my dere hert / that hys sorow
Is causeles / and that he shal see to morow
A ryng quod he / ye hasilwoode is shaken
Ye neece myn that ryng / must haue a stone
That myght ded men / alyue maken
And such a ryng trowe I / that ye haue none
Discrecion out of your heed is gone
That fele I now quod he / and that is rowth
O tyme y lost wel mayst thou curs slowth
Wote ye not wele / that noble and hye corage
Ne sorowyth not / ne styntyth not for lyte
But yf a foole / were in a Ialous rage
I nold sette at his sorow a myte
But feffe hym / wyth a fewe wordis whyte
Another day whan I myght hym fynde
But thys thyng stant al / in another kynde
He is so gentyl / and so tendre of hert
That wyth hys deth / he wyl hys sorow wreke
For trustyth wel / how sore that hym smert
He wyl to yow / no Ialous word speke
And for thy neece / or that hys hert breke
So speke yowre self / to hym of thys matere
For wyth oo word / ye may hys hert stere
Now haue I told / what peryl he is ynne
And hys comyng vnwyst of euery wyght
And parde harme may ther be / none ne synne
I wyl my self be wyth yow al thys nyght
Ye / know wel eke / he is your owne knyght
And that by right / ye must vpon hym tryst
And I al prest to fetche / hym whan ye lyst
Thys accydent / so pytous was to here
And eke so lyke a soth / at pryme face
And Troylus hyr knyght / to hyr so dere
Hys pryuy comyng / and the siker place
That though she dyd hym / as than a grace
Considred al thynges / as they stoode
No wonder is sith / she dyd al for goode
Criseyde answerd / as wysly god at rest
My soule bryng / as me is for hym wo
And Eame ywys fayne wold I do the best
If that I had grace / to do so
But whethyr that ye dwelle / of for hym go
I am tyl god / me bettyr mynd sende
At Dulcarnon / at my wyttes ende
Quod Pandarus / ye neece wyl ye here
Dulcarnon is callid flemyng of wretchis
It semyth hard for wretchis wyl not here
For veray slowth / and other wylful tetchis
Thys seyd he by hem / yt be not worth two fetchis
But ye be wyse / & haue this matere in hande
Nys nother hard / ne skylful to withstonde
Than Eame quod she / doeth herof as ye lyst
But or he come / I wyl fyrst aryse
And for the loue of god / sith al my tryst
Is on yow two / and ye both wyse
So wyrkyth now / in so dyscrete a wyse
That I honour may haue / and he plesaunce
For I am here now / in your gouernaunce
Thys is wel sayd quod he / my nece dere
Good thryft came on that / wyse gentyl hert
But liggyth styll / and takith hym ryght here
It nedyth not / no further for hym stert
And eche of yow / ease other sorowes smert
For soone hope I / we shul all be mery
For loue of god / and venus I the hery
Thys Troylus ful soone / on knees hym sette
Ful sobyrly ryght by hyr beddis hede
And in hys best wyse / hys lady grette
But lord so she was / sodaynly rede
Ne though men shuld / smyte of hyr hede
She myght not o word / a ryght out bryng
So sodaynly for hys soo • e comyng
But Pandarus / that so wele cowd fele
In euery thyng to pleye / anone bygan
And sayd neece / see how thys lord can knele
Now for your trowth / see thys gentylman
And wyth that word he for a qwysshon ran
And sayd now knelyth / whyle that yow lyst
That god yowre hertis / bryng soone at rest
Can I not seyn / for she had hym not ryse
If sorow it put / out of remembraunce
Or ellie that she tooke it / • n thys wyse
Of dyew • e / as for hy • obeysaunce
But wele I rede / she dyd hym thys plesaunce
That she hym kyst • al though he sighed sore
And bud hym 〈◊〉 a d • un / wythout • n mor •
Quod Pandarus now wyl ye wele bygynne
Now doth hym 〈◊〉 / goode neece 〈◊〉
Vpon yowre beddis s • de / al wythynne
That eche of yow the • et • ay other here
And wyth that word he drewe hym to the fyre
And toke a lyght / & feyned hys contenaunce
As for to looke • vpon an old romaunce
Criseyde that was / Troylus lady ryght
And clere stood / on a grounde of sikernesse
Al though she hyr seruaunt / and hyr knyght
He shuld of ryght / none vntrowth in hyr gesse
Yit natheles / considered hys dystresse
And that loue to / in cause of suche folye
Thus to hym sp • ck she / of hys Ialousye
Lo hert myn / as wold the excellence
Of loue / ageynst the whyche • oman may
Ne ought eke goodely / make resistence
And eke by cause / I felt wel and saye
Yowre grete trowth / and seruyce euery daye
And yt yowre hert al myn was / sooth to seyne
Thys droue me / to rewe vpon your peyne
And your goodnesse haue I found alwey yit
Of whyche my dere hert / and my knyght
I thank it yow / as fer as I haue wyt
Al can I not / as moche as it were ryght
And I hensforth my connyng / and my myght
Haue and ay shal / how sore that me smert
Be to yow trewe / and hole wyth al myn hert
And dredeles that shal be found at preue
But hert myn / what al thys is to sayne
Shal wel be told / so that ye yow not greue
Though I to yow right / on yowre self cōpleyne
For therwyth mene I / fynally the peyne
That holt your hert / and myn in heuynesse
Fully to slene / and euery wrong redresse
My good hert not I / for why ne how
That Ialowsye alas / that wyckid wyuere
So causeles is cropen / in to yow
The harm of whyche / I wold fayne delyuere
Alas that ye al hool / or of hym a shyuere
Shuld haue hys refute / in so dygne a place
That Ioue out soone / out of your hert hym race
But o thou Ioue / auctour of nature
Is thys an hononr / vnto thy deyte
That folk vngylty / suffre here Iniure
And he that gylty is / vnquyt goth he
O were it leeful / for to pleyne / on the
That vndeserued / suffrist Ialowsye
Of that I wold / vpon the pleyne and crye
Eke al my woo is thys / that men now vsen
To seye ryght thus / that Ialowsye is loue
And wold a busshel of venym all excusen
For that one greyn of loue / is in shoue
But that wote the hye god / that sit aboue
Yf it be syker loue / hate or grame
And after that / it ought to bere hys name
But certeyn is / som̄e maner Ialowsye
Is excusable / more than som̄e ywys
As whan cause / and som̄e suche fantasye
Wyth pyte so wel / repressid is
That it vnneth doeth / or sayth amys
But goodely drynkyth vp / all hys dystresse
And that excuse I / for the gentylnesse
And som̄e so ful / of furye and dyspyte
That it surmountyth / hys repressioun
But hert myn / ye be not in thys plyte
That thank I god / for whyche your passioun
I wyl not calle it but an Illusioun
Of habundaunce of loue / and besy cure
That doeth your hert / thys dysease endure
Of whyche I am ryght sory / but not wroth
But for my desire / and your hertis rest
Whether so yow lyst / by ordal or by oth
By sort or be what wyse / so that yow lest
For loue of god / late preue it for the best
And yf that I be gylty do me deye
Alas what myght I more / done or seye
Wyth that a fewe / bryght teeris newe
Out of hyr eyen fyl / and thus she seyde
Now god thou wost / in thought ne dede vntrewe
To Troylus was neuer yit Criseyde
Wyth that hyr hond / doun in the bed she leyde
And wyth the shete it wryed / and sighed sore
And held hyr pees / not a word spack she more
But now help god / to qwenche al thys sorow
So hope I that he shal / for he best may
For I haue seen / a ful mysty morow
Folowe ful oft / a myry somer day
And after wynter foloweth grene may
Men seen alday / and rede eke in storyes
That after sharp showres / ben vyctoryes
Thys Troylus / whan he hyr wordis herd
Haue ye no care / hym lyst not to slepe
For it thought hym / no strokes of a yerd
To here or see / Criseyde hys lady wepe
But wele he felt / aboute hys hert crepe
For euery teere / whyche that Criseyde as • ert
The cramp of doth / streyneth hym by the hert
And in hys mynd / he gan the tyme acurse
That he came there / or that he was bore
For now is wycke / tornyd in to worse
And al the labour / he hath do byfore
He thought it lost / he wend he nas but lore
O Pandarus alas thought he / thy wyle
Seruyth of nought / so welawey the whyle
And ther wythal / he hyng a doun the heed
And fyl on knees / and sorowfully he sight
What myght he say / he felt he nas but deed
For wroth was she / yt shuld his sorowes lyght
But natheles whan he speke myght
Than said he thus / god wote that of this grame
Whan al is wyst / than am I not to blame
Therwyth the sorow / of hys hert shette
That from hys eyen / fyl ther n • t a teere
And euery spyryte / hys vygour in knette
So they astonyed / and oppressed were
The feelyng of hys sorow / and of hys chere
Or of ought ellis / fled was oute of towne
A doun he fyl all sodaynly / in a swowne
Thys was no lytel / sorow for to see
For al was huysht / but Pandare vp at the last
O neece peas / or we be bost quod he
Be not agast / but alwey at the last
For thys or that / he hym in to the bed cast
And sayd thyef / is thys a mannes hert
And of he rent / al to hys bare shert
And sayd neece / but ye help vs now
Ywys your owne / Troylus is born
Alas so wold I / and I wyst how
Ful fayne quod she / alas that I was born
Ye ne •• wyl ye pul out the thorn
That scikyth in hys hert / quod Pandare
Sey al foryeue / and stynt all thys care
Ye that to me quod she / leuer were
Than al the goode / the senne aboute goth
And therwythal she swore hym in hys cere
Y wys my dere hert / I am not wroth
Haue here my trowth and many another oth
Now speke to me / for it am I Creseyde
But al for nought / yit myght he not abreyde
Tho Troylus / gan sorowfully to syke
Lest she were / wroth hym thought his hert deyde
And sayde alas / vpon my sorowes syke
Haue mercy on me / swete hert myn Criseyde
And yf that in the wordis / that I feyde
Be ony wrong I wyl nomore crespace
Doth as yow lyst / I put me in youre grace
Criseyde answerd of gylt myseryoord
That is for to sey / I foryeue al thys
And euermore on thys nyght record
And beth wel ware / ye do nomore amys
Nay dere hert myn / quod he ywys
And now quod she / that I haue do yow smert
Foryeue it me / myn owne swete hert
Tho Troylus wyth bus / of that supprysed
Put all in goddis hond / as he that ment
Nothyng but wel / and sodaynly auysed
He hyr in armes / fast to hym hent
And Pandarus / wyth ful goode entent
Layde hym to sleepe / and sayd yf ye be wyse
Swowne not now / lest mo folke aryse
What myght or may / the sely lark sey
Whan that the sperhawke / hath it in hys foote
I can nomore / but of thys ylke twey
To whom thys tale / sugre he or swoote
Though that I tarye a yere / som̄tyme I mote
After myn auctour / tel of theyr gladnesse
As wele as I haue / told theyr heuynesse
Criseyde wyth that / felt hyr thus y take
As wryten clerkis / in theyr bookes old
Ryght as an aspen leef / she gan to quake
Whan she hyr felt / in hys armes fold
And Troylus al hool / of hys cares cold
Gan thankyn tho / the bryght goddis seuene
That sundry peynes / bryngen folk to heuene
Thys Troylus in armes gan hyr streyne
And sayd o swete / as euer mote I gone
Now be ye caught / ther nys but we tweyne
Now yeldyth yow / for other boote is none
To that Criseyde / answerd thus anone
Ne had I er now / my swete hert dere
Be yolden ywys / I were not now here
O sooth is sayde / that helyd for to be
As of a feuer / or another grete sikenesse
Men must drynk alday / as men may see
Ful bytter drynk / and for to haue gladnesse
Men duren of peyne / and grete dystresse
I meane it here / as of thys aduenture
That thurgh a peyne / hath found now hys cure
And now swetnesse / semyth more swete
That bytternesse assayed / was byforn
For out of woo / in blysse now they fleete
None suche they felt / sith that they were born
Now is thys bet / than both two be lorn
For loue of god / take euery womman heede
To worke thus / whan it comyth to neede
Criseyde al quyte / from euery drede and teene
As she that iust cause had hym to tryst
Made hym suche feeste / that Ioye it was to seene
Whan she hys trowth / and clene entent wyst
And as about a tree / wyth many a twyst
By •• ent and wrythe / the soote woodebynde
Gan eche of hem / in armes other wynde
And as the newe / abasshed nyghtyngale
That styntyth fyrst / or she begynne to syng
Whan she heryth / ony hyerdis tale
Or in the hedgis / ony wyght styryng
And after sikernesse / hyr voys doth out ryng
Ryght so Criseyde / whan that hyr drede stent
Opend hyr hert / and told al hyr entent
And ryght as he / that sawe hys deth y shapen
And dye must / in aught that he gan gesse
And sodaynly rescous / doth hym escapen
And from hys deth / is brought in sykernesse
For al thys world / ryght in suche gladnesse
Is Troylus / and hath hys lady swete
Wyth wors hay / god lete vs neuer meete
Hyr armes smale / hyr streyght back and softe
Hyr sides long flesshly smoth and whyte
He gan to stroke / and bad goode thryft ful ofte
Hyr snowysh throte / hyr brestis rounde & lyte
Thus in thys heuene / he gan hym delyte
And therwythal / a thowsand tyme hyr kyst
That for what to do / for Ioye vnneth he wyst
Than seyd he thus / o loue o charyte
Thy moder eeke / Citherea the swete
After thy self / next heryed be she
Venus meane I / the wele wylly planete
And next Ymeneus / I the grete
For neuer man was / to yow goddis hold
As I that ye haue / brought from cares cold
Benygne loue / thou holy bonde of thynges
Who so wyl grace / and lyst not the honoure
Lo hys desire wyl fle / wythout wynges
For thou noldyst of bounte / hem socoure
That seruen best / and alwey most laboure
But yf thy grace / passed our desertis
Al were lost / that I dare sey certis
And for thow me / that cowd best deserue
Of hem that nombred be vnto thy grace
Hast holpen there / I lykly was to sterue
And me bystowed / in so hygh a place
That ilke boundis / may no blis pace
I can nomore / but lawde and reuerence
Be to thy bounte / and thyn excellence
And ther wythal / Criseyde anon he kyst
Of whyche certeyn / she felt no dysease
And thus sayd he / now wold god I wyst
Myn hert swete / how I myght yow please
What man quod he / was euer thus at ease
As I on whom / the fayrest and the best
That euer I say / deyneth hyr hert to rest
Here may men see / that mercy passyth right
Thexperience of thys / is felt in me
That am vnworthy / to yow my lady bryght
But hert myn / of yowre benygnyte
So thynkyth though I vnworthy be
Yit mote neede / amende in som̄e wyse
Ryght thurgh the vertu / of yowre hye seruyse
And for the loue of god my lady dere
Sith god hath wrought me / for you euer to serue
As thus he wyl / that ye be my stere
To do me lyue / yf that ye lyst or sterue
So techyth me how that I may deserue
Yowre thank / so that I thurgh myn Ignoraunce
Ne do nothyng / that do yow dysplesaunce
For certis fressh wommanly wyf
The day is sith / that trowth and dylygence
Ye s •• l in me fynden al my lyf
I nyl certeyn / breke yowre defence
And yf I do / present or in absence
For loue of god / 〈◊〉 slee me wyth the dede
Yf that it lyke / vnto yowre wommanshede
Y wys quod she / myn owne hertis lust
My ground of ca • e / and al myn hert dere
G •• mercy / for on that to al my trust
But lett vs fulle away / from thys matrre
For thys suffysitt •• / whyche that is sayd here

And a •
• o word / wythout repentaunce
Wel come my knight / my 〈◊〉 / my suffysaunce
Of theyr delyte or Ioyce / one the lest
Were in possyble / in my wyt to sey
But Iugyth ye / that han ben at the feest
Of suche gladnesse yf / 〈◊〉 lys • pley
I can nomore / but 〈◊〉 thy • ylke twey
That nyght betwyxt / drede and sikernesse
They felt in loue / the gre •• worthynesse
O blysful nyght / of whom so long I sought
How blyth vnto hem both / thow were
Why ne had I suche one / with my fowle y bought
Ye for the lest Ioye / that was there
Awey thou fowle daunger / and thow fere
And lete hem / in thys heuen blys dwelle
That is so hye that noman can telle
These ylk two / that ben in armes laft
So both to hem / a sundre to gd it were
That eche of hem from other / wend byraft
Or ellis lo thus / was theyr most fere
Lest al thys thyng / but nyce dreames were
For whyche ful oft / eche of theym seyde o swete
Clyppe I yow thus / or ellis do I meete
And lord so he gan / goodely on hyr see
