Ne nen tendement consydere / ne tonge telle
The cruel peynes / of this woful man
That passyn euery torment doun in helle
For when he sawe / she myght not dwelle
Whiche that his sowle / oute of his hert rent
Withoute more / he oute of the chambre went

div.head: And begynneth the Fyfthe

lg.l: aProchen gan ye fatal day of destyne
That Iouis hath in his dysposycyon
And to you angry parcas sustrē thre
Commytted to doo anone execucyon
For whiche Creseyde must oute of the toune
And Troylus shal dwelle / forth in pyne
Tyl lachesys his threde no lenger twyne
The gold tressyd Phebus hye on loft
Shyned had with his beames clere
The snowes molt / & Zephyrus as oft
Y • brought ageyne the lusty leues grene
Syth that the sone of Heccuba the quene
Bygan to loue hyr fyrst / for whome his sorow
Was al / that she depart shold a morow
Ful redy was at pryme Dyomede
Creseyde vnto the grekes hoost to lede
For sorowe / of whiche she felt hyr hert blede
As she that nyst / what was best to rede
And trewely as men in bokes rede
Men wyst neuer woman haue more care
Ne was so loth / oute of a towne to fare
This Troylus withoute rede or lore
As a man that hath his ioyes eke forlore
Was waytyng on his lady euermore
As she / that the sothfast crop & more
Of al his lust / or ioyes here bifore
But Troylus / now fare wele al thy ioys
For shalt thou neuer / see hyr eft in Troys
Sothe is whyle that he bode in this manere
He gan his woo ful manly for to hyde
That wele vnnethe / it seen was in his chere
But at the yate / there she shold oute ryde
With certeyne folk he houyd hyr to byde
So woo bygo / al wold he not compleyne
That on his hors vnnethe he sat for peyne
For Ire he quoke / so gan his hert gnawe
When Dyomede / on hors hym gan dresse
And sayd to hym self this ylk sawe
Alas quod he / thus fowle & wretchydnesse
Why suffre I it / why nyl I it redresse
Were it not bet at ones for to dye
Than euermore in langoure / thus for to drye
Why nyl I make at ones ryche & poure
To haue ynough to doo / or that she go
Why nyl I brynge al Troye in Roure
Why nyl I slee this Dyomede also
Why nyl I rather with a man or two
Stele hyr awey / why wil I thus endure
Why nyl I help / to myn owne cure
But why he nold doo so fel a deede
That shal I sey / & why he lyst to spare
He had in herte alwey a maner drede
Lest that Creseyde in rumour of this fare
Shold haue ben slayn / lo thus was al his care
And elles certeyn / as I saide ore
He had it done withoute wordes more
Creseide when she redy was to ride
Ful sorowfully she sighte / & saide alas
But forth she mote / for ought that may betide
There nys none other remedye in this caas
And forth she rode ful sorowfully a paas
What wonder is / though hir sore smert
When she forgoth / hir owne dere hert
This Troilus in wise of curtesye
With hawke on hond / & with an huge rowte
Of knyghtes rode / & dide hir companye
Passyng alle the valeye ferre withoute
And ferther wold haue ride / oute of doute
Ful fayne / & woo was hym to goo so soone
But ryght with that was Anthenore y gone
But turne he must / & eke it was to done
Oute of the grekes hoost & euery wyght
Was of it glad / & sayd he was welcome
And Troylus nere al his hert lyght
He peyned hym with al his ful myght
Hym to withold of wepyng at the leest
And Anthenore / he kyst & made feest
And here with al / his lady • s leue to take
He cast his eye vppon hyr pytously
And nere he rode / his cause for to make
To take hyr by the hond / al sobyrly
And lord she gan wepe t • ndyrly
And he ful soft / slyly gan hyr seye
Now hold youre day / & do me not to deye
With that his courseur / torned he ab • u ••
With 〈◊〉 pale / & vnto Dyomede
No word he spak / ne none of al his reut •
Of whiche the sone of Tydeus took beede
As he that couthe more than hie C •• de
In suche a craft / & by the myne hyr •• nt
And Troylus to Troye homeward went
This Dyomede that led • yr by the brydel
When that he sawe the folke of Troye awey:
Thought al my labour / shal not be m • ydel
If that I may / for somwhat shal I sey
For at the les • yet / it may short ouer wey
I haue herd seyde eke / tymes twyre twelue
He is a foole that wyl fory • ce hym selue
But netheles thus / thought he wele ynough
That certeynly / I am aboute nought
If that I speke of loue / or make it tough
For douteles yf she haue in hyr thought
Hym that I gesse / he may not be y brought
So soone awey / but I shal fynde a mene
That she not yet shal wy •• what I mene
This Dyomede as he that couthe his good
When tyme was / gan falle forth in speche
Of this & that / & asked why she stood
In suche dysese / & gan hyr byseche
That yf he encrece myght or eche
With ony thyng / hyr ease that she wold
Comounde it hym / & he doo it wold
For trewely he swore hyr as a knyght
That ther nas thing with which he myȝt hir please
That he nyl do his hert & al his myght
To doo it / for to doo hyr hert an ease
And prayd hyr she wold hyr apease
And sayde ywys we grekes conne haue ioye
To honour yow as wese / as folk of Troye
He sayde eke thus / • wote ye thynke it strange
No wonder to / for it is to yow newe
T •• queyntaūce of these Troians for to chaūge
For folk of grece / that ye neuer knewe
But wold neuer god / but that as trewe
A greke ye myght among vs alle fynde
As ony Troian is & eke as kynde
And by cause I swore yow ryght now
To be youre frend / & helply to my myght
And for the more acqueyntaunce eke of yowe
Haue I had than another straunge wyght
Soo fro this forth I pray yow day & nyght
Comaundyth me how sore that I smert
To doo al that may lyke vnto youre hert
And that ye me wold as for your broder treate
And takyth not my frendshyp in despyte
And thouȝ your sorowes ben for thynges grete
Note I not why / but oute of more respyte
Myn hert hath to amende it grete delyte
And yf I may youre harmes not redresse
I am ryght sory for youre heuynesse
For though ye Troiās be with vs grekes wroth
Haue many a day / & ben yet parde
O god of loue syth we seruen bothe
And for the loue of god my lady free
Whome so ye hate / ne be not wroth with me
For trewely there can no wyght yow serue
That half so loth youre wrath wold deserue
And nere it that we ben so nye the tent
Of Calcas whiche that see vs bothe may
I wold of this now tr •• e al myn eutent
But this ensealed shal be tyl another day
Yeue me youre hand / I am & shal be ay
God help me so whyle that my lyf may dure
Youre owne aboue ony creature
Thus sayd I neuer or now to women born
For god myn hert as wysly glad soo
I loued neuer woman here byforn
As peramour ne neuer shal no moo
And for the loue of god be not my foo
Al can I not to yow my lady dere
Compleyne a ryght / for I am yet to lere
And wondryth not myn owne lady bryght
Though yt I speke of loue to yow thus blyue
For I haue herd or this of many a wyght
That louyd thyng / he neuer sawe his lyue
For I am not of power for to stryue
Ageynst god of loue but hym obeye
I wyl alwey / & of mercy yow preye
There ben so worthy knyghtes in this place
And ye so fayre that eueryche of hem alle
Wylle peynen hem to stond in youre grace
But myght me so fayre a grace falle
That ye me for your seruaunt wold calle
So lowely ne so trewely wold serue
Nyl none of hem as I shal tyl I sterue
Crrseyde vnto that purpoos lytel ansuerd
As she that was with sorowe oppressyd soo
That in effect she nought his tales herd
But here & there / now here a word or two
Hyr thought hyr sorowful hert brest a two
For whan she gan hyr fader fer aspye
Wele nyghe doune of hyr hor • she gan to sye
But netheles she thanked Dyomede
Of al his trauayle & his good chere
And that hym lyst his freudshyp hyr to lyde
And she acceptynge it in good manere
She wold do fayne / that is hym lyef & dere
And trustyn hym she wold & wele she myght
As seyde she / & from hyr hors she lyght
Hyr fader hath hyr in his armes nome
And twenty tyme he kyst his doughter swete
And seyde dere doughter myn welcome
She sayde she was feyn with hym to mete
And stode forthe mylde & mansuete
And thus I leue hyr with hyr fader dwelle
And forth I wyl of Troylus yow telle
To Troye is come this woful Troylus
In sorowe aboue al sorowes smert
With felon loke & face defpytous
And sodenly doune from his hors he stert
And thurgh his palays with a swollen hert
To chambre went / of nothyng tooke he hede
For none durst to hym speke a word for drede
And there his sorowes that he spared had
He yaue an yssue large / and deth he cryed
And in his throwes frentyk sore & mad
He cursyd Iuno Appollo & eke Cupyde
He cursyd Ceres Bachus / and Cypryde
His byrthe / hym self & eke nature
And saue his lady / euery creature
To bed he goth / walwyth there & 〈◊〉
In furye / as doeth he Ixyoun in 〈◊〉
And in this wyse / heuy tyl day sorou ••••
But tho bygan his hert / a lytel vnswelle
Thurgh t • rys / whiche gan vp to welle
And pytously he cryed vpon C •• sey ••
And to hym self ryght thus he spok & sayde
Where is myn owne lady ly • f & 〈◊〉
Where is hyr whyte b •• st / where is it 〈◊〉
Where ben hyr armes / and hyr eyen 〈◊〉
That •• ster nyght this tyme with me were
Now may I we • e o •• ne many a 〈◊〉
And graspe aboute I may but in this place
Saue a py •• we I fynde none to embrace
How shal I doo when shal she come ageyne
I not alas why let • I hyr goo
As wold god I had as tho be slayn
O hert myn Creseyde & swe • e soo
O lady myn that I loue & no moo
To whome for euermore myn • ert I lowe
See how I dye / ye wyl not me •• scowe
Who seeth yow now my ryght • ode steree
Who syt ryght now or scant in youre pre • ence
Who can comfort now youre 〈…〉
Now I am goo / who yeueth yow andy • nce
Who speketh for me now in myn absence
Alas no wyght / & that is al my care
For wele I wo • e as euyl as I ye 〈◊〉
How shal I thue ten dayes ful endure
When I the fyrst nyght haue al this trne
How shal ye doo sorowful creature
For tendyrnes how shal ye eke sustene
Suche woo for me / how pytous pale & grene
Shal be youre fresshe womanly face
For longyng or ye torne in to this place
And when he fylle in ony s •• mbrynges
A none begynne he shold to grone
And dreme of ryght dredeful thynges
That nyght / as mete that he were alone
In place horryble makyng ay his mone
Or metyn that he was amonges alle
His enemyes / & in her hondes f • lle
And therwith al his body shold stert
And with the styrt al sodenly awake
And suche a crampe feele aboute his hert
That of the fere hys body shold auake
And ther with al / he sholde a noyse make
And seme as though he shold fulle deepe
From hye aloft / and than he wold wepe
And rewe on hym self so pytously
That wonder was to here his fantasye
Another tyme he shold myghtely
Comfort hym self / and sey it was foly
So causeles suche dredys for to drye
And after begynne his aspre sorowes newe
That euery man myght on his sorowe rowe
Who couthe telle a ryght or ful deseryue
His weo his pleynt / his langour & his pyne
Not al the men that haue or ben alyue
Thow reder mayst ful 〈◊〉 thy self dyuyna
That suche a woo my wyt can not defyne
On ydel shold I wryte it with ynke
When that my wyt is wery it to thynke
On heuene the sterres wer • y sene
Al though ful pale woxen was the mon •
And whyten gan the orysount shene
Al Estward as it is wonte to done
And Phebus with his rosy cart soone
Gan after that to dresse hym vp to fare
When Troylus hath sent after pandare
This Pandare that of al day byforn
Ne myght haue come Troylus to see
And though on his hede / he had it sworn
For with kyng Priamus al day was he
Soo that it lay not in his lyberte
Nowhere to goo / but on the morow he went
To Troylus when that he for hym sent
For in his hert he couthe wel dyuyne
That Troylus al nyght for sorowe woke
And that he wold telle hym of his pyne
This knewe he ryght wele withoute book
For whiche to his chābre the ryght wey he toke
And Troylus tho soothly he grette
And on the bed ful soone he gan hym sette
My Pandare quod Troylus the sorowe
Whiche that I drye / & may not long endure
I trowe I shall not lyue tyl to morowe
For whiche I wold alweys in aduenture
To the deuyse of my sepulture
The fourme & of my meoble thow dyspone
Ryght as the semeth lest is for to done
But of the fnrye & flawmes funerall
In whiche my body brenne shal to gleede
And of the feest & playes palestral
At my vygyles I pray take good hede
That that he wele and offre mars my stede
My swerd / myn helme / & lyef broder dere
My shelde to pallas yeue that shyneth clere
The poudre in which myn hert brent shal torne
That pray I the thou take / & it conserue
In a vessel that men clepyn an vrne
Of gold to my lady that I serue
For loue of whome thus pytously I sterue
So yeue it hyr & doo me this plesaunce
To pray hyr to kepe it for a remembraunce
For wele I feele by my maladye
And by my dremes / now & yore ago
Al certeynly that I mote nedes dye
The Owle eke whiche that hyght Escaphylo
Hath after me shryght / al these nyghtes twoo
And god Mercurye now of me woful wretche
The sowle guyde / & when ye lyst it fetche
Pandare answerd & sayd O Troylus
My dere frend as I haue told the yore
That it is foly for to sorowe thus
And causeles / for whiche I can no more
But who so wyl not trowen rede ne lore
I can not see in hym no remedye
But lete hym worche with his fantasye
But Troylus I praye the telle me now
If thow wote or this ony wyght
Hath louyd peramour as wele as thow
Ye god wote / & from many a worthy knyght
Hath his lady ben a fourtenyght
And he not yet made haluendele the fare
What nede is the to maken al this care
Syth day by day thou mayst thy self see
That from his loue / or elles from his wyf
A man mote twynne of necessyte
Ye though he loue hyr / as his owne lyf
And though bytwene yow were neuer no strif
For wele thou wost my lyef broder dere
That alwey frendys may not ben y fere
How done these folk that seen her loues wedded
By frendys myght / as it betyd ful oft
And seen hem in her spouses bed y beddyd
God wote they take it wysely fayre & soft
Withoute wordes or blowyng oute aloft
And for they conne a tyme of sorow endure
As tyme hem hurt / tyme wyl hem recure
So shalt thou endure & lote slyde
The tyme / & found to be glad & lyght
Ten dayes is not so long to abyde
And syth she to come hath behyght
She nyl hyr heest breke for no wyght
For drede not but she wyl fynde a wey
To come ageyne my lyf that dare I ley
Thy sweuenes eke / & al suche fantasye
Dryue oute & lete hem goo to mysehauuce
For though they procede of thy Melancolye
That doeth the fele in slepe al this penaunce
Strawe for al thy sweuenes sygnyfyannce
God help me so / I compt hem not at a bene
There wote noman a ryght what dremes mene
For preestys of the temple tellen this
That dremes ben the reuelacyons
Of goddes / & as wele they telle ywys
That they ben infernal illusyons
And leches seyn that of complexyons
Proceden they of fastyng or glotenye
Who wote in soth what they sygnefye
Eke other soyn that thurgh Impressyons
As yf a wyght hath fast a thyng in mynde
That therof come suche vysyons
And other seyn as they in bookes fynde
That after tymes of the yere by kynde
Men dreme & that theffect goth by the mone
But leue no dreme syth it is not to done
Wele worth of dremes al these old wyues
And trewely angury of these fowles
For fere / wherof men wene to lese theyr lyues
As rauenes qualme / & shrikyng of these oules
To trowen on it / fals & foule is
Alas alas that so noble a creature
As is a man shold drede suche ordure
For whiche with al myn herte I the byseche
Vnto thy self / al this thou foryeue
And ryse now vp withoute more speche
And lete vs cast / how forth may best bedryue
This tyme & eke / how fresshely we may lyue
Whan that she comyth that shal be ryght soone
God help me soo / this thynk me best to done
Ryse lete vs speke / of lusty lyf in Troye
That we hane lad / & forth this tyme dryue
And eke of tyme comyng / as of ioye
That brynge shal oure blysse / now so blyue
And langour of these / twyes dayes fyue
We shuln therwith / so foryete oure oppresse
That wele vnnethe / it shal do vs duresse
This towne is ful of lordys al aboute
And trewes lasteth / al this mene whyle
Goo we pley vs / in som lusty route
To Sardepedon / not hens but a myle
And thus thow shalt / the tyme wel begyle
And dryue it forth / vnto thy blysful morowe
That thou hyr see / that is cause of thy sorowe
Now ryse / my dere broder Troylus
For certeyne none honour / is to the
To wepe / & in thy bed to rowken thus
For trewely of one thyng / trust thow me
If thou thus lygge / a day twoo or thre
The folk wyl saye / that thow for cowardyse
Thou feynest the seke & darst not aryse
This Troylus ansuerd / O broder dere
This knowen folk / that han suffred peyne
That though he wepe & make sorowful chere
That felyth harme / and smert in euery beyne
No wonder is though that I euer pleyne
Or alwey were I am no thyng to blame
Syth I haue lost / the cause of al my game
But s • th of fyn force I must arise
I shal arise as soone as euer I maye
And god to whome myn herte I sacrifise
So send vs hastely now the tenthe daye
For was there neuer fowle so fayne of maye
As I shal be when / she comyth in Troye
That cause is of my tormente / & my Ioye
But whyder is thy rede quod Troylus
That we pley vs may best in this towne
My counseyl is by god / quod pandarus
To ryde & pleye vs with Sarpedon
So long of this they speken vp & doun
Tyl Troylus at the last gan assent
To ryse / & forth to Sarpedon they went
This Sarpedon / as he that honourable
Was euer his lyf / & ful of hye largesse
With al that myght serued be at table
That deynte was / al cost it grete rychesse
He fed hem day by day / that suche noblesse
As sayden bothe the more & eke the leste
Was neuer seen or wyst at ony feste
Nor in this world there nys none ins ••• ment
Delyte of songe / or touche of corde
As fer / as ony wyght hath euer went
That tonge telle / or hert may recorde
That at the fest / it nas herd acorde
Of ladyes eke so fayre a companye
On daunces as tho / was none seen with eye
But what auayleth this to Troylus
That for his sorowe no thyng of it rought
For euer in one / his hert pyteuous
Ful besyly Creseyde his lady sought
On hyr was euer / al that his hert thought
Now this now that / so fast ymagynyng
That glad ywys can hym no festenyng
These ladyes that at the •• st been
Syth that he sawe his lady was aweye
It was his sorowe / vppon hem to sene
Or for to here / Instrumentes pleye
For she that of his hert bare the keye
Was absent / loo this was his fantasye
That no wyght shold make melodye
For there nas houre / in the day nor nyght
When he was there / that no man myȝt hym here
That he no sayde / O blysful lady bryght
How haue ye fare / syth that ye were here
Welcome ywys myn owne lady dere
But wele awey / al this nas but a mase
Fortune his houe / entendyd bet to glase
The letters eke / that she of old tyme
Had hym sent / he wold anone rede
And ofte betwyxt / none & pryme
Refyguryng hyr sha • / & hyr womanhede
Within his hert / & euery word & dede
That passed was / & thus he droof to an ende
The fourth day with Pandare his frende
And sayd / lyeue brother Pandarus
Entendyst thou / that we shal here byleue
Til Sarpedon forth wyl conueye vs
Yet were it fayrer that we took our loue
For goddes loue / lete vs soone at eue
Oure leue take / and home lete vs torne
For trewely I nyl not thus soiourne
Pandare ansuerd / be we comen hyder
To fetche fuyre & torne home ageyne
God help me soo / I can not telle whyder
We myght gone / yf I shal sothly seyne
There ony wyght / is of vs more feyn
Than Sarpedon / & yf ye hens hye
Thus sodenly / I hold it vylonye
Syth that we sayde / we wold bleue
With hym a wyke / and now thus sodenly
The fourth day take of hym oure leu •
He wold wonder / on it trewely
Lete vs forth hold / oure purpoos fermely
And syth that ye behyghte hym for to abyde
Hold forward now / and after •• te vs ryd •
This pandarus with al peyne & woo
Made hym to dwelle / & at the wekes ende
Of Sarpedon they took hyr l • ue tho
And on theyr wey they sped hem to wend

Quod Troylus / now lord me gr •••
send
That I may fynde / at myn home comyng
Creseyde y come / & therwith he gan syng
Ye •• syl woode quod this Pandare
And to hym self ful softely he seyde
God wot • referyde / may thy 〈◊〉 fare

Or Cal •••
send to Troylus Creseyde
But netheles he 〈◊〉 thus & 〈◊〉
And swore ywys / his h • rt hym thus 〈◊〉
She wold come as soone as she myght
When they vnto the paleys were y comon
Of Troylus / they doune of hor • alyght
And to the chambre the wey haue they 〈◊〉
And in to tyme / that it gan to nyght
They speke al of Creseyde the bryght
And after this / when •• m bothe life
They sped hem from sowper vnto rest
On morowe as sone / as day bygan to clere
This Troylus gan of his slepe to abreyde
And to Pandare his owne broder dere
For loue of god / ful pytously he seyde
As goo we see the paleys of Creseyde
For syth we yet may haue no more feste
Soo lete vs see hyr pal • ys at the leste
And ther with al hys meyne for to blende
A cause he fond in Towne for to goo
And to Creseyde hous they gan to wende
But lord this cely Troylus was woo
He thought his sorowful hert barst a twoo
For when he sawe hyr dores sperid alle
Wel nyghe for sorowe a doune he gan to falle
Therwyth when he was ware / and ga • behold
How shet was euery wyndowe of the pla ••
As frost hym thought his hert gan to cold
For whiche hym thought with dedely pale 〈◊〉
Withoute word forth by he gan to pace
And as god wold / he gan so fast to ryde
That no wyght of his countenaunce espyde
Than sayd he thus / O palays desolate
Of honour of gladnes whylome best y dyght
O palays empty and dysconsolate
O thow lāterne / of which quenchyd is the lyȝt
O palays whylome day / that now art nyght
Wele ought thow to falle doune / & I to dye
Syth she is went that was wonte vs to guye
O palays whylome crowne of hows alle
Enlumyned with sonne of al blysse
O ryng from whiche the Ruby is y falle
O cause of woo / that cause hast be of lysse
Yet syth I may not bet / fayn wold I hysse
Thy cold do •• / yf I durst for this rowte
And fare wel shryne / of which ye corps is out
Therwith he cast on Pandarus his eye
With chaungyd face / and pytous to byhold
And when he myght his tyme ryght espye
Ay as he rood to Pandarus he told
His newe sorowe & eke his ioyes old
Soo pytously / and with so dede an hewe
That enery wyght / myght on his sorowe rewe
From thensforth / he rydeth vp & doune
Aud euery thyng come hym to remembraūce
As he rode by the places in the towne
In whiche he had / had his plesaunce
Loo yonder sawe I last my lady daunce
And in that temple with her eyen clere
Me caught fyrst / my ryght lady dere
And yonder haue I herd / ful lustely
My dere herte laugh & yonder pleye
Sawe I hyr ones / eke ful blysfully
And to me ones yonder gan she seye
Now good swete / loue me wele I preye
And yond soo goodly / gan she me hehold
That to the deth / myn hert is to hyr hold
And • at the corner in the yonder hows
Herd I myn al ther leuest lady dere
Soo womanly with boyce melodyous
Syngen so wele / so goodly and so clere
That in my soule me thynketh I here
That blysful sowne / and in that yonder place
My lady fyrst me took vnto hyr grace
Than thought he thus / O blysful lord Cupyde
When I the processe haue in memorye
How thou me hast werreyd on euery syde
Men myght a book make of it lyke a storye
What nede is the to seke of me vyctorye
Syth I am thyn & hooly at thy wylle
What ioye hast thou thyne owne folk to spylle
Wele hast thow lord broke on me thyne Ire
Thou myghtful god / & dredeful for to greue
Now mercy lord / thou woost wel I desyre
This grace moost of al lustes leue
And lyue and dye I wyl in that byleus
For whiche I ne axe in guerdon but a boone
That thow me send Creseyde ageyne soone
Dystreyne hyr hert as fast to retourne
As thow doest myn / to longe hyr to see
Than wote I wele / that she nyl not soiourne
Now blysful lord / soo cruel thou ne be
Vnto the blood of Troye I pray to the
As Ioue was / vnto the blood of Thebane
For which the folk of Thebes / cauȝt theyr bane
And after this / he to the yates went
There as Creseyde / rode oute a ful good paas
And vp & doune there made he many a went
And to hym self ful ofte he sayd alas
From hens rode / my blys & my solas
And wold blysful god now for his ioye
I myght hyr seen ageyne come to Troye
And to the yonder hylle / he gan hyr gyde
Alas / & there I took of hyr my leue
And yond I sawe hyr / vnto hyr fader ryde
For sorowe of whiche / myn hert wyl to cleue
And hyder home I come / when it was eue
And here I dwelle oute cast / from al ioye
And shal tyl I may see hyr efte in Troye
And of hym self / ymagyned he ful ofte
To be defeted / pale and wexe lesse
Than he was wont / & that men sayden softe
What may it be / who can the sothe gesse
Why Troylus hath al this heuynesse
And al this nas but his melancolye
That he had of hym self suche fantasye
Another tyme ymagyne he wold
That euery wyght / that went by the weye
Had of hym rowthe / and they seyn shuld
I am ryght sory / Troylus wyl deye
And thus he droofe forth yet a day or tweye
As ye haue herd / suche lyf he gan lede
As he that stood betwene hope & drede
For whiche hym lyked in his songes shewe
Thencheson of his woo / as he best myght
And made a song of wordes but a fewe
Somwhat his woful herte for to lyght
And when he was from euery mans syght
With softe voys / he of his lady dere
That absent was / gan syngen as ye shal here
O sterre of whiche I haue y lost the lyght
With hert sore / ought I to bewayle
That euer derke in turment / nyght by nyght
Toward my deth / with wynd • I 〈◊〉 & sayle
For whiche the tenthe nyght / yf that I fayle
The Aydemant of thy beames / bryght & oure
My shyp and me Carybdye wylle deuoure
This song when he had songen soone
He syl ageyne in to his syghes old
And euery nyght as he was wonte to 〈◊〉
He stood the bryght mone to behold
And al his sorowe he to the mone • old

And sayde ywys when thou art horne •
〈◊〉
I shal be glad / yf al the world be trewe
I sawe thyn hornes eke / old by the morowe
When 〈◊〉 rode my ryght lady 〈◊〉
That cause to of my turment & my sorowe
For whiche bryght • neyna the clere
For loue of god •• nne fast aboute thy 〈◊〉
For when thy hornes newe gynne spryng
Than shal she come / that may my blysse 〈◊〉
The day is more / and lenger euery nyght
Than they be wont to be / hym thought tho
And that the sonne went his cours vnryght
By lenger •• ey / than he is wonte to do
And sayde ywys me dredyth euermo
The sonnes sone Phyron to be a lyue
And that his cart amys he doth dryue
Vpon the wallys / fast he wold walke
And on the grekes fast he wold see
And to hym self ryght thus he wold talke
Loo yonder is myn owne lady free
Or elles yonder / there the tentes be
And thens comyth this ayre / that is so swote
Foe in my sowle I fele it doth me bote
And hardyly this / wynde more & more
Thus stounde mele encreaced in my face
Is of my lady deere / syghes sore
I preue it thus / for in none other space
Of al this Towne / saue only in this place
Fele I no wynde / that sownyth so lyke peyne
It seyth alas / why twynned be we tweyne
This long tyme he dryuyth forth ryght thus
Tyl fully passed was the nynthe nyght
And ay besyde hym / was this Pandarus
That besyly dyde his ful myght
Hym to comfort / & make his hert lyght
Yeuyng hym hope alwey the tenthe morowe
That she shal come / & stynt al this sorowe
Vpon that other syde was this Creseyde
With wymmen fewe among the grekes strong
For whiche ful oft / alas alas she seyde
That I was born / wel may myn hert long
After my deth / for now lyue I to long
Alas / & I may it not amende
For now is wers / than euer yet I wende
My fader nyl for no thyng do me grace
To goo ageyn / for nought I can hym queme
And yf so be that I my terme pace
My Troylus shal now in his hert deme
That I am fals / & soo it may wel seme
Thus shal I haue vnthank on euery syde
That I was born / so wele awey the tyde
And yf I me put in ieopordye
To stele awey to nyght / & it byfalle
That I be caught I shal be holde aspye
Or elles / loo this drede I moost of alle
If in the handes of somme wretche I falle
I am but lost al be myn hert trewe
Now myghty god thou on my sorowe rewe
Ful pale was woxe hyr bryght face
Hyr lymes leene / as she that al the day
S • ood wh • n she durst / and lokyd on the place
There she was borne / & there she dwellyd ay
And al the nyght wepyng / alas she lay
Aud thus dyspeyred oute of al cure
She lad hyr lyf / this woful creature
Ful ofte a day / she syghed for dystresse
And in hir self / she went ay portrayeng
Of Troylus the grete worthynesse
And al his goodly wordys recordyng
Syth first yt day / theyr loue bygan to spryng
And thus she sēt hyr woful hert a fyre
Thurgh remembraunce of that she gan desyre
In al this world / there nys so cruel hert
That hyr had herd compleyue in that sorowe
That nold ha • e wept for peynes smert
Soo tendyrly she wepte bothe eue & morowe
Hyr nedyd no terys for to borowe
And this was yet the worst of al hyr peyne
Ther was no wyȝt / to whom she myȝt cōpleyne
For rewfully she loked vpon Troye
Byheld the toures hye & eke the halles
Alas quod she the plesaunce & the ioye
The whiche al newe torned in to galle is
Haue I had oft within yonder wallys
O Troylus what doest thou now she seyde
Lord whether thou yet thynke vppon Creseyde
Alas I ne had trowed / vpon youre lore
And wend with yow / as me red or this
Than had ynow not syghed / half so sore
Who myght han seyde / that I had done amys
To stele awey / with suche one as he is
But al to late / comyth the lectuarye
When men the corps vnto the graue carye
To late is now / to speke of that matere
Prudence alas / one of thyn eyen thre
Me lakked alwey or that I come here
Of tyme passed I wyl remembre me
And present tyme / wele couthe I see
But future tyme / or I was in the snare
Couthe I not see / that causith al my care
But netheles betide / what betyde
I shal to morowe at nyght / by est or west
Oute of this hostel / on som manere side
And goo with Troylus where so hym lest
This p • rppos wyl I hold / and this is best
No fors of wykke tonges / Iangel • rye
For euer on loue / haue wretches enuye
For who so wyl of euery word take heede
Or rewle hym self / by euery wyghtes wyt
Ne shal he neuer thryue oute of drede
For that somme men blamen euer yet
Loo other men / yet comendyn it
And as for me / al suche varyaunce
Felycyte clepe I my suffysaunce
For whiche withoute ony wordes mo
To Troylus wyl I / as for conclusyon
But god it wote / or fully nyghtes twoo
She was ful fer from that entencyoun
For bothe Troylus and Troye toun
Shal knotteles thurgh hyr hert slyde
For she wyl another purpoos abyde
This Dyomede / of whome I telle yow? gan
Goth now within hym self / ay arguyng
With al sleyghte / and al that euer he can
How he may best / with shortest taryeng
In to his net / Creseydes hert breng
To this entent / he couthe • euer fyne
To fysshen hyr / he leyd oute hook & lyne
But netheles wel in his hert he thought
That she was not withoute a loue in Troye
For he neuer syth / he her thens brought
Ne couthe hyr see laugh / ne make ioye
He nyst how best / hyr hert to acoye
But for to assay / he seyde not ne greuyth
For he yt nought ne assayeth / nouȝt ne cheuyth
Yet sayd he hym self vppon a nyght
Now am I not a foole / that wote wel how
Hyr woo for loue is of another wyght
And herupon to goo assaye now
I may wel wyte / it wyl not be my prow
For wyse folk in bookes it expresse
Men shold not wowe a wyght in heuynesse
But who so myght wynne suche a floure
From hym / for whome she mornyth nyȝt & day
He myght sey / he were a conquerour
And ryght anone / as he that told was ay
Thought in his hert / hap how I hap may
Al shold I dye / I wyl hyr hert seche
I shal no more lese / but my speche
This Dyomede / as bookes vs declare
Was in his nede prest & corageous
With sterne voys / & myghty lymes square
Hardy ryght strong / and chyualrous
Of dedys lyke his fader Tydeus
And some men seyn he was of tonge large
And heyr he was of Calydoyne & Arge
Creseyde med yoc • e / was of stature
Therto of shap / of face / & eke of chere
There myght be no fayrer creature
And of tyme this was hyr manere
To goo y tressyd with hyr heres clere
Doune by hyr Coler / at hyr bak behynde
Whiche with a threde of gold / she wolde bynde
And saue hyr browes ioyned in fere
There was no lak in ought I can espyen
But for to speke of hir eyen clere
Trewely they wryten al that hyr syen
That paradyse stood formed in her eyen
And with hyr ryche beaute euermore
Stroofe loue in hyr ay / whiche was more
She sobre was symple / & wyse with al
The best nortured eke that myght be
And goodly of hyr speche in general
Charytable estatly / lusty / and free
Ne neuermore lakkyd hyr pytee
Tendre herted / slydyng of courage
But trewely I can not telle hyr age
And Troylus wele woxen was in heyght
And complete fourmed by proporcyon
Soo wele that kynde not amende myght
Yong / fresshe / strong / and hardy as lyoun
Trewe as styele in eche condycyoun
One of the best entedchyd creature
That is or shal whyle the world may dure
And certeynly in storye / as it is founde
That Troylus was neuer vnto no wyght
As in his tyme / in no degre secound
In daryng doo that longyth to a knyght
Al myght a Gyaunt / passen hym of myght
His force ay with the fyrst / & with the best
Stood peregal / to do what hym lest
But for to telle forth of Dyomede
It fyl after / that on the tenthe day
Syth that Creseyde / oute of the cyte yeede
This Dyomede as fresshe / as braunche in may
Come to the tent / there as Calcas lay
And feyned hym with Calcas haue to done
But what he ment / I shal yow telle soone
Creseyde at short wordys for to telle
Welcomed hym / & dyd hym by hyr set
And he was ethe ynowe / to make duelle
And after this withoute long let
Spyces & wyn men forth hem fet
And forth they speke of this & that y fere
As frendys doo / of whiche som ye shal here
He gan fyrst falle of the werre in speche
Betwyxt hem & the folk of Troye Town
And of thassyege / he gan hyr byseche
To telle hym / what was hyr oppynyoun
Fro that demaunde / he so descendyth doun
To asken hyr / yf that she straunge thought
The grekes gyse / & werkys that they wrought
And why hyr fader / taryeth here so long
To wedden hyr vnto somme worthy knyght
Creseyde that was in hyr peynes strong
For loue of Troylus hyr owne dere knyght
As ferforth as she connyng had or myght
Ansuerd hym tho / but al of his entent
It semed not / she wyst what he ment
But netheles this ylke Dyomede
Gan in hym self assure / and thus he seyde
If I a ryght / haue take of yow hede
Me thynketh thus / O lady myn Creseyde
Syth that I fyrst honde on youre brydel leyde
When ye oute come of Troye by the morow
Ne couthe I neuer see yow but in sorow
Can I not seyn what may the cause be
But it for loue of somme Troian it were
The whiche ryght sore wold a thynk me
That for ony wyght that dwelleth there
Sholden spylle a quarter of a tere
Or pytously / youre self soo begyle
For dredeles it is not worth the whyle
The folk of Troye / as who seyth al & some
In prysoune be / as youre self see
For thens shal none a lyue come
For al the gold bytwene sonne & see
Trustyth ryght wele / & vnderstonde me
There shal not one to mercy / goo alyue
Al were he lord of worldes twyes fyue
Suche wreche on hem for fetchyng of Heleyne
There shal be take or that we hens wende
That Maunes whiche goddes ben of peyne
Shold ben agast / how grekes sholde hem shende
And men shuln drede vnto the worldes ende
From hens forth to rauysshe ony quene
So cruel shal oure wreche on hem be sene
And but yf Calcas lede vs with Ambages
That is to sey with double wordes slye
S • che as men clepe a word with two vysages
Ye shal wel knowe / that I nought ne lye
And al this thyng ryght sone with youre eye
And that anone ye wyl not trowe how soone
Now taketh heede / for it is to done
What wene ye youre wyse fader wold
Haue youe yew / for Anthenore anone
If he ne wyst that the cytee shold
Destroyed be / why nay soo mote I gone
He knoweth ful wele ther shal escape none
That Troian is / & for the grete fere
He durst not / that ye duellyd lenger there
What wold ye more loue som lady dere •
Lete Troy & Troians from youre hert pace
Dryue out your bytter hope / & make good chere
And clepe ageyne the beaute of youre face
That ye with salt teres so deface
For Troye is brought in suche ieopardy
That it to saue is nowher remedye
And thynketh wele / ye shal in grekes fynde
A more parfyte loue / or it be nyght
Than ony Troian is / and more kynde
And bet to serue yow / wyl do his myght
And yf ye vouch • souf my lady bryght
A wyl be he / to serue yow my selue
Ye leuer than be kyng of grekes twelue
And with that word / he gan to wexe rede
And in his speche a lytel wyght be quo • e
And cas • a syde a lytel with his hede
And s • ynt a whyle / and afterward be wo • e
And sobyrlyche on hyr threwe his looke
And sayd I am / al be it to yow no ioye
As gentyl a man / as ony wyght in 〈◊〉
For yf my f • der Tydens he seyde
Lyued had / I had be long or this

Of Calcydony and Arge / a
• yng Creseyde
And so I hope I shal be yet ywys
But he was sleyn / alas the more harme is
Vn • appely at Theles / al to rathe
Polemytes / and many a man to scathe
But herte myn syth I am youre man
And y • the fyrst / of whome I sec • e grace
And serue yow / as hertely as I can
And euer shal whyle I to lyue haue space
Soo or that I departe oute of this place
That ye me graunt that I may to morowe
At better leyser / telle yow my sorowe
What shold I telle his wordes / that he seyde
He spak ynough for one day at the meest
It preueth wele he spak • soo that Creseyde
Graunted hym a morow / at his request
To haue a speche with hyr at the lest
Soo that he nold speke of suche matere
And thus she sayd to hym as ye maye here
As she that had hyr hert on Troylus
Soo that ther may none it arace
And strangely she spak / & seyd thus
O Dyomede I loue that ylke place
That I was born in / and Ioue for his grace
Delyuere it soone / of al that doo it care
God for thy myght / soo lene it wel to fare
That grekes wold in Troye their wrath wreke
If that they myght I knowe it wele ywys
But it shal not fallen / as ye speke
And god to forn / & further ouer this
I wote my fader loyse and redy is
And that he hath me bought / as ye me told
So dere I am the more to hym hold
These grekes ben of hyghe condycyoun
I wote it wele / but certeyne men shuln fynde
As worthy folk within Troye Town
As connynge / as parfyte / & as kynde
As bytwene Orcades & y • de
And that ye couthe wele youre lady serue
I trowe it wele / hyr thank for to deserue
But as to speke of loue ywys she seyde
I had a lord / to whome I wedded was
The whiche myn hert had / tyl that he deyde
And other loue / as helpe me now pallas
There in myn herte nys ne neuer was
And that ye be of noble & hye kynrede
I haue it herd wel telle oute of drede
And that doeth me / to haue so grete a wonder
That ye wyl scorne ony woman soo
Eke god wote loue and I ben fer a sonder
I am dysposed / bet soo mote I goo
Vnto my dethe to playne & make woo
What shal I doo after can I not seye
But trewely as yet me lyst not to pleye
Myn hert is now in trybulacyon
Aud ye in armes lesy day by day
Here after when ye wonnen hane the towne
Parauenter than so it hap may
That when I see / that neuer yet I say
Than wyl I werk / that I neuer wrought
This word to yow ynough suffysen ought
Tomorowe wol I speke with yow fayn
So that ye touche not of this matrre
And when yow lyst ye may come here agayne
And or ye goo / thus moche I sey yow here
As help me pallas with hir heres clere
If that I shold on ony greke haue routhe
It shold be youre self by my trouthe
I seye not therfor that I wyl yow loue
Ne I say not nay / but in conclusyon
I mene wele by god / that sytte aloue
And therwyth al she cast hyr eyen doune
And gan to syghe / & sayd O Troye Towne
Yet byd I god in quyete & in rest
I may the see / or doo myn herte brest
But in effect as shortely for to saye
This Dyomede al fresshe newe ageyne
Gan precen in / fast hyr mercy praye
And after this the soth for to seyne
Hyr gloue he took / of whiche he was ful feyn
And fynally when it was woxen eue
And al was wele / he roose / & toke his leue
The bryght Veuus folowyd / and ay tought
The weye there brode Phebus a doune lyght
And Cythera the chare hors ouer raught
To whyrle oute of the lyoun / yf she myght
And Signifer his candel shewed bryght
Whan Creseyde vnto hyr rest went
In with hyr faders faire bryght tent
Retournyng in hyr sowle vp & doune
The wordes of this sodeyne Dyomede
His grete estate & perylle of the Towne
And that she was alone / & had nede
Of frendys / & thus bygan to brede
The cause why the sooth for to telle
That she tooke purpoos fully for to duelle
The morowe cam / and goostely for to speke
This Dyomede is come to Creseyde
And shortely lest that ye my tale breke
Soo wele he for hym self spak & seyde
That al his syghes sore a doune he leyde
And fynally the soothe for to seyne
He left of the grete / of al his peyne
And after this / the story telleth vs
That she hym yafe the fayre bay stede
The whiche she ones had of Troylus
And eke a broche that was lytel nede
That Troylus was / she yaf this Dyomede
In dede the bet / from sorowe hym to releue
She made hym were / a pensel of hyr sleue
I fynd eke in the storye elles where
When thurgh the body / hurt was Dyomede
Of Troylus tho wept she many a tere
Whan that she sawe his wyde woundes blede
And that she took to kepe hym good hede
And for to hele hym of his sorowes smert
Men seyn I note / she yaf hym hyr hert
But trewely the storye tellyth vs
Ther made neuer woman more woo
Than she whan she falshed Troylus
She sayd alas / for now is clene a go
My name of trouthe in loue for euermo
For I haue falshed one the gentyllest
That euer was & eke the worthyest
Alas of me vnto the worldes ende
Shal neyther of me be wryte nor s • nge
No good word / for this book wyl me shend •
Y rollyd shal it be on many a tonge
Thorugh outr the world / my • elle shal be 〈◊〉
And wymmen wyl me hate moost of alle
Alas that suche a caas shold me byfalle
They wyl sey in as moche / as in me is
I haue hym doo dyshonoure wele aweye
Al be I not the fyrst that dyde a • nye
What helpyth that to doo my blame aweys
But syth I see 〈◊〉 nys no bett •• weys
And that to late it is now for to •• we
To Dyomede alga •• I wylbe trewe
But Troylus syth I no better may
And syth that thus departen ye and I
I praye god / yeue yow ryght good day
As for the gentyllest knyght tr • wely
That euer I sawe to serue feythfully
And 〈◊〉 can ay his lady honoure kepe
And with that word / she br • se anon • to wept

And
•• rtes yow hatyn shal I neuer
And frendys loue / that shal ye loue of me
And my good word / al myght I lyuen euer
And trewely I wold ryght sory be
To see yow in ony aduersy ••
And gylteles I wo • e wele I yow l • ue
But al shal passe / & thus I take my leue
But trewely how long it was bytwene
That she forsoke hym for this Dyomede
There is none other auctor telleth I wene
Take euery man now to his bookes hede
He shal no terme fynde oute of drede
For though that he began to loue hyr soone
Or he hyr wan / yet was there more to done
Ne me lys • not / this cely woman chyde
Forther than the story wyl deuyse
Hyr name alas is publysshed so wyde
That for hyr gylt / it ought ynowe suffyse
And yf I myght excuse hyr in ony wyse
For she so sory was for her vntrouthe
Ywys I wold excuse hyr yet for routhe
This Troylus as I byfore haue told
Thus dryueth forthe / as wele as he myght
But ofte was his herte hoote & • ld
And namely that ylke nynthe nyght
Whiche on the morowe / she had hym behyght
To come ageyne / god wote ful lytel reste
Had he that nyght / nothynge to slepe hym leste
The laurer crowned Phebus with his heete
Come in his cours / ay vpward as he went
To warmen of the eest the wawes wete
And Cyrces doughter sa • ge with good entent
When Troylus his Pandare after sent
And on the wallys of the Towne they pleyde
To looke yf they can ought see of Creseyde
Tyl it was none they stood for to see
Who that there come / & euery maner wyght
That come from fer / they sayde it was she
And that wey couthe knowen hem a ryght
Now was his herte heuy / now was it lyght
And thus beiaped they stonde to stare
Aboute nought Troylus & Pandare
To Pandarus this Troylus tho seyde
For ought I wote / byfore none sykerly
In to this toune not cometh here Creseyde
She hath ynough a doo there hardyly
To wynne from hyr fader / so trowe I
Hyr old fader wold yet make hyr dyne
Or that she goo / god yeue his herte pyne
Pandare answerd / It may wel be certeyn
And for thy lete vs dyne I the byseche
And after none / than mayst thow come ageyn
And home they gone withoute more speche
And come ageyne / and long may they seche
Or that they fynde / that they after gape
Fortune hem bothe / thynketh for to iape
Quod Troylus I see wel ynowe that she
Is • aryed with hyr old fader soo
That or she come / it wol nyhe euen be
Come forth I wylle vnto the yate goo
These portyers ben vnconnyng euermo
And I wyl doo hem holde open the gate
As nought ne were / al though she come late
The day goth fast / & after that come eue
And yet come not to Troylus Creseyde
He lokyth forth by hedge / by tree / by greue
And fer his heede on the walle he leyde
And at the last he torned hym & seyde
By god I wote hyr menyng now pandare
Al moost ywys / al newe was my care
Now douteles this lady can hyr good
I wote she comyth rydyng pryuely
I commende hyr wysedom by myn hood
She wyl not make people nycely
Gawryn on hyr when she comyth / but softely
By nyght in to Towne she thynketh ryde
And dere broder / thynk not long to abyde
We haue not elles to done ywys
And Pandarns now shalt thow trowe me
Haue here my trouthe / I see yond where she is
Heue vp thyne eyen / man mayst thow not see
Pandare ansuerd / nay so mote I the
Al wrong by god / what feist yu man wher arte
That I see yond nys but a fare carte
Alas thow seyst ful soth quod Troylus
But hardyly it is not al for nought
That in myn herte that I reioyse thus
It is ageynst som good / I haue a thought
Note I not how / but syth that I was wrouȝt
Ne felt I suche a comfort sothe to seye
She cometh to nyght / my lyf dare I leye
Pandare answerd / it may be wel ynough
And held with hym of al that euer he seyde
But in his herte he thought / & fast lough
And to hym self ful sobyrly he seyde
From hasylwoode / ther Ioly Robyn pleyde
Shal come al that thow doest abyde here
Ye fare wele al the snowe of fern yere
The wardeyn of the gates gan to calle
The folk / whiche withoute the gates were
And bad hem dryue in theyr bestes alle
Or al that nyght they must abyde there
And fer within nyght with many a tere
This Troylus gan homeward for to ryde
For wele he sawe / it helpyd not abyde
But netheles he gladdyd hym in this
He thought amys he had compted his day
And sayde I vnderstonde haue al amys
For thylk nyght / I last Creseyde say
She sayd I shal be here / yf that I may
Or that the mone / O dere herte swete
The syoun passe oute of this Aryete
For whiche she may yet hold hyr heste
And on the morowe vnto the yate he went
And vp & doune / by west / & eke by Eeste
Vpoon the wallys made he many a went
But al for nought / his hope alwey hym blent
For whiche at nyght in sorowe & syghes sore
He wente hym home withoute ony more
His hope al clene oute of his herte fled
He ne hath wheron / no lenger now to honge
But for the peyne hym thought his hert bled
So were his throwes sharp & wonder stronge
For when he sawe she abode soo long
He nyst what he ymagyne therof myght
Syth that the hath broke / that she hym behyght
The thyrd / the fourth / the fyfthe / & the syxth day
After the dayes ten / of whiche I told
Bytwene h • pe & drede his herte lay
〈◊〉 somwhat trustyng on hyr heestes old
But when he sawe / she nold hyr terme hold
He can now see none other remedye
But for to shape hym soone for to dye
Ther wyth the wykked spyryte / god vs blesse
Whiche that men clepe woode Ielousye
Gan in hym crepe in al this heuynesse
For whiche by cause he wold soone dye
He ne ete ne dranke for his melancolye
And eke from euery companye he fled
This was the lyf / that al this tyme he led
He soo defeted was that no maner man
Hym knowe myght / vnnethe where he went
Soo was he lene / & therto pale & wan
And feble that he walked by potent
And with his Ire thus hym self he shent
And who so asked hym / wherof he smerte
He seyde his harme was al aboute his herte
Priamus ful ofte / & eke his moder dere
His bretheren & his sustren gan hym freyne
Why he so sorowful was / in al his chere
And what thyng was the cause of his peyne
But al for nought he nold his cause pleyne
But seyde / he felt a greuous maladye
Aboute his hert / & fayn wold he dye
Soo on a daye / he leyd hym doune to slepe
And so byfelle that in his slepe he thought
That he walked in a forest to wepe
For loue of hyr that his peyne wrought
And vp & doune / as he the forest sought
Hym thought he saw a bore with Tuskes grete
That slepe a geyne the bryght sonnes hete
And by this bore / fast in armes fold
Lay kyssyng ay / his lady bryght Treseyde
For sorowe of whiche / whan he gan byhold
Loude he cryed on Pandarus & seyde
For sorowe of whiche / almost ther he deyde
O Pandarus now knowe I crop & rote
I am but dede / there nys none other boote
My lady bryght Creseyde hath me bytrayed
In whome I trustyd moost of ony wyght
She esses where hath now hyr hert apayed
The blisful goddes thurgh theyr grete myght
Haue in my dreame shewed me ful ryght
Thus in my dreame Creseyde haue I behold
And al this thyng to pandarus he told
O my Creseyde / alas what subtylyte
What newe lust / what beaute / what seyence
Hath thus withdrawe your hert / & loue frō me
This is the cause of youre long absence
Hath from me raft / alas youre aduertence
O trust / O feyth / O depe assuraunce
Who hath me raft Creseyde al my plesaunce
Alas why lete I yow from hens go
For whiche wel nyghe oute of my wyt I breide
Who shal now trowe on ony othes moo
God wote I wende lady bryght Creseyde
That euery word was gospel / that ye seyde
But who may bet begyle / yf hym lyst
Than he on whome men wene best to tryst
What shal I doo / my Pandarus alas
I feele now so sharp / & a newe peyne
Syth that ther lyeth noo remedye in this caas
That bet it were I with myn hondes tweyne
My self slee / than thus alwey to pleyne
For thurgh the deth my wo shold haue an ende
There euery day with lyf my self I shende
Pandare ansuerd / & sayd alas the whyle
That I was borne / haue I not seyd or this
That dremes may many a man begyle
And why for folk expownen hem amys
How durst thow sey / that fals thy lady is
For ony dremes ryght for thyne owne drede
Lace be thy thought / thou canst no dremes rede
Parauenter there thou dremest of this boore
It may so be / that it may sygnefye
Hyr • ader eke / whiche old is & hoore
Ageyne the sonne lyeth in poynt to dye
And she for sorowe gynneth wepe & crye
And there he lyeth kyssyd hym on the groūd
Thus sholdest thou thy dreames ryȝt expound
How myght I than done quod Troylus
To knowe of this / were it neuer so lyte
Now seyst thow wysely quod tho pandarus
My rede is this / syth thow canst wele endyte
That hastely a letter thou to her wryte
Thoragh whiche thow shalt bryngen it about
To knowe a soothe ther thou art in doute
And see now why / for I dare wel seyn
That yf so is / she vntrewe be
I can not trowe she wyl wryte ageyn
And yf she wryte thow shalt soone see
As whether she hath / ony lyberte
To come ageyne / or elles in som clause
If she be let / she wylle assygne a cause
Thow hast not wryte to hyr / syth she went
Ne she to the / and this I durst leye
There may suche cause be in hyr entent
That hardyly thow wylt thy self seye
That hyr abode / the best is for yow tweye
Now wryte hyr than / & thow shalt see soone
A soothe of al / ther is no more to done
Acordyd ben they to this conclusyon
And that anone these ylke lordes two
And hastely syt Troylus a doune
And rollyth in his hert to & fro
How he may best descryuen hyr his woo
And to Creseyde his owne lady dere
He wrote ryght thus / and sayd as ye shal here
Ryght fresshe floure / whos I haue ben & shall
Withouten part of elles where seruyse
With hert / body / lyf / lust / thought & al
I woful wyght in euery humble wyse
That tonge can telle or hert may deuyse
As oft as matere occupyeth place
Me recomaunde I vnto youre noble grace
Lyketh yow to wyte swete hert
As ye wel knowe / how long tyme agone
That ye me left in asper peynes smert
When that ye went / of whiche yet boote none
Haue I none had / but euer wors bygone
From day to day am I / and soo more dwelle
Whyle it yow lest lo ye of wele & wo my welle
For whiche to yow with dredeful hert trewe
I'wryte as he that scrow dryue • h to wryte
My woo that euery houre 〈◊〉 newe
Compleynyng / ae I da •• / or con 〈◊〉
And that a 〈◊〉 / ye may wele 〈◊〉
The 〈◊〉 whiche that sro myn 〈◊〉 rey ••
They wold speke / yf they • cuthe compleyne 〈◊〉
Yow fyrst / byseche, I with youre eyen 〈◊〉
To looke on this de fowled / & vnfold
And ouer al this / ye my lady dere
Wil vouchesauf this letter to byhold
And by the cause eke of my cares cold
That 〈◊〉 my wyt / yf ought amye me stert
So y • ue it me myn owne swete hert
〈…〉 curst or ought of ryght
〈…〉 lady pytously compleyne
〈…〉 that I ought be that wyght
〈…〉 this that ye these monthes tweyn
Haue taryed their / ye seyde soothe to seyne
But 〈…〉 ye nold in hoost sorourne
But 〈◊〉 two monethes yet ye not 〈◊〉
But 〈…〉 moche / as I mo • e nedes lyke
Al that yow lyketh I dare pleyne no more
But 〈◊〉 wyth sorowful syghte syke
Yow wry •• I myn vnirsty sorowee sore
From day to day desyryng euermore
To knowe fully / yf yowre wylle were
How ye hane feid / and deo whyle ye be there
Whos welfare / and hel • / god eke encrease
In honoure suche / as vpward in degre
It growe alwey so / that it neuer cease
Lyke as youre self 〈◊〉 can my l • dy fre
Deuyse I pray 〈◊〉 god so more it be

And graunt that 〈◊〉
• oone vpon me 〈◊〉
As wysly as in al I am youre trewe
And yf yow lyke to knowe of the fare
Of me whos woo / ther may no wyght deseriue
I can no mo • e / but 〈◊〉 of •• ery care
At wrytyng of 〈…〉 I was alyue
Al redy cute my woful goos • to dryue
Whiche I delay / and hold hym yet in hond
Vpon the syght of mat • re of youre sond
Myn eyen twoo in veyne / with whiche I see
Of woful teres salt / arn woxen welles
My songe in playnt of myn aduersyte
My good in harme / myn ease woxen helle is
My ioye in woo / I can yow seye not elles
〈◊〉 turned is / for whiche my lyf I wary
Euery ioye / is torned to me contrary
Whiche with your comyng home ageyn to Troye
Ye may redresse / and more a thowsand sythe
Than euer I had encrecyng in me ioye
〈◊〉 was there neuer herte yet so blythe
〈◊〉 haue his lyf / as I shold be as swythe
As I yow see • though no manere routhe
〈◊〉 mene yet / thynke vpon yowre trouthe
And yf so moche my deth I haue deserued
Or yf yow lyst no more vpon me see
In guerdon yet of al I haue yow serued
〈◊〉 I yow my hertes lady free
That heruppn / ye wyl wryte me
For loue of god / my ryght loode sterre
Or d • the lete make an ende of al my werre
• there cause ought that doth yow for to duelle
That with youre letter ye me recomforte
For though to me youre absence be an helle
With pacyence I wyl my wo supporte
And with your letter of hore I wyl dysporte
Now wryteth swete / • le •• me thus not pleyne
With hoope or •• th delyuere me from peyne
Ywys myn owne dere herte trewe
I wote than / whan ye next vpon me see
Soo bost haue I myn helthe / & eke myn hewe
Creseyde shal not conne knowe me
Iwys myn hertes day / my lady free
Soo thurstyth ay myn herte to byhold
Youre beaute that my lyf vnnethe I hold
I say nomore / al haue I for to seye
To yow wel more than I telle may
But whether ye done me lyue or deye
Yet pray I god / so yeue yow ryght good day
And faryth wele / ryght fayre fresshe may
As ye thal lyf or deth may me comaunde
And to youre trouthe I me recomaunde
With helthe suche / that but yf ye yeue me
The same helthe / I shal neuer helthe haue
In yow lyeth / when yow lyst / it so shal be
The day on whiche me clothen shal my graue
In yow my lyf / youre myght is it to saue
Me from dysese / of al peynes smerte
And f • re now wele myn owne swete herte
This letter forth was sent vnto Creseyde
Of whiche hyr answer in effect was this
Ful pytously she wrote ageyne and seyde
That as soone / as euer she myght ywys
She wold come / and mende that was amys
And fynally wrote / & sayd hym than
She wold come / but she wyst neuer whan
But in her letter / she made suche feestes
That wonder was / & swore she louyd hym best
Of whiche he fond / but bottumles byhestes
But Troylus thow mayst now Est or west
Pype in an yuy leef / yf that the lest
Thus goth ye world / god sheld vs frō myschāce
And euery wyght / that meneth trouthe auan̄ce
Encreasen gan the woo from day to nyght
Of Troylus / for taryeng of Creseyde
And lassen gan his hope & eke his myght
For whiche al doune vdon his bed hym leyde
He ne ete ne drank / ne slepe / ne no word seyde
Ymagynyng ay that she was vnkynde
For whiche wel nyhe he wax oute of mynde
This dreme / of whiche I told haue here byforn
May neuer come oute of his remembraunce
He thought as wele / he had his lady born
And that Iouys, of his purueaunce
Hym shewyd had in slope the sygnyfyaunce
Of hyr vntrouthe & dysauenture
And that this was shewyd hym in fygure
For whiche he for Syble his suster sente
That callyd was Cassandra eke al aboute
And al his dreme / he told hyr or he wente
And hyr bysought / assoylen hym the doute
Of this strong bore with tuskys stoute
And fynally within a lytel stounde
Cassandra ryght thus his dreme expound
She gan fyrst smyle / & sayd broder dere
If thow a sothe of this desyrest to knowe
Thow must a fewe of old storyes here
To purpoos how that fortune ouerthrowe
Hath lordes hye / whiche within a throwe
This bore shalt yu know wel / & of what kynd
He comyn is / as men in bookes fynd
Dyane whiche that wrothe was & in yre
For grekes nold doo hyr sacryfyce
Ne encens on hyr aulter set a fyre
She for that grekes / gan hyr despyse
Wroke hyr in a wonder cruel wyse
For with a bore / as grete as Oxe in stalle
She made hym et • vp hyr corne & vpnes alle
To slee this bore was all the countre reysed
Amonges whiche there come this bore to see
A mayde one of this world best y preysed
And Meleager lord of that countre
He louyd soo / this fresshe mayde free
That with his manhood / or he wold stent
This bore he slowe / and hyr the heede he sent
Of whiche as old • okes tellen vs
There roos a • ontek • a grete enuye
And of this lord des • endyd Tydeus
By lyne / or esses / old bookes lye
But how this Meleager gan for to dye
Thorugh his moder wyl I yow not •• lle
For al to long it were for to duelle
She told eke / how Tydeus she sent
Vnto the strong • yte of Thebes
To clayme kyngdom of the cyte & went
For his felowe • an Possymytrs
Of whiche his owne broder Ethyocles

Ful wrongfully of 〈◊〉
held the strength
This • old she by processe & by lengthe
She told eke / how he monyde • as • erte
〈…〉 knyghtes stou ••
〈…〉 kynged with theyr 〈◊〉
〈…〉 ther the cyte of aboute
And of the holy serpent & the welle
And of the furyed of gan she hym 〈◊〉
Associat profugum / Tideus prim • Po •• midem
Tidea legatum / docet infidias 〈◊〉 secundis
Teraus Hermodien 〈…〉
Mor • fur • e • euine / quin •• narrātur & angues
Ouartue ba • et wges / ineuntes 〈◊〉 septem

Archynon luse • / seyto lud •
〈◊〉 leguntur
Dat Grai • s Thel • s / v ••• em sep •• nis vmb • s
Ocrauo c • adit / Tideus spes vit • pelagis
Ipomedon nono moritur cum Parthonepeo
Fulmine percusso / decimo Canapus superatur
Vndecimo sese / perimunt per vutnera fratres
Argiuam flentem / narrat duodenis & ignem
Of Archenores buryeng / and the playes
And how Amphyoray / fyl thurgh the ground
How Tydeus was slayn lord of Argeys
And how Ipomedon in a lytel stounde
Was dreynt & dede / Parthonope of wound
And how Canapus the prowde
With thonder was slayn that cryed lowde
She gan hym eke telle / how that eyther broder
Ethyocles and Polemyte also
At a scarmuche eche of theym slowe other
And of Argyue / hyr wepyng & hyr woo
And how the town was brent / she told eke th •
And so descendyd doune from gestys old
To Dyomede / & thus she spack & told
This ylke bore bytokeneth Dyomede
Tydeus sonne that doune descended is
Fro Meleager / that made the bore to blode
And thy lady • where that she be ywys
This Dyomede hyr hert hath / & she his
Wepe yf thow wylt or leue / for oute of doute
This Dyomede is in / & thou art out
Thow seyst not soth thou fals sorceres
With al thy fals goost of Prophecye
Thow wenest to be a grete dyuyneres
Now seest thow not this foole of fantasye
Peyneth hyr / on ladyes for to lye
Awey quod he there Iouys yeue the sorowe
Thow shalt be fals paraunter yet to morowe
As wele myghtest thow lye vppon Alceste
That was of creatures / but men lye
That euer was the kyndethe & best
For when hyr husbond was in ieopardye
To dye hym self / but yf she wold dye
She chaas for hym to dye / and goo to helle
And starf anone as vs the bokes telle
Cassandre goth / & he with cruel herte
For that his woo / for anger of her speche
And from his bed al sodeynly he stert
As though al hole hym had made a leche
And day by day / he gan enquere & seche
A sooth of this with al his besy cure
And thus he dryneth forth his aduenture
Fortune whiche hath the permutacyon
Of thynges had / as it is here commytted
By purueaunce and dysposycyoun
Of hym Ioue / as Reygnes shul be flytted
From folk in folk / or when they shal be smitted
Gan pul awey the fethers bryght of Troye
From day to day / tyl they be bare of ioye
Among al this the fyn of the parody
Of Hector gan approche wonder blyue
The faate wold / his soule shold vnbody
And shapen had a mene oute to dryue
Ageynst whiche faat / hym helpyth not to stryue
But on a day to fyght gan be wende
At whiche alas he caught his last ende
For whiche me thynketh yt euery maner wyȝt
That hauntyth armes / ought to bewayle
The deth of hym that was so noble a knyght
For as he drowe a kyng by the auentayle
Vnware of this Achylles thurgh the mayle
And thurgh the body gan hym for to ryue
And thus yt worthy knyȝt was brouȝt frō liue
For whome as old bookes tellen vs
Was made suche wo that tonge may it not telle
And namelyche the sorowe of Troylus
That next hym was of worthynes welle
And in this woo gan Troylus to duelle
That for that sorowe / & loue of his vnrest
Ful ofte a day he had his herte brest
But netheles though he gan hym dyspeyre
He dred ay his lady was vntrewe
Yet ay on hyr his herte gan repayre
And as louers done / he sought ay newe
To gete ageyne Treseyde bryght of hewe
And in his herte he wente ay excusyng
That Calcas caused al hyr taryeng
And oftyme he was in purpoos grete
Hym self lyke a pylgrym to desguyse
To seen hyr / but he couthe not counterfete
To be vnknowe of folk that were wyse
Ne fynd excuse a ryght / that myght suffyse
If he among the grekes knowen were
For whiche he wepte ful ofte many a tere
To hyr he wrote yet efte al newe
Ful pytously he lete not for slouth
Bysechyng hyr / that syth he was trewe
That she wold come ageyne / & hold her trouth
For whiche Creseyde vppon a day for routhe
I take it soo / touchyng al this matere
Wrote hym ageyne / & sayd / as ye may here
Cupydes sone / ensample of goodlyheed
O swerd of knyghthode / sours of gentylnesse
How myght a wyght in turment & in drede
And helthles send yow / as yet gladnesse
I herteles / I syghe in grete dystresse
Syth ye with me nor I with yow may dele
Yow may I send neyther herte ne hele
Youre lettres ful the papyr al be pleynted
Conceyued hath myn hertes pyte
I haue eke seyn with teres al be peynted
Youre letter / & how ye • quyren me
To come ageyne / whiche yet may not be
But why lest that this letter found were
No mencyoun make I now for fere
Greuous to me / god wote your vnreste
Youre hast / & if at the goddes ordynaunce
It semeth not / ye take it for the best
For other thynges nys in youre remembraun ••
As thynketh me / but only youre p • saunce
But he not wroth / and that I yow byseche
For that I tarye / it is for wykked speche
For I haue herd wel more than I wende
Towchyng v • two how thynges haue y stōde
Whiche I shal with dyssymylyng amende
And be ye not wrothe I haue eke vnderstonde
How ye ne doo / but hold me in honde
But now no fore / I can not in yow gesse
But al trouthe euer / and al gentylnesse
Come I wyl / but yet in suche disioynt
I stond as now / but what houre or what daye

That this shal b •
• an I not apoynt
But in effect / I pray yow as I may
Of youre good word / & of youre frendship ay
For trewely / whyse my lyf may dure
As for a frend / ye may in me assurr
Yet I pray yow / on euyl ye ne take
That it is short / whiche I to yow wryte
I dare not there I am wel lettres make
• le neuer yet couthe I wel • endyte
Eke grete effect / men wryte in place lyte
Thene • ut is al / & not the lettres space
And farith now wel god haue you in his grace
Troylus this letter thought al straunge
When he it sawe / and sorowfully he syght
Hym thought it a kalendys of chaunge
But fynally he ful ne trowen myght
That she ne wold hold hym that she hyght
For withful euyl wylle / lyst hym to leue
That louith wele in suche caas / thouȝ hym greue
But netheles men seyn that at the last
For ony thyng / men shuln the sooth see
And suche a caas betyd / and that as fast
That Troylus wele vnderstood that she
Nas not so kynde / as hyr ought to be
And fynally he wote now oute of doute
That al is lost / that he hath ben aboute
Stood on a day / in his melancolye
This Troylus / and in suspectyoun
Of hyr / for whome he wende for to dye
And soo byfel that thurgh Troye Towne
As was the gyse / bore was vp & doime
A maner cote armure / as seyth the story
Byfore Deyphebus in sygne of vyctory
The whiche Cote / as seyth Lollyus
Deyphebe had rent from Dyomede
The same day / and whan this Troylus
It sawe he gan to take of it hede
Auysyng on the lengthe / & of the brede
And al the werk / & as he gan byhold
Ful sodeynly his herte gan to cold
As he that on the coler fond within
A broche that he Creseyde yafe at morowe
That she from Troy must nedes twynne
In remembraunce of hym / & of his sow •••
And she hym leyde her feyth ageyne to borowe
To kepe it / but now ful wele he wyst
His lady was no l • nger for to tryst
He goth hym home / and than ful soone he sende
For Pandarus / & al this newe chaunce
And of his broche / he told hym word & ende
Compleynyng of hyr hertes varyaunce
His long loue / his trouthe & his penaunce
And after dethe withoute wordes more
Ful fast he cryed his rest hym to restore
Than • pak he thus / O lady bryght Creseyde
Where is youre feyth / where is youre byhest
Where is youre loue where is your trouth he seide
O Dyomede / haue ye now al this fest
Alas I wold haue trowed at the lest
That syth ye nold trewe to me stonde
That thus ye nold haue hold me in honde
Who shal now trowe ony othes moo
Alas I wold neuer haue wende or this
That ye Creseyde couthe haue chaunged so
Not but I had a gylt / or done amys
So cruel wende I not youre herte ywys
To slee me thus / alas your name of trouthe
Is now fordone / & that is al my reuthe
Was there none other froche ye lyst to lete
To fese with youre newe leue quod he
But thylk broche / that I with teres weete
Yow yofe / as for a remembraunce of me
None other cause alas ne hadden ye
But for despyte / & eke for that ye ment
Al vtterly to shewe youre entent
Thorugh which I see clene out of your mynde
Ye haue me cast / and I ne can ne may
For al this world within myn herte fynde
To vnloue yow a quarter of a day
In cursyd tyme I borne was wel away
That ye that doo me al this woo endure
Yet loue I best of ony creature
Now god quod he / yet send me that grace
That I may mete with this Dyomede
And trewely yf I haue myght and space
Yet shal I make / I hope his sydes blede
O god quod he that oughtest taken hede
To further trouthe / & wronges to punyce
Why nyl thow doo a vengeaunce of this vyce
O Pandare that in dremes for to tryst
Me blamed hast / & ofte me vp breyde
Now mayst thow see thy self / yf that thow list
How trewe is now thy nece bryght Creseyde
In sondry fourmes / god it wote he seyde
The goddes shewe / bothe ioye & tene
In slepe / and be my dreme it is sene
And certeynly withoute more speche
Form hens forth / as ferforth as I may
Myn owne dethe in armes wylle I seche
I retche not how soone be the daye
But trewely Creseyde swete may
Whome I haue ay with al my myght y seruyd
That ye thus doo / I haue it not deserud
This Pandarus that al these thynges herd
And wyst wele / he sayd a sooth of this
He not a word to hym ageyne answerd
For sory of his frendes / sorowe he is
And shamed for his nece had done amys
And stood astonyed of these causes twey
As stille as stone / a word couthe he not not sey
But at the last / thus he spak & seyde
My broder dere I may doo the no more
What shold I sey / I hate ywys Creseyde
And god wote I wyl haate hyr euermore
And that thou me bysoughtest done of yore
Hauyng vnto myn honoure / nor to my rest
Ryght no reward / I deed al that ye left
If I dyd ought / that myght liken the
It is me •• ef and of this treson now
God wote that it / a sorowe is vnto me
And dredeles for heates 〈◊〉 of you
Right fayn wold I it amende / wise I how
And too thys world almyghty god I pray
Delyuer hyr sone I can no more say
Gre • e was the sorowe & the playnte of tro • lu •
But forth his ceurs of fortune gan to holde
〈◊〉 loueth so the sone of tydeus
And twylus 〈◊〉 wepe in cares colde
Suche is the world who so can beholde
In eche estate is 〈◊〉 hertes reste
God lete v • take it al for the • este
In many cruel bataylle out of drede
Of troylus this ylke noble knyght
〈◊〉 men may in th • se olde bookes red •
Was seen his knyghthode & his grete myght
And dredele • his yrr day and nyght
Ful cruelly the gres • y • ay abought
And alwey most this d •• m • de he sought
And ofte tyme I fynde that they mette
With blody 〈◊〉 & with worde a 〈◊〉
Assay • ng how then speres we • r I w • tt •
And god wotr with 〈◊〉 a cruel 〈◊〉
Can troylus vpon 〈◊〉 to 〈◊〉
But netheles fortune 〈◊〉 not ne wotd
Of other hand that eyther dye shold
And yf I had taken for to wryte
The a • nes of thise ylke worthy man
Than wold I of his bataylles endyte
But for that I to wryte first began
Of his loue I haue sayd as I can
His worthy dedes who so list hem here
Rede dares he can telle hem al in fere
Bysechyng euery lady bryght of hewe
And euery gentylwoman what she be
That al le that Creseyde was vntrewe
That for that gylt ye be not wroth with me
Ye may hyr gylt in other bookes see
And gladlyer I wold wryte / yf yow lest
Penolopes trouthe / and good Alcest
Ne I seye not this / as only for this men
But moost for wymmen that betrayed be
Thorugh fals folk / god yeue hem sorowe amen
That with theyr grete wordes & subtylyte
Bytrayeth yow / & this now meueth me
To speke / & in effect al yow I prey
Beeth ware of men / & herken what I sey
God lytel book / goo lytel Tregedye
That god thy maker / yet or that I dye
So sende me myght / to make somme comedye
But lytel book / make thow none enuye
But subget be thou vnto al Poesye
And kysse ye steppes / where as thow seest space
Of Vyrgyle / Ouyde / Homere / Lucan / & stace
And for ther is so grete dyuersyte
In Englysshe / & in wrytynge of oure tonge
Soo pray to god / that none myswryte the
Ne the mysmetre for defaute of tonge
And red where so thow be / or elles songe
That thow be vnderstonde / god I byseche
But yet to purpoos of my rather speche
The wrathe / as I bygan yow for to seye
Of Troylus how the grekes bought dere
For thousandys of his handes dyd he deye
As he that was withoute ony pere
Saue Hector in his tyme as I can here
But wele awey / sauf only goddes wylle
Dyspytously hym slowe the fyers Achylle
And when that he was slayn in this manere
His lyght goost / ful blysfully is went
Vnto the holownes of the eyght spere
In his place letyng eche element
And there he sawe with ful aduysement
How he was sloyne / alas al to rathe
The folke of Troye to moche harme & skathe
And doune from thens fyrst he gan aduyse
This lytel spot of erthe / that with the see
Enbracyd is / & fully gan despyse
This wretchyd world / & helde it vanyte
To respect of that playne felycyte
That is in heuene aboue / & at the last
There he was slayn / his lokyng doune he case
And in hym self he l • ugh ryght at the woo
On hem that wepen for his deth so fast
And dampnen al oure werkes that folowen so
The blynde lust / whiche that may not last
And shold al oure hertes to heuene cast
Now forth he went shortely for to telle
There as Mercurye sortyd hym to dwelle
Suche fyne hath loo / this Troylus for loue
Suche fyne his loue / suche fyne his noblesse
Suche fyne hath his estate ryal aboue
Suche fyne hath fals worldes trotylnesse
Suche fyne hath al his grete worthynesse
And thus bygan / his louyng of Creseyde
As I haue told / and in this wyse he deyde
O yong fresshe folkes / he or she
In which that loue vp growyth with your age
Repayreth home from worldly vanyte
And of youre herte vp casteth the vysage
To thylk lord / that after his ymage
Yow made / and thynketh al is but a fayre
This world that passyth sone / as ••• ures faire
And louyth hym whiche that ryght for loue
Vpon a crosse oure soules for to beye
Fyrst starf & roose / & syth in heuene aboue
For he wyl fals no wyght dare I seye
That wyl his herte al holy on hym leye
And soothe / he best is to loue / and moost meke
What nedeth feyned loue here for to seke
Loo here of Paynems cursyd old rytes
Loo here what al theyr goddes may auayle
Loo here these worldes wretchyd appetytes
Loo here the fyne & guerdon for trauayle
Of Ioue Appollo / of mars / suche rascayle
Loo here the forme of old clerkes speche
In poetrye / yf ye theyr bookes seche
O moral Gower this book I dyrect
To the and to the Phylosophycal Strode
To vouchesauf there nede is to correct
And of youre benyngnytees / and zelys goode
And to that sothfast / Crist that starf on roode
With al myn herte of mercy I prey
And to the lorde ryght thus I speke & seye
Thou one and twoo / and thre eterne a lyu •
That regnest ay in thre twoo and one
Incircumscript / & al mayst circumscryue
Vs from vysyble and Inuysyble foon
Defende & to thy mercy euerychone
So make vs Ihesu for thy mercy dygne
For loue of mayden / & moder thyn benyngne

div.trailer: Here endeth Troylus / as touchyng Creseyde
